PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Ottawa, August 23rd, 1932.

Sir,-

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant, I beg to say that cheque for your June quarter salary as teacher of the Telegraph Creek Indian Day School is going forward addressed to you at 1445 - 13th Ave. West, Vancouver, B.C.

Owing to a change in our accounting system, there has been some delay in forwarding cheques for the past quarter. The Department regrets any inconvenience that has been caused you in this regard.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland.
For Supt.of Indian Education.

Donald C. McDevitt, Esq.,
1445 - 13th Ave. W.,
Vancouver, B. C.
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

To date I have not received grant due June 30th 1932 on receipt of my Quarterly Returns as Teacher at Telegraph Creek B.C.

I have communicated with Mr. Harper Reed, Indian Agent at Telegraph Creek and have not as yet received any reply.

The reason I write is that I had depended on this for my fare to Telegraph Creek for the opening of School. If in the meantime my cheque has not been mailed would it be possible to obtain same. Thanking you for an early reply.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

**CANADA**
Ottawa, May 29th, 1934.

Sir,

The March quarter return showing the attendance of Indian children at the Telegraph Creek Combined School has just been received.

The return shows an average attendance of 8.88 and, at the rate of $20 per capita per annum, based on the average attendance, the amount due for the March quarter is $53.28. A cheque for this amount is being issued and sent to the Secretary-Treasurer of the Telegraph Creek School Board.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

The Deputy Minister,
Department of Education,
Victoria, B. C.
June 6th, 1934.

J. D. Sutherland, Esq.,
Acting Superintendent of Indian Education,
OTTAWA, ONT.

Dear Sir:

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 28th ult., your file 158-5-3, informing me that you have sent a cheque for $53.28 to Telegraph Creek School Board in respect of the education of Indian children attending the Telegraph Creek School.

Yours very truly,

Superintendent of Education.

SJW:MR
Sir,

I beg to submit herewith the Telegraph Creek Assisted Day School Return ending June 29th 1934.

It will be observed that it is far from good, the reason for this being that the Indians are now feeling the depression to some extent, and have all moved out to their fish camps and other such places where Moose and living is easier to obtain.

Also to some little extent Mr Will Thorman, now in charge of his late father's Mission, that of Thaltan Village, has started in to teach some of the children residing out at the Fish Camp, which is a very good idea indeed; and it is thought that this movement will grow in size.

There are, of course, more White and Halfbreed children attending the Telegraph Creek School now so that the loss of some Indian Children is not so serious to the school itself, but does cut down the Teachers Salary.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant.

Harper Reed,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary
The Dept. Of Indian Affairs.

TELEGRAPH CREEK
INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Several of the 19 Indian children who attend the Provincial Public School are in need of better desk accommodation, there being insufficient desks for their use. Agent Reed was advised to ask the Department to authorize the purchase of new desks as may be reasonably required, not exceeding ten in number. Some school books are also wanted for which the Agent will make requisition. It is thought that assistance should be granted in the manner suggested, since no school tax is imposed in the district either upon white or Indians and the school is remotely situated. In a conversation with one of the local school trustees, Mrs. Hyland, I was advised that difficulty is experienced in securing from the Provincial Education Department sufficient equipment for the proper carrying out of school work here. No doubt, lack of school taxation in Telegraph Creek is responsible.
Sir:

I beg to refer to the report of the Assistant Indian Commissioner dated August 30th in regard to his inspection of the Stikine Indian Agency. On page ten (10) he refers to School Affairs at Telegraph Creek. This portion of the report was sent to the Provincial Department of Education which points out that that Department provides free of cost to rural districts all pupils' desks that are required in any of the rural schools of the Province, and that all that is necessary is for the School Board to apply to the Education Department giving the actual number of desks of each size (small, medium or large) that are needed at the school. The district itself is expected to provide all other necessary equipment and supplies for the teacher. As a large number of Indian children are in attendance at Telegraph Creek the Superintendent of Education considers it to be in order for the Department of Indian Affairs to make a small yearly grant of say $25.00 to $30.00 for school supplies and maintenance.

I have sent instructions to Agent Reed to take the matter of the school desks up with the School Board at Telegraph Creek with a view to their making requisition for necessary school desks.

With regard to other equipment and maintenance, I would recommend that this Department provide a grant as indicated by the Superintendent of Education. The same could be expended when necessary by arrangement between the Indian Agent, the local Trustees and Board of Education.

Your obedient servant,

W. E. Ditchburn.
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

I am instructed by the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, to make application to the Government for a grant to an Indian School at Ucluelet. The facts concerning it, are the following:

1. The School was opened about the beginning of September, 1894.

You will recollect the sad death of the Rev. M. Swartout of Ucluelet. His widow & daughter, a girl of perhaps 20 years of age remain there & the Church propose to allow them a salary to carry on the school & attend to evangelistic work among the Indians. The suggestion is that Mrs. Swartout should carry on the day school but should have permission to allow her daughter to assist or take her place in the school if her health should not always allow her to teach. Mrs. Swartout is also, I think quite qualified to teach such a school but neither of them have a certificate & the Church writes me asking if that fact or allowing them both to teach would interfere with the grant from the Dept. I am going to Ucluelet next week & will have an opportunity to notice how they get on with the work but meantime have the honor to enquire whether you would have any objection to Mrs. Swartout being appointed teacher, tho not holding a diploma & also whether the daughter might be allowed to assist in the teaching occasionally, subject of course to there being no falling off in the work of the school. They are not of course well off & the Church would like to help them. I do not think there would be any danger of deterioration to the school.

Dear Mr. Scott:-

Your note received enquiring as to Mr. Vanderveen's qualifications for appointment to Ucluelet school. I am sorry if we neglected to notify you of Mr. Vanderveen's application and to seek the Department's approval of his appointment. The correspondence with him was conducted in October last, although he did not enter upon his duties until February.

In his application he states that he has had a High School education, followed by a special course at Cornell University. Before going west he had two year's city mission work, and during the three years of his service at the Regina School, whilst he was farm instructor, he came into touch with every department of the work on the Reserve, as well as the school; We felt that we could scarcely expect to get a man with better qualifications for so secluded a spot as Ucluelet. He was very highly recommended by Mr. Eaton, the principal of the Regina school, as well as by Rev. Mr. Henry, Presbyterian minister at Regina. So far I believe the indications are that the appointment is a good one. He seems to have entered into his work with a good deal of interest and writes as though enjoying it.

The frequent changes amongst the workers in the Indian work is embarrassing, but I think we are gradually getting a higher grade into the service. We have probably on the Plains one or two yet who are not very efficient, but all the others are, I believe, capable and doing satisfactory work. I hope Mr. Vanderveen's appointment will meet with your approval.

I am,

Yours sincerely,

R.F.M./MBA.

I have tried to make this day school work here as

I desire to leave here April 1st and I have notified the
Secretary of our Indian Mission work of the same last December.

Attendance is not at all satisfactory. Parents are not interested in education.

Mr. Ross has now resigned as teacher.

Mrs. Chas. Clark of Toronto, Secretary of Indian Work for the W.M.S. of the Presbyterian Church, was present during my inspection of this school.

She informed me that they had engaged a qualified and experienced teacher to take charge of this school, September 1st, 1918.

RECOMMENDATION:

I would most respectfully recommend that the Agent of this reservation visit the Indians after their return from fishing and notify them of the fact that a capable teacher had come to take charge of their school and further that the Department expected them to send their children regularly to school.

If after this warning they do not send their children to school, the Agent should get the names of some two or three of the most irregular pupils and place these on one of the boarding schools.

This, I believe, would stimulate the attendance.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letters of the 13th and 15th instant in reference to the appointment of Miss Gertrude Lawrence as teacher of the Ucluelet Indian Day School and asking for certain information in regard to the school.

In reply I beg to say that this school is closed during the months of July and August for the holidays.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

Ottawa, March 13, 1920.

MEMORANDUM. Mr. Scott,-

Rev. Mr. Edmison, Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the Presbyterian Church, requests that Miss Gertrude Lawrence be appointed teacher of the Ucluelet Day School at a salary of $900.00 per annum, to succeed the present teacher, who is resigning on March 31st, next.

Miss Lawrence's record in the service of the Department is as follows:- She was appointed teacher at the Assiniboine Day School in September, 1910, at a salary of $550.00 per annum. This was increased to $720.00 on the first of January, 1911, and she remained at this school until June 30th, 1916. She was appointed teacher at Ucluelet on September 4th, 1918, at $750.00 and remained there until June 30th, 1919, when she was transferred to the Cote's Day School at the same salary and left there on December 31st, last. It is now requested that she be again appointed teacher at Ucluelet at an increased salary of $900.00 per annum.

She has a Second Class Professional Ontario Certificate, with normal training, and also a Second Class Professional Certificate for Alberta.

Inspector Cairns, reporting on her work at Ucluelet, states that the school had a successful year, largely due to the fact that the teacher has been zealous and efficient. She knows how to present a lesson so as to interest the pupils. Her reason for leaving Ucluelet was lack of accommodation, and she thought the salary should equal that paid to the public school teachers in the same community.

I should be pleased to be informed as to whether
her appointment as teacher at Ucluelet should be approved,
and, if so, whether she be granted a salary at the rate of
$900.00 per annum.

Dear Sir,

At the meeting of the Executive of our Board held last week I conferred with Dr. Wilson, our District Superintendent from Vancouver, in regard to securing a teacher for Ucluelet. Dr. Wilson strongly advised that a male teacher should be sent to an isolated point like Ucluelet. It does not seem possible to keep a lady teacher there for any length of time. While we had our missionary Mr. Ross living there, the teacher stayed with them and seemed contented, but now the situation is different. Dr. Wilson says he could secure a male teacher but fears he could not accomplish this with a salary of $750. He thinks he could secure a man on the coast for $900 or $1000. Through him I learn that the Government is already paying $900 to some of the Indian teachers on the coast, and at schools where the attendance is no larger, if as large. I will be glad to know by return mail if you can see your way clear to provide a salary of $900 if we can secure the man.

Yours sincerely,

Sir:

On making the customary Reserve patrol when in Ucluelet and investigating certain reports that had been given by Indians, according to your instructions I investigated the reported religious activities at the Ucluelet Indian Church on the Itatscoo #1 Reserve.

On Sunday 26th, February, 1933, at 10 P.M. I arrived at the Ucluelet Indian Church on the Itatscoo Reserve. There I found the Indians and Miss Ryckman together with Mrs. Moore (a sister of Miss Ryckman, the teacher and missionary), engaged in a strange religious practice. These practices seemed to consist of working the Indians up to a frenzy and then they would all chant and some of the Indians would come up to the front of the Church and face the wall and after some time had elapsed they would start to break into an unintelligible gibberish, this gibberish was neither English, Chinook or the Indian language. I watched for some time and then the Indians started to leave the front of the Church, then noticed that there were several prostrate on the floor and that there was what appeared to be a sheet, or some white cloth fastened up to the wall and that the Indians had been facing this. During the time I was there I heard no religious instruction of any kind, but songs were chanted and religious ejaculations were heard throughout the crowd. Mrs. Moore was at all times at the front of the church and was passing through the Indians and inciting them in these demonstrations, while Miss Ryckman was at the rear of the church, holding her hands over her head and chanting. I left the vicinity of the church shortly after the closing of the services at 11:45 p.m. and proceeded to the M.S. Duncan Scott where I made my verbal report to you.

I have enquired from some of the most reliable Indians re these services and they all report that it is the practice to hold them very late at night and that they are held every night but Monday.

Ed. E. Frost, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Alberni, B.C.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

As requested by you, I made a patrol of the Ucluelet Indian Reserve (Itatsoo No. 1) on Sunday March 12th 1933.

On arriving near the Church my attention was called to unusual sounds apparently coming from the vicinity of the church. I went over to that building and looked through the window; there were about a dozen persons in the Church, two of whom were white women, and the rest Indians. They were practicing what appeared to be some form of religious ceremony or rite; they were chanting, moaning and posturing and making unintelligible noises also waving their arms and gesturing. There was some object on the wall at the end of the Church, that they seemed to be attracted to; I could not make out what it was. I arrived at the church at approximately 11 p.m. and left at approximately 12 noon at which time the service was still continuing.

On questioning an Indian youth (one Willie Tutube) who was on the sidewalk by the Church, he informed me that one of the white women taking part in the service was Mrs. Moore, a sister of Miss E.B. Ryckman, the United Church Missionary teacher at the Ucluelet School. Miss Ryckman was the other; he also stated that these services are held a number of times each week and that they often lasted until 2 or three o'clock in the morning.

As I am not conversant with the regular form of worship practiced by the United Church and did not consider myself competent to judge whether the ceremonies being carried on at Ucluelet were the regular form of worship or not, I requested the R.C.M.P and the B.C. Police to attend at one or more of these meetings and make a report on what actually happened, the enclosed reports were made of meetings that took place on entirely different dates.

After having received these reports I sent copies of same to the Rev. F.W. Pitts, who is an ordained Minister of that faith, for his information and if he considered it advisable, his action, Mr. Pitts later informed me verbally that he reported the matter to the United Church Mission Board at Toronto. To ensure that the Department being conversant with what had occurred, the attached reports were submitted to Ottawa.

I am convinced of the wisdom of the Department's intended action to request the United Church to change the teaching service at Ucluelet as I feel sure that a change would benefit the teacher herself and be in the interest of the Church.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

Following the communications which were addressed to us concerning the situation at Ucluelet, our Superintendent of Missions in British Columbia, Dr. S. S. Osterhout, made a personal visitation. Bruce Gray, M.A., B.D., who has for four years been assistant minister at our largest church in Victoria. Dear Sir:

I have been informed this morning that Mr. Neil Perry, at present teacher of the Indian Day School at Uclulet, has been appointed Secretary of the Economic Council working under the Provincial Government, and that he wishes to resign his position as teacher of the above School. I have instructed Mr. Perry to forward a written resignation to the Department explaining the circumstances of the case through Mr. Indian Agent Frost.

Dr. Wilson of the First United Church, Victoria, and Professor Farr, Victoria College, have had conferences with me this morning with regard to the future of the work at Uclulet. I understand that the authorities of the United Church of Canada, on the recommendation of the above named gentlemen, intend to nominate the below mentioned candidate as teacher and missionary at Uclulet Indian Day School.

Mr. Charles Storch,
1046 Lyall Street,
Victoria, B.C.

I may say that I have interviewed Mr. Storch today and see no reason why he would not make a success of the work as teacher at Uclulet. He is a member of the United Church of Canada; twenty-six years of age; trained at Victoria Normal School 1926-29 and holds a first-class B.C. Teacher's certificate. He has full second year standing in the University of British Columbia and almost four years' experience teaching in the ungraded and graded Provincial schools. Mr. Storch is well recommended by the Provincial Inspectors and Principals under whom he served. He has taught the Sunday School at the First United Church, Victoria, for eight years and his class of boys is the largest in any Sunday School in Victoria. Mr. Storch can lead the Church singing at Uclulet as well as teach this subject in the Day School. He is in very good health, six feet three tall and weighs one hundred and eighty pounds.
Mr. Perry,

I understand that it is quite possible that Mr. Storch will marry Miss Irene Helgesen, who is twenty-four years of age and a fully trained nurse, today.

As it is necessary that the teacher of the Uclulet Indian Day School should proceed from Victoria either by boat this evening or at latest by stage tomorrow, the United Church are instructing Mr. Storch to take over Mr. Neil Perry's work, pending his appointment by the Department of Indian Affairs. I would therefore ask you to communicate with the Department in this matter, if possible by night letter. I may say in conclusion that I think Mr. Storch a very good candidate for the position left vacant by Mr. Perry's resignation.

Your obedient servant,

"Gerald H. Barry."

Dear Mr. Hoey:

You will remember that when I was in your office, you spoke about the need of making changes in our teaching staff in British Columbia at Ucluelet and at Alberni. I took the matter up when I was there, and secured the co-operation of the officials in British Columbia.

I also interviewed Miss Pitts, and talked to her about the work and the desire to have a change made.

From the report submitted by Captain Barry - which you showed me - I gathered that there was every disposition on his part to have both Mr. Von Storch and Miss Pitts given an opportunity to make good somewhere else.

I beg, therefore, to nominate to your department as the Teacher at Klemtu, Mr. Charles Von Storch.

For Ucluelet I beg to nominate Mr. E.B. Severson who has been our Missionary-Teacher at Fort Essington. I know that Captain Barry's report concerning Mr. Severson was not too enthusiastic, but at the same time I gathered that he might have another opportunity in a different type of community. That is why we are nominating him for Ucluelet.

For Campbell River I beg to nominate Miss Ketha Pitts who has been serving at Alberni.

With kindest regards, believe me,

Yours sincerely,

Geo. Dorey.

Extract from report of Inspector Barry on his visit to the Ucluelet Indian Day School on March 20, 1942:

Though I have not the official file with me I believe that Mr. Noble was only given a temporary appointment as teacher of the Ucluelet Indian Day School. It is quite obvious that he is not a success at that school, and I would recommend that he be not employed as a teacher of an Indian day school after the end of the present academic year.

The progress of the children at Ucluelet this year has been most unsatisfactory. It is very difficult for me to believe that Mr. Noble has in fact taught the pupils anything of a worth while nature.

April 5, 1943

Dear Sirs,

Re my recent leave of absence to attend the Victoria Preaching, I wish to state I am very sorry I was absent when the Provincial Inspector came to examine my school. It was very unfortunate and I sincerely hope you will not regard Mr. Ashbridge to blame for the event, or if you criticize my actions also you have a right to criticize my actions also.

First I asked the Agent for two days intending to board the Head Boat at 3 p.m. or 3-30 p.m. or may be as late as 4 p.m. Having an arrangement with an Indian to take me over. You cannot I have found rely upon the Indian they do not even notify you when they cannot fulfill a contract, I was left on the float alone.

I had a serious epidemic of the on the Reserve with the result on Wednes. our four children came, whole families were stricken. At noon one of the four went home sick and the others seemed ready to follow.
So when I saw the Mail Boat arriving early and knowing I had to walk two miles to Albion Bay to board it, I did not call the school but gave the three children credit for attendance. If I have done wrong, I ask forgiveness, I am sorry.

Then I was told the Speedboat came every Sunday, it had done so for two previous Sundays and it was not until I arrived in Port Alberni that I discovered it only came when chartered. To be sure of returning Sunday, I had to place $40 in the hands of Mr. Riley. I was in a predicament. I called at the Agency to ask for another day under the circumstances in Monday. Mr. Ashbridge was in Victoria, the secretary told me he would be there until Friday. I went to Victoria hoping to get the Agent's permission to close the school on Monday, with the "flu" so bad I thought another day would be worse rather than a loss. I may conscientiously say that had I been at the Reserve I doubt whether there would have been more than three children present at school on the Thursday morning.

Having found myself compelled to break the school law, I thought I would teach on Saturday. I found myself with the "flu" in bed all Sat and most of Sunday. I had it all that week and the following Saturday was completely...
exhausted and unable to teach. I spent that Saturday in bed. Well I yet had hopes of getting that extra day's teaching in during March. I didn't want to say anything about the matter to the Agent who had so kindly given me the two days. But it seems the devil will out. I find he has heard through some means or other of my action.

Well allow me to state that I believe in justice and I will be as fair as I can. I took the liberty of giving the children credit for a day's schooling they have not yet had but (D.V.) and health permitting I am planning to teach an extra day during the Easter vacation. I realize this does not exempt me from breaking the letter of the school law but it does fulfill the spirit.

Will you kindly forgive me, and allow me to make this amends? If my actions are too bad for this, all I can say is, I am sorry and I will have to face the consequences. Please understand I did not know the Inspector was coming or was already in Ucluelet, if he had phoned on arrival I would gladly have cancelled a trip on which I had set my heart.

Hoping this will explain my part in this case—
Yours respectfully,
Bishop Black.
Please excuse the paper I have just run out of writing paper and it is two miles to the store.

BB.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Ucluelet Indian Day School

I have a long letter from Rev. Bishop Black, who tells me that he has got into serious trouble by absenting himself from his school. I heard about it when I was in Vancouver and I rather expected to hear from you in the meantime. Mr. Black was very anxious to attend the Victoria Presbytery, in order to hear the Moderator, Dr. Sclater. I gather that he had asked Mr. Ashbridge for a two days' leave of absence, but, through a combination of circumstances, he was not able to return for Monday. I think he did everything he could, but he did not get back in time to teach on the day when the Inspector had gone to inspect the school.

I shall be very glad if you will let me know what action the Department contemplates. I should like to have the opportunity of discussing the matter with you when I am in Ottawa before anything definite is done. I think Mr. Black is doing a reasonably good piece of work as a teacher, and I am sure that he had no intention of breaking a rule when he started out. I have had no copies of letters which you have sent him, and consequently can only write from what Mr. Black tells me.

Yours sincerely,

I beg to refer to your letter, dated May 11th,
1943, in connection with the Ucluelet Day School, and to
report that the school building is very old and gives a
very poor impression to the casual visitor, while being
kept as clean as is possible under the circumstances.
The surroundings are poor, being situated on the edge of
the reserve, and the walks and grounds have a depressing
appearance.

Attendance at this school is very poor and the
parents are difficult to deal with, unless stern measures
are employed. Owing to the majority of the parents being
employed by the cannery, one mile distant, children are
either left home with little or no care, or are taken to
the cannery with them, hence the absence from school.
The present teacher, Reverend Bishop Black, apparently
lacks initiative and experience in dealing with Indians,
and is essentially a missionary, inclined to placate the
parents and allow the children to dominate the school,
rather than insist in attendance and use kindly firmness
in his dealings with the pupils.

In view of the unfortunate record of this school
over the past few years and the poor prospects of instit-
uting a worthwhile day school, also in the interests of
the neglected children, I would respectfully recommend that
this school be closed and the remaining eligible pupils be
absorbed by the Alberni Residential School. Attendance at
this school at inspection in April was 3, at May inspection
5. Three of these arrived one hour late on both occasions.

P. B. Ashbridge,

Grades One and Two. Thirty-seven pupils.

The above-named school has been closed since 1943 for the reason that the available pupilage was insufficient to warrant its continued operation. INSPECTION OF SCHOOLS:

Ahousat Day School on day of inspection had an attendance of only three pupils; two of whom could not read. This was partly due to families being away at the Canneries. On the whole this school was very disappointing, and I feel that the teacher is wasting her time.

Day schools is emphasized. The school at Ucluelet should be re-opened if a teacher can be found. Season day schools also should be conducted at Nootka, Kildonan, and Ceepeecoo, as the parents cannot leave their children behind when employed at the Canneries; and the Residential schools cannot accommodate them. In consequence there are several over school age who cannot obtain an education.

P.B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

Ucluelet Day school also shows a little better attendance. School and pupils both found clean and tidy. Grounds and sanitary arrangements are in good order. Re: New School - Ucluelet, B.C.

District School Inspector Davey recently conducted a survey of the school age and pre-school age children on the Ucluelet Reserve, West Coast Agency, and those on the Toquart Reserve, less than a mile away, and found that the enrolment from the Ucluelet Reserve was twenty-five and that there were fifteen or sixteen school age children from the Toquart Reserve who could attend if classroom space was made available. It is apparent, therefore, that the two-room school with teacher's quarters will be necessary to meet our requirements at that point. Mr. Davey also ascertained that erection of a one-room school at Olahoose was unnecessary and consequently, it is recommended that the appropriation for schools at these two points be combined, thus making available a total of $28,000.00 for the erection of the required two-room school at Ucluelet. Subsequently Mr. Davey visited Ucluelet with a representative of National All-Steel Buildings Limited, who have now submitted the attached tender in the amount of $23,700.00, for the erection of a Quonset building in accordance with the plan attached.

Questionnaire completed by Superintendent Garrard with regard to this school building, is also enclosed, but I gather from Mr. Neary's various letters that we are not in a position to consider the erection of precut, prefabricated or Quonset buildings until we have investigated the possibilities of securing firm tenders on the erection of the Department's standard school building. If this is correct, have you sufficient information to proceed with the advertisement immediately, or if not, will you please let me know what additional information is required.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Encl.

Subject: Quonset 40' x 52' - 2-room school with teacher's quarters above for Ucluelet Indian Reserve.

Dear Sirs:

We are pleased to quote our firm price of $23,700.00 for the school complete as per plan but less plumbing and electrical work. This price includes rough grading of site and playgrounds, and the following:

1. Cement Foundation and partial basement.
2. Floors - Linoleum on 3/8 veneer over shiplap.
3. Insulation - 2" Fibre Glass as per plan.
4. Dado - 4' of ¼ P.V. hardboard.
5. Walls and Ceiling - ½ Donnacona.
6. Blackboards - one side and both ends of classrooms.
7. Windows - double hang throughout except in toilets which are standard Quonset sash.
8. Doors - Monodoors as per plan.
9. Stairways - fir, treads as per plan.
10. Inside Trim - ½ x ¾ Crown mold around doors and windows 1¼" - ½ rd. at dado line.
11. Baseboard - 4" bullnosed.
12. Outside finish - 1¼ x 1-3/4 stucco mold.
13. Painting - 3 Coats outside trim - 2 coats inside wall and trim.
14. Toilet rooms - Flexboard walls and ceiling with Asphalt tile floors.
15. Heating - 30" wood furnace with necessary ducts.

Memorandum:

CHIEF TREASURY OFFICER.

Ucluelet Indian Day School
Clahoose Indian Day School.

In our Main 1949-50 Estimates is the sum of $14,000.00 for the erection of one-room schools and residences on each of the above reserves in the West Coast Indian Agency.

We have now received a recommendation from Mr. Indian Commissioner Arneil reading as follows:

"District School Inspector Davey recently conducted a survey of the school age and pre-school age children on the Ucluelet Reserve, West Coast Agency, and those on the Toquart Reserve, less than a mile away, and found that the enrolment from the Ucluelet Reserve was twenty-five and that there were fifteen or sixteen school age children from the Toquart Reserve who could attend if classroom space was made available. It is apparent, therefore, that the two-room school with teacher's quarters will be necessary to meet our requirements at that point. Mr. Davey also ascertained that erection of a one-room school at Clahoose was unnecessary and consequently it is recommended that the appropriation for schools at these two points be combined, thus making available a total of $28,000.00 for the erection of the required two-room school at Ucluelet".

Therefore, would you please take the necessary action to have $14,000.00 transferred from the Clahoose project to the Ucluelet project as recommended by Mr. Arneil and concurred in by myself.

Director,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Ucluelet Indian Day School.

Included in our estimates for 1949-50 is the sum of $14,000.00 for the erection of a one-room school and teacherage on the Ucluelet Indian Reserve, West Coast Agency, British Columbia.

We have now received a letter from Mr. Indian Commissioner Arnell in which he states as follows:

"District School Inspector Davey recently conducted a survey of the school age and pre-school age children on the Ucluelet Reserve, West Coast Agency, and those on the Toquart Reserve, less than a mile away, and found that the enrolment from the Ucluelet Reserve was twenty-five and that there were fifteen or sixteen school age children from the Toquart Reserve who could attend if classroom space was made available. It is apparent therefore, that the two-room school with teacher's quarters will be necessary to meet our requirements at that point. Mr. Davey also ascertained that erection of a one-room school at Clahoose was unnecessary and consequently it is recommended that the appropriation for schools at these two points be combined, thus making available a total of $28,000.00 for the erection of the required two-room school at Ucluelet".

In view of the information now received, I would recommend as follows:

(1) That a two-room school be erected at Ucluelet in place of a one-room school.
(2) That the sum of $14,000 be transferred from the Clahoose project to the Ucluelet project.

(3) That approval be given to the attached requisition to the Departmental Purchasing Agent for the insertion of the attached advertisement in the newspapers indicated.

Director.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL,

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources has provided for the construction of a two-room Indian Day School and attached teachers' residence on the Ucluelet Indian Reserve in the West Coast Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, for the education of the Indian children living there;

THAT, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, tenders have been advertised for in local and trade newspapers;

THAT we have received, as a result of these advertisements, the following three tenders:

(1) National All-Steel Buildings, Vancouver, B.C. ... $23,700.00

(2) Souther Construction Company,
Port Alberni, B.C. ................... $42,612.00

(3) Turner Contracting Company, (telegram only)
Port Alberni, B.C. .................... $46,600.00

THAT the above tenders have been examined by Departmental officials and it is found that that of the Souther Construction Company complies with the conditions outlined on tender forms as prepared by the Indian Affairs Branch and the plans and specifications as prepared by the Lands and Development Services Branch;

THAT the tender of the National All-Steel Buildings, Limited, is for a quaint type school;

THAT similar low-cost schools of this type, erected by provincial and municipal school authorities, have been examined by our officials and found to be satisfactory;

THAT Departmental officials, therefore, recommend the acceptance of the lowest tender, namely that of National All-Steel Buildings, Limited, of Vancouver, British Columbia, in an amount of $23,700.00;

THAT funds are available for this purpose in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.
The undersigned, therefore, recommends the acceptance of the tender of National All-Steel Buildings, Limited, of Vancouver, British Columbia, for the erection of this two-room Indian Day School and attached teachers' residence in the amount of $23,700.00 which, with contingencies, may amount to the sum of Twenty-six Thousand Dollars ($26,000.00).

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Valuelot Indian Day School.

Included in our Estimates for 1949-50 is the sum of $28,000.00 for the erection of the above school (originally $14,000 but increased to this amount when two-room school found to be needed after educational survey).

In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, we called for tenders for the erection of a standard two-room school and teachers' residence on this reserve. When these tenders were opened the following three bids were noted:

(1) National All-Steel Buildings, Vancouver, B.C. .... $23,700.00
(2) Souther Construction Co., Port Alberni, B.C. ....... 42,612.00
(3) Turner Contracting Company, Port Alberni, B.C. (Telegram only) ............... 46,600.00

The plan for a Quonset building accompanied the tender of National All-Steel Buildings, Limited. The other two firms would of course erect a school by standard methods of construction.

Our Superintendent of Education immediately sent an Airmail letter to Mr. Indian Commissioner Arnell to ascertain whether they were prepared to recommend the erection of this Quonset school, in lieu of our standard plan.
An army message has just been received from Mr. Arneil reading as follows:

"RE YOUR LETTER UGLUMLUT SCHOOL RECOMMEND
IN THIS CASE ACCEPTANCE OF NATIONAL ALL STEEL BUILDING TENDER."

In view of the following facts I would recommend the approval of the Minister for the attached Submission to Council:

(1) There is a difference of nearly $20,000 between the Quonset tender and that of the lowest bidder for standard construction.

(2) The acceptance of this tender will eliminate the need for either a transfer of funds from another project or the inclusion of additional funds in our Supplementary Estimates.

(3) The erection of a Quonset type school will take only six to eight weeks and should be ready for occupancy by October.

Acting Director.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated 26th July, 1949 from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources has provided for the construction of a two-room Indian Day School and attached teachers' residence on the Ucluelet Indian Reserve in the West Coast Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, for the education of the Indian children living there;

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Act, tenders have been advertised for in local and trade newspapers with the following results:

(1) National All-Steel Buildings, Vancouver, B.C. ... $23,700.00
(2) Souther Construction Company,
    Port Alberni, B.C. ......................... $42,612.00
(3) Turner Contracting Company, (telegram only)
    Port Alberni, B.C. ................. $46,600.00

That the above tenders have been examined by Departmental officials and it is found that that of the Souther Construction Company complies with the conditions outlined on tender forms as prepared by the Indian Affairs Branch and the plans and specifications as prepared by the Lands and Development Services Branch;

That the tender of the National All-Steel Buildings, Limited, is for a Quonset type school;

That similar low-cost schools of this type, erected by provincial and municipal school authorities, have been examined by our officials and found to be satisfactory;

That Departmental officials, therefore, recommend the acceptance of the lowest tender, namely that of National All-Steel Buildings Limited, of Vancouver, British Columbia, in an amount of $23,700.00.

That funds are available for this purpose in Vote 230, 1949-50, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

The Honourable
the Minister of Mines & Resources.

Superintendent Garrard, reference his letter of November 5th attached, following a recent inspection of the school construction project at Ucluelet, has reported various changes which should be made to the structure before it is completed. These changes which are outlined in his letter have been discussed with National All-Steel Buildings Limited, who are prepared to supply the materials and do the work additional to their contract. They have offered to -

1. Install eight larger sash in the front basement wall for ........................................ $280.00

2. Replace the window in the rear cloak room with one Mono door for ........................................ $75.00

3. Install a 4' x 4' "Alsynite" panel above the front door for ........................................ $66.50

4. Fit and install 1½" galvanized pipe posts and railing on both sides of the concrete steps for ........ $150.00

5. Install an additional window in the upstairs living quarters similar to the one in the living room for $189.00

6. Provide supervision, transportation, freight, etc., in connection with the above-mentioned changes at a cost of ........................................ $100.00

It is regretted that these improvements were not apparent to us at the time the plan of the building was approved but the fact remains that all of the above listed items, with the possible exception of No.5, are matters which should be attended to before the structure is completed and I would suggest that if authority for the expenditure required cannot be expeditiously secured, I be authorized to enter into a separate agreement with National All-Steel Buildings for each of these improvements.

Re: Ucluelet Indian Day School

On my recent visit to the above School it was noted that:

1. The lighting in the basement of this building is inadequate. The windows which are to be installed 30" x 18" being too small to admit sufficient light and it is recommended that the eight openings in the front of the School be increased from 30" x 18" to 30" x 36".

2. This building has only one exit on the ground floor the only other exit from the building being through the furnace room, the approach to which comes within a few feet of the main exit. It is suggested that an additional exit be made where the present plans call for a window at the back of the left end of the building looking at it from the front. A sketch enclosed. This would also decrease the distance to be travelled to get to the upper floor when approaching from the rear where a well will be situated. I believe, this will be a necessity if this building is inspected by a fire Marshall.

3. The front hall has insufficient light. Namely a glass panel in a door which will be approximately 2' x 2' at the most. It is suggested that a 4' x 4' opaque fluted panel be fitted immediately above the door. This can be made out of one panel similar to the one above the landing on the upper floor.

4. That a guard or rail be fitted on both sides of the front steps as the height from the door level to the ground when filled in will be about 6 feet, at present nearly eight.

5. That an additional window similar to the one in the living room be installed in the front of the building opening out of the Lounge? The present windows open on the eastern end and look out on to trees only whereas the one on the front will look seaward and give additional light making this a most pleasant room with a splendid view.

N.W. Garrard
Superintendent
Indian Agency.

Re: Sidewalk - Ucluelet School

Would you kindly grant authority for the expenditure of $290.00 for the construction of a plank walk from the present village walk to the new Ucluelet School. This is required as at present it is necessary to walk through a heavy black mud which is from 5 to 12 inches in depth. There is at present a few planks or boards on the ground but these only serve to stop one from going too deep into the mud.

This walk will require to be approximately 320 feet long and raised off the ground. It is proposed to have this three plants wide the same as the walk which the band have constructed from their Band Funds and which goes through the Village.

The requirements will be 60 pieces of 2 x 12 x 16, 20 pieces 4 x 4 x 16, 400 feet of shiplap is also required for lining the sides of the store-room in the basement as this was not included in the contract.

Memorandum to Mr. Robinson:

Re: Ucluelet Indian School
Alberni Agency, B.C.

On February 28 I inspected the school building recently erected by the National All-Steel Buildings Ltd. On this trip I was accompanied by Mr. Garrard, Superintendent, West Coast Agency.

The contract for this structure was awarded on August 18, 1949 and the school was opened January 9, 1950. The contract was let on the contractor's plans dated March 24, 1949 and their letter dated July 5, 1949. The Contractor has not completed his contract in respect to the following items:

(1) Leaks from the Roof

There is definitely at least two leaks from the roof as water runs in at every rainfall into the front bedroom and down the partition between the kitchen and bathroom. I noticed that some of the washers under the screws holding down the corrugated iron are turned upward. This might be the cause of the leaks.

The leaks have existed all winter.

(2) Leaks from End Windows

On both end walls of the concrete basement at the ground floor joists there is indication that water comes down the inside of the end walls of the building. Water also comes in through the classroom ceilings. In my opinion, this water comes from the end walls and enters the walls at the second story windows. At these windows the corrugated iron sheathing butts against the window jamb with no further protection to keep the water out. The plan shows a window trim on the outside and this is not on. I suggest that metal be applied to the junction of the corrugated iron and the window jamb and that it be covered with the window trim.

(3) Floors

The floors consist of asphalt tile on 3/8" plywood laid on building paper over shiplap. In both classrooms in the hall between them and on the landing of the second floor much of the tile is broken up. This is caused by warping of the plywood. It is evident that the plywood was laid when the shiplap was wet.

The tile on the top tread of the stairs was left protruding over the tread one-half inch, causing it to break off unevenly. This tile should have been set back
from the edge of the tread with a protective strip of metal or hardwood.

(4) Sags in Floor

The floor in Classroom No. 2 drops noticeably between the supporting partition in the basement and the stair well. I understand that the post at the stairway in the basement was put in after the sag took place. An attempt should have been made to jack this section of floor back into place before the finishing work was done.

(5) Sags in Donnacona

Some sheets of donnacona on the ceiling are sagging. There are no headers at end of sheets and not sufficient nails in the sheets.

(6) Staircase

The type of treads used was for placing between two walls. The exposed end of the treads should be trimmed to make a finished job. The rail and post have not been painted.

(7) Basement Floor

The basement floors, except for the furnace rooms, are an extra to the contract. These floors were badly finished in that sags in the surface allow one-half inch of water to lie in places on the floor. No floor drains were put in the play rooms but a drain was put through the end wall at floor level in the store rooms. Water only runs out this drain when it becomes deep on the floor.

(8) Leveling Grounds

There are felled trees on the grounds around the building not yet limbed. The backfilling of the building has not been completed. In places water has been lying two feet deep in pot holes against the wall. Much of the water in the basement came from this source.

(9) No heating was supplied to the single teacher's room on the second storey.

(10) The interior painting is very poor for a two coat job.

There has no doubt been condensation in the building, particularly in the basement, from the green concrete. This has been aggravated by seepage from pot holes around the wall, from leaks from the roof and end walls, and from the fact that there never was sufficient heat put on the building to dry out the wet lumber used in construction.

I recommend that the Contractor be required to rectify the items outlined above.

R. M. Martin

That similar low-cost schools of this type, erected by provincial and municipal school authorities, have been examined by our officials and found to be satisfactory;

Re: Ucluelet Indian Day School

With reference to Mr. Phelan's letter of March 9th, the original quotation from National All-Steel Buildings and blueprint are returned herewith.

District School Inspector Davey visited this new school shortly after the Company's Final Progress Payment #3 attached hereto, was submitted, and reported quite unfavourably with regard to some of the work. In order to protect the Department it was deemed advisable to have the structure inspected by one of our engineering staff and at the first opportunity Mr. R.M. Martin proceeded to Ucluelet and in due course reported, reference his memorandum of March 15th, attached. A meeting with Mr. DeWolf, General Manager of All-Steel Buildings, and his Construction Supervisor, was subsequently arranged and the defects in the structure were discussed in some detail. We found it difficult, however, to place responsibility for all these defects entirely on the contractor for the reason that no detailed specifications accompanied the contractor's tender and his responsibilities with regard to heating the building during construction, etc., were not clearly defined.

National All-Steel Buildings Ltd., is presently in the process of liquidation and actually they do not now have the facilities for remedying the defects in the structure and to insist on their doing so would inevitably result in considerable delay. Under these circumstances it is considered advisable to have our engineering staff assess the cost of
completing the work and to relieve the contractor of further responsibility by reducing the amount due him under the contract by this cost. Mr. Martin and Mr. Robinson of the engineering staff feel the work could be completed for $1200.00 and the Company, reference their letter of March 28th attached, is satisfied to have payment due them reduced by this amount in order to quickly conclude the matter. This is desirable from their point of view as they wish to have liquidation of the Company concluded as soon as possible and it is desirable from our point of view because it will enable us to complete payment under the contract from this year's funds.

Mr. DeWolf, in his letter of March 28th attached sets out the amount due the Company under the contract, less the $1200 deduction. This amount, plus the Company's 10% deposit, totals $7,786 and payment of this amount to the Company is recommended.

It will be necessary for us to have $1200 encumbered in the new fiscal year to complete the building but it is unlikely that weather conditions will permit of the necessary work to the playground being carried out until mid-summer.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

District School Inspector Davey visited this new school shortly after the Company's Final Progress Payment #3 attached hereto, was submitted, and reported quite unfavourably with regard to some of the work. In order to protect the Department it was deemed advisable to have the structure inspected by one of our engineering staff and at the first opportunity Mr. R.M. Martin proceeded to Ucluelet and in due course reported, reference his memorandum of March 15th, attached. A meeting with Mr. DeWolf, General Manager of All-Steel Buildings, and his Construction Supervisor, was subsequently arranged and the defects in the structure were discussed in some detail. We found it difficult, however, to place responsibility for all these defects entirely on the contractor for the reason that no detailed specifications accompanied the contractor's tender and his responsibilities with regard to heating the building during construction, etc., were not clearly defined.

National All-Steel Buildings Ltd., is presently in the process of liquidation and actually they do not now have the facilities for remedying the defects in the structure and to insist on their doing so would inevitably result in considerable delay. Under these circumstances it is considered advisable to have our engineering staff assess the cost of completing the work and to relieve the contractor of further responsibility by reducing the amount due him under the contract by this cost. Mr. Martin and Mr. Robinson of the...
engineering staff feel the work could be completed for $1200.00 and the Company, reference their letter of March 28th attached, is satisfied to have payment due them reduced by this amount in order to quickly conclude the matter. This is desirable from their point of view as they wish to have liquidation of the Company concluded as soon as possible and it is desirable from our point of view because it will enable us to complete payment under the contract from this year's funds.

Mr. DeWolf, in his letter of March 28th attached sets out the amount due the Company under the contract, less the $1200 deduction. This amount, plus the company's 10% deposit, total $7,786 and payment of this amount to the Company is recommended.

It will be necessary for us to have $1200 encumbered in the new fiscal year to complete the building but it is unlikely that weather conditions will permit of the necessary work to the playground being carried out until mid-summer.

(sgd) W.S. Arneil

To the Secretary,

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter No. 357576, dated Feb. 24, in which you say that you will be pleased to hear again from me upon receipt of a reply to my letter to Mr. Cox, Indian Agent, at Telegraph Creek, in regard to the establishing of a school at Tahltan.

I wrote to Mr. Cox Nov. 5th, before I had Rev. Mr. Thorman's heroic offer to return from England with his son, who is of age, to take up the school and mission work at Tahltan if I could provide a salary. My letter of Jan. 18th, would explain that I had these two men who had lived there before and knew the language ready to go back and rally the Indians round them.

To this second letter I have not had time to get a reply but to my first letter which simply asked if he approved of reopening the school at Tahltan, if he thought a grant could be secured for this, and also another for the Liard Indians 250 miles in the interior &c. To this he has replied as follows:

"I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 1st of Nov. last regarding the Indians of this agency and in reply beg to say that I am very anxious that the Indians should have schools established among them wherever it is practical and think that a school at Tahltan should be fairly well attended especially if it was kept open during the summer when the Indians are there, but there is little use in having the children attend only a few weeks when the Indians are in to do their trading and then be taken out in the woods to soon forget what little they..."
had learned which I fear would be the case with the Liard Band". Please note that this last clause refers to the Liard Indians whom our missionary Rev. Frank Palgrave visited last summer at Liard Post 250 miles beyond Telegraph Creek. The old chief there made a most urgent appeal for a school teacher. Mr. Palgrave laid this before me on his return here. I cannot press for this grant because I know of no one willing to go so far into the Interior away from every remnant of civilization, but the case of Tahltan is different.

Will you allow me to present the urgency of this case as briefly as possible.

1. Rev. Frank Palgrave began and Rev. T.P. Thorman carried on work here under the auspices of the Church of England some years ago. Mr. Thorman reduced the language to writing and translated portions of the Bible, hymns, prayers, readers, teaching school faithfully among young and old without a Government grant. Erecting mission buildings there &c. His wife dying he resigned and owing to expense our Church was unable to send in a missionary to take his place.

2. Last summer as a holiday trip Rev. Mr. Palgrave revisited his old field. The Indians welcomed him most warmly. He taught school for about two months in the summer. They implored him to either come back or send them a teacher. Mr. Cox helped him and the Indians to put a new foundation under the Mission house which is used also as a school. Mr. Palgrave on his way back to England laid the responsibility upon me not to disappoint these Indians.

3. I at once took the matter up, wrote to Mr. Vowel, Mr. Cox, and at a venture to Rev. Mr. Thorman in England. Mr. Thorman responded by offering to come ba
with his son if I would pay their travelling expenses from England to Tahltan and give them an adequate salary, pointing out that it is not a "one man mission". I must let them know so that they can be here in June ready to take the first steamer up the Stickine.

To put the case in a nut-shell - The Church is not responsible for the school. The Government is not responsible for the Mission, but owing to the extreme isolation and the excessive cost the only practicable plan is to work the two together. The Government could not get a teacher to live there on a small grant. The Church will have to decline to reopen the mission and school without an adequate Government grant to the school.

For the proposed grant of $750 (or say $700) the Government will secure the services of two men for the school who both understand the language, one with a knowledge of medicine.

— Mr. Cox, the Indian Agent favours the reopening of the school at Tahltan.

— Mr. Vowell, the superintendent of I.A., recommends it.

— Mr. Palgrave, the pioneer missionary of the Stickine, urges it with all his power.

— Dr. Inglis of Telegraph Creek admits that it is impossible for him, twelve miles away, to look after these Indians.

— Many of the Indians say that if there were a school at Tahltan they would keep away more from Telegraph Creek where they meet with more temptation than in their own village.

As for travelling expenses, though it seems only reasonable that the Government should make some allowance, say from Vancouver to Tahltan, yet I do not press this in the same way.

I earnestly trust that the Government will give me an answer soon.
as Mr. Norman will have to give due notice before he will be allowed to leave his parish in England and he must be on hand for the steamer up the Stickine. I am informed that the season will be very short this summer for the steamer. One month most likely.

As soon as I hear that a grant has been made I can complete arrangements.

Yours faithfully,

F. H. Du Vernet

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of June 5th, 1911, and this is my first opportunity for reply.

This is a most isolated spot almost without humanity, reach with few and uncertain friends.

With regard to the School on the said reserve, it is all that one can wish for and reasonably expect.

The attendance is excellent at the present moment there are 30 children upon the register, and the attendance has been for weeks past 20 to 26 daily.

The conduct is all that can be desired, and their knowledge perfectly acquired when we remember when we opened the school fourteen months ago not one child knew A.B.C.

Instead of five and half holidays the parents of the children would soon better be saved during the annual holidays time until the all have for the fall hunt for food. All the Indians are here now in their spring season, but the land agitation among the B.C. Indians had reached here and does much harm partly in our efforts for their good.
The Indian Agent Mr. Cox has resigned. (He expressed himself much pleased several times on his visits here at the office.) Mr. Cox has been appointed to whom do I send my quarterly School Attendance Report etc.?

Will you kindly cause some Quarterly School Patterns to be sent to me? I have none.

I do call attention, although I have written once before and received no reply to the following:

When I left England to come here, the Rt. Hon. of California said the Department had allowed $500 per ann. for the Teacher and $250 per ann. for the Assistant. This building fund has only been paid for the first quarter and not since.

The building is the property of the Church of England and paid for at such cost, and I presume that Assistant's part includes warmth and light.

For seven months in the year (the winter is between seven and eight months here) it costs $1 per day for wood for School, only—waps are common labourers $4.25 per day; this sum is paid by B.C. Govt.

You will kindly note $200 for building warmth and light is not an excessive allowance. The house falls in winter & so does the snow.

Yours sincerely,

Sir,

It was my privilege to visit the Indian Village of Tahltan 172 miles up the Stikine River and to spend a week there about the first of June last. I spent a whole morning inspecting the school taught by Rev. T.P. Sherman. There were about a dozen children present. These children had only been under Mr. Sherman's care for two years and knew nothing in the way of education before this. I cannot speak too highly of the progress they have made in reading, writing, spelling, arithmetic, geography &c., also from being wild untamed children they showed in their respectful manners the wonderful influence Mr. Sherman has had over them. There is no doubt in my mind that both from the standpoint of the school and the church it is when the Indians are in their own village twelve miles from the contaminating influence of Telegraph Creek the most effective work can be done.

I have just received a letter from Mr. Sherman stating that acting upon the new regulation he has been keeping the school open in July with an attendance of between 16 and 20. Later the Indians will be away for the Fall Hunt when the attendance at school will be small.

On June 6th, I visited the Public School at Telegraph Creek and found five children present, one an Indian child.

I had a long talk with the Indian Agent, Mr. Simpson. He expressed himself as much pleased with the Tahltan Indian Day School, which he visits about once a month, and unlike Mr. Symon, strengthens instead of weakens the hands of the missionary and teacher.

I have had to pay Mr. Sherman
I have had to pay Mr. Sherman $1,200 a year. The cost of living up in this isolated region is excessive. Without the Government grant of $300 towards salary and $250 rental for school building I should have to close the Mission. No teacher could live on the Government grant alone.

I have reported my visit to the Department and given my testimony to the good work being done in the school because in a recent letter the Department spoke of closing the school if the attendance did not keep up, and further owing to the migratory habits of the Indians it may be difficult to put in the full number of school days and so under the new rule the salary grant may be reduced. I consider that no school in the Diocese has for the limited period of operation done better work.

It is a difficult problem—the teaching of school when the Indians wander. The former government did not favour increasing the number of Boarding Schools. For the immense outlay the returns are very slight. Children are removed from their parents whose authority is destroyed, and are unfitted for the ordinary life that awaits them when they return after six years absence. I do not know what the present policy of the Department is. I think both Mr. Beasy and Mr. Simpson favour the Boarding School plan, but they have not had the experience I have had in the difficulties in the way.

Yours faithfully,

J. H. Tun Turner
Bishop of Caledonia

To the Secretary of

Department of Indian Affairs, OTTAWA,

Sir,

I am in receipt of a long letter from Rev. T.P. Thorman of Tahltan, Stickine River explaining the causes of a decrease in the average attendance at the Day School during the past year.

It is best for the Indians that they should remain as much as possible on their Reserve so that their children may go to school and young and old may be away from the temptations to drink and immorality which proximity to a white village brings.

The Tahltan Indians receive many inducements to move their families to Telegraph Creek, the white settlement twelve miles away. Indirectly the Government encourages this by providing that the Indian children may attend the Public School for White children in this village. According to Mr. Thorman's letter, when Mr. Tyson, Indian Agencies Inspector, visited Tahltan Reserve last August the Indians put to him the question— "May we live where we like?". Mr. Tyson replied "Yes you may". On hearing this many went off with their families to live at the white village of Telegraph Creek. In three weeks time the attendance at the Indian Day School dropped from 27 to 5. While Mr. Thorman has not seen a case of drunkenness at Tahltan among the Indians it is very different at Telegraph Creek. There the work of the missionary for the
Indian seems to be almost undone. There is also a white-man who keeps agitating the Indians over the land question, and the sad unrest which is such an obstacle to our missionary work in these parts has spread up the Stickine. Many of our missionaries are now utterly disheartened because of this "land agitation" and Mr. Thorman says this is another cause of lack of attendance.

While Mr. Tyson may have been strictly speaking correct in what he said yet as the Indians would regard him as higher than the Indian Agent the effect of his words has been most disastrous. Most of our Indian Agents have said—If you want to live off the Reserve, then you must renounce the privileges of the Reserve" but in this case the Department offers school and medical attendance to induce the Indians to live in a village where through drink and vice they will soon be exterminated.

I understand that the new Indian Agent on the Stickine is alive to this situation, and is rather inclined to recommend a Boarding School at Tahltan, but after my financial experience with Boarding Schools I should hesitate to involve the Church in such.

I think we should give the Day School at Tahltan a fair chance, and an other trial. I sympathize deeply with Mr. Thorman in his most isolated post with the thermometer often down to 60 below, and think that he deserves every encouragement both from the Government and the Church.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

F.H. Du Vernet
Bishop of Caledonia

Dear Sir,

It is a common report that the Indian Land Question is receiving the attention of the Government at this time; and that a Commission has been appointed to inquire into debate upon the requirements of the different tribes in these parts. Until a movement had been made in this direction it was of little use making mention of educational progress among these people on account of their boycotting all concerned with the Government; a sad state of affairs brought about by a travelling agitator. Now that the Indian mind is pacified to a great extent I will ask the Government to give its accustomed consideration to remarks of a like nature.

For many years the Anglican Mission has been established among this tribe of Indians, who, for the most part, are members of the Church.

It was as far back as the year 1897 that the first school was opened; but this only continued for a space of 6 years. The Government
at some time made no great. The Mission was helped by a supply of drugs. I believe there was an Indian Agent. However, through lack of support from outside, and the then indifference of the Indians to education, the School was forced to be closed.

In 1910 the School was again opened and was received very favourably by the parents of school children, who lent their utmost support in keeping their children for a time at School. Nevertheless the problem of continuing this School as an educational enterprise is by no means solved yet. There is the eternal drawback of the precarious existence of a nomadic people which allows no long stay in any one place; the Indian spend thrift manner of living & his loss of liquid gold the children of their right in their parents as soon as they have run through the cash in hand are forced to return to the hunting grounds. These two drawbacks alone mean the ever-lasting repetition of the premises & slackness of any true discipline.

Then there is the question of morals. I have never seen these lower in standard among any people. True not entirely due to themselves but rather to the cosmopolitan influx during the gold rush of '95. & the want of law order.
at the present time. It is no uncommon thing, in fact, the general rule, for little girls of 13 to be open prostitutes; some even younger than the above age are known to be of doubtful chastity. Telegraph Creek, some 12 miles away, harbours mischief. The evil, whiskey may be obtained for the asking; there is profanity, of living between whites & Indians; little boys & girls swear all the filth of camp followers before they can even speak their own tongue decently; mankind is laid waste on all sides; motherhood is shunned at & influences frequent childbirths are encouraged. Morals cannot attain a very high standard in such an environment. I appeal now for a school that will give these children an ordinary chance of being brought up in a "human way." Such a school would be welcomed by quite a few families. The parents at Pahli can take a keen delight in seeing their children neat tidy & in setting them to attend regularly at school. A school that would contain all practical virtues combined with some arts of hand crafts would be one of the greatest blessings the Government could bestow upon this tribe. And yet it is not desirable to educate the youth here beyond themselves so as to bring discontent among them & make the girls too proud to marry their own kind. A Boarding & Industrial...
School is what is really needed. The children from adjacent hills might be brought to this school. Sable Fan is distant from the liquor traffic—no good habits could be kept off. The town is the home of the people who could see their children as frequently as convenient. The cost need not be very great. A wagon road passes just below the village making transportation of material & foods will with a moment's notice.

I am writing to Bishop Ro Vernet asking him what extent the Church could help; but he is failing much support in that quarter. I feel confident the Department will put some little consideration to my remarks.

I have the honor,

To be your faithful & obedient servant,

F. P. Norman

Sir,

I beg to submit herewith Agents report on Telegraph Creek school for the month of November 1912.

At the close of the summer holidays the trustees were unable to secure a master for the Telegraph Creek school as there was no certainty of the grant being continued by the Department of Indian Affairs in Ottawa, and the provincial grant of $90.00 towards the masters salary was considered too low in view of the high cost of living in this country. The school board then communicated with the member for this electoral district, urging him to have the grant from the Department continued, and arrangements were made with the Rev. T.P. Thorman, former school master for the Tahltan school who was then on his way to England, to send his son out to fill the position. Meanwhile as the provincial law called for an attendance of eight pupils before the grant from the local government could be claimed, and there were only two white children of school age, every effort was made to have the Indians with children send their boys to the Telegraph Creek school to make up the required number. Mr. W. Thorman the new master arrived on the 1st of November and immediately opened school with an attendance of 14, Indian children and two whites. Most of these children were formerly on the roll at the Tahltan Mission school but their parents were staying here for the winter, as they can secure steady employment, consequently there are no children at the Tahltan village and there is very little hope of conditions changing later on.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

There is, as you know, a tribe of Indians on the Stikine River above Telegraph Creek. A number of them live in "The Creek" but many of them wish to be again settled at their old village of Tahl-Tan, where it would be much better if they were all living. Your Department evidently has realized this as you made a small grant recently to assist in obtaining a better water supply for the old village. These natives when at Tahl-tan are in touch with both their fishing and hunting and the mothers and children can stay at home while the men are away.

The establishment of a small school there for about five or six months in the summer would be of great value. Mr. Harper Reid, the Indian Agent in that area, also recommends this.

There is a first class man there who could take charge of this school. He is a son of an early missionary there and talks the language of the people, but was educated in England and had taken two years at Oxford before the Great War broke out. He was a tutor for some time in an English family.

I will be glad to hear from you re this matter and trust you will give it favourable consideration. If you place this school under my supervision I shall do all I can to make it as useful as possible. I may say that nearly all the natives who will live at Tahl-tan will be Church of England.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir,

This report of the Summer School at Tahltan is somewhat belated as I've been busy moving, i.e., walking, back and forth from Telegraph Creek to Tahltan which has taken up considerable of my time, in consequence I find myself behind in much of my work.

I opened a day school at Tahltan on June 25th and closed after 36 school days on the 23rd day of August having taught school on 3, 4 and sometimes 5 days a week as I was able to fit in the days with any other work.

Ten pupils attended, the names are as follows: Andrew Dick, James Dick, Mona Etzerza, Charles Etzerza, Mable Henry, Lawrence Henry, Leonard Henry, Fansy Quash, Matilda Quash, Lennox Quash, the first six have at broken intervals attended the school in Telegraph Creek but the last four have not previously attended any school. None of these children had attended any school since prior to Easter. These children were in the vicinity of Tahltan since Mid-March when the men folk left their families to go Spring Beaver hunting.

The school closing was made to facilitate the families fall excursion to the mountains for "grease."

There were other children who would have attended school but arrived too late in the season, also the severe summer colds prevalent this year were a drawback.

I have omitted to add that the above mentioned children came from four families and averaged an attendance of 7.9.

The idea of the Mission summer school was not to run in opposition to the Provincial School at Telegraph Creek but to give those children in the vicinity of Tahltan an opportunity to continue their studies, or start them as the case might be without going into the undesirable atmosphere of Telegraph Creek. In addition the spring and summer months are devoted to tanning hides for mocassins and clothing and for drying fish which occupations are not so readily accomplished in Telegraph Creek.

While not wishing to minimise the work of the school in Telegraph Creek, Emphatically this is not the place to further their welfare—the tone is far from high—which statement you will agree is correct when you consider the class of homes from which so many of the Provincial Pupils come. These pupils, about 20 in number, are with the exception of two white boys all half breeds, quarter breeds, etc. Indeed, from many years of observation, I consider many of the Indian encampments as being a far more suitable place in which to rear children than in Telegraph Creek.

The school at Telegraph Creek is crowded and if the Provincial Pupils receive their measure of tuition, how can an Indian child unless he be unduly bright keep abreast of the Provincial Pupils?

Without wishing to stretch this report to undue length, as you are already aware of all of the above stated facts I would add that the summer school was received well, well attended and with better luck will be more successful next summer when we hope to have...
more equipment. I was late in getting the news around that a school would be held. There was a little background of opposition also as it was thought that it might interfere with the Provincial School. I studiously avoided any friction with the Provincial programme.

There is little likelihood of any of the children, whom I taught this summer, attending Telegraph Creek school or being in the vicinity of Telegraph Creek or Tahltan until next March.

This should have been May. Indian families simply cannot afford to come to town until after the Beated Hunt is finished & the Beated Hunt will be "Feet" Beated all gone. H.R. J.

Yours faithfully,

"W. P. Thorman"

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Referring to my memorandum dated October 29th, last, regarding the request of His Lordship the Bishop of Caledonia for the opening of a summer school for the benefit of the Indian children at Tahltan, in the Stikine agency, northern British Columbia (Federal District of Skeena), I have now to inform you that His Lordship has nominated Mr. W. Thorman for the position as teacher. Mr. Thorman has the necessary qualifications and conducted classes at this point during the past summer. There are 22 Indian children available and it is expected that there will be an average attendance of 15 children during the period the school is open next summer. It is proposed to open the school on or about May first, next, and conduct it for a period of five months.

I shall be pleased to have your approval of the Bishop's nomination of Mr. W. Thorman as teacher.

Deputy Superintendent General.
