Dear Sir:

I am, as you will see by the letterhead, in Montreal a long way from my western Diocese and as mails are very uncertain to and from the Telegraph Creek region so that I can not well communicate with you through your agent there. I am therefore bringing the following matters directly to your attention.

1. It is our desire to continue the school for natives at Tahltan this coming summer as we have in the past and solicit the usual co-operation of your department in this matter. Mr. W. Thorman is our efficient teacher there.

2. I have been informed that it is the purpose of the department to build a school at Dease Lake this spring. There are a number of our Anglican natives there and I believe some Roman Catholics and that the department wishes the school to be run along non-denomination lines. Would your department give me the particulars re this enterprise?

(a) Is the school to be built, and when ready for use?
(b) How long a time in the summer will it be expected to be carried on?
(c) What salary will be paid to a teacher in this very difficult place?
(d) Will the government pay travelling expenses of a teacher going in for the short time the school is to be in operation? I would be glad to get this information as early as possible so that if necessary I could set about the task of getting a suitable man.

3. In the village of Aiyansh, or sometimes called Gitlakdamics, there never has been a building for an Indian day school. A large room in the Mission House being used for this purpose. This is not as suitable as it should be, by any means, which fact is agreed to both by the Inspector of Indian Schools, the Church and the natives themselves. The Indian Agent, Mr. W. E. Collison agrees with this also.

Re: TAHLTAN RESERVE DAY SCHOOL. (summer)
Anglican Mission.

I beg to submit a Report on the above Indian Seasonal Day School, situated in the Tahltan Village and on that Reserve.

Under Authority 158-2-1, February 20th 1940, permission was granted to operate this school over the summer, for a period of 5 months. Mr (Rev) W.P. Thorman was appointed the Teacher, as in years gone by, and the Salary allowed was at the rate of $90-00 per month. Replacement of school materials was granted with also some few extras all of which were obtained and forwarded to this school.

Upon going over the Records of School Reports, it is seen that this school has operated for a period of 6 months, and not as originally arranged. As your Agent was on duty in the south part of B.C., during the month of September, it is not known as to if the Department allowed this extra period, or not. Returning after the visit to the South, the September School Report was received from Teacher Thorman without comment, and with pressure of work in this Office was forwarded to the Department; and the extra month not mentioned.

The School has been doing good work, and the attendance fair, but without doubt were the Rev Thorman to insist that other indian children, belonging to his Mission—that could and should attend this excellent school—were induced to do so—much extra good work would be accomplished. This would also, perhaps, go away with the attendance of indian children to the Provincial Day School in Telegraph Creek; during the winter months. Several children spending the summers at the near-by Fish Camp, and on this Reserve, should be made to attend this school.

Here again is a matter for the inspection of Inspector Coleman during his visit to these parts; next summer. It is considered that this school should be reopened next summer as at April First, and that the usual supplies be allowed, with the Salary the same as in past times. It is expected that Mr Thorman will again be nominated as the Teacher, by his Bishop, but this question will be settled at a later date.

but the schools were not in session, consequently no examination could be made of the children in their work. These are reported on as follows:

TAHLTON (Anglican)

This school 19x23 9'6" wall, was erected in 1936 at a cost of about $300.00 to the Department, some labour or supervision apparently being given by Mr. Thomas. It is well constructed of logs with ample lighting from one side, the floor being covered with roofing material and painted, a common practice in this district. It is equipped of eleven double homemade desks and a drum heater. There is only one latrine for both sexes and another should be constructed, the cost being about $15.00. Regular school desks, fastened on battens would well be provided for this school when funds are available. There is no blackboard, apart from a piece of black oil cloth about 4 yard square. I would recommend the supply of two sections of regular blackboard material and chalk rail.

It is noted that the school has an extension at the rear about 12' square, fitted out with stained glass window altar, etc. and that the school is used for Church services. This appears to be the general practice in this agency and I very much question the practice as there are, in my opinion, serious objections to the use of a school room for religious gatherings of adults owing to the increased risk of infection besides the disorganization of the school set up. The children's desks could hardly be considered satisfactory pews for adults. In addition, the presence of so much religion paraphernalia is somewhat out of colour in a class room. If it must remain, I would recommend that it be screened off by suitable doors when school is in session. These remarks apply to the other schools visited, Dease Lake, McAdam, although the Rev. Father Carpentier has screened off the altar. The Indians should be induced by the Missionaries to erect separate buildings for church purposes.

The average monthly attendance at Tahltan school varied between 13 and 18. The village is quite small. Grades are as follows: Grade 1 -- 4 pupils, average age 7½

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Re: - Mr. W. P. Thorman.

The records here indicate that W. P. Thorman has been employed by this Branch as teacher of a seasonal Indian day school in the Stikine agency. This school, which is known as the Tahltan Seasonal School, is a comparatively small building and had at the date of the last inspection - April, 1942 - an enrolment of 11 pupils.

Mr. Thorman was nominated for this school by the Right Reverend G. A. Rix, Anglican Bishop of the diocese of Caledonia. The Bishop, in a letter dated October 15, 1934, states:

"There is a first class man there who could take charge of this school. He is a son of an early missionary there and talks the language of the people. He was educated in England and took two years at Oxford before the Great War broke out. He was a tutor for some time in an English family."

The acting Indian agent, Mr. R.H.S. Sampson, in his last report on the school, states:

"The general progress at this school is better than at other seasonal schools in the agency, although even here there appears to be room for much improvement. The schoolroom is small and when attendance increases there will be crowding, as the home-made double desks in use are bulky."

There is very little on file here with respect to the work undertaken and accomplished by Mr. Thorman. The few reports we have, however, would indicate that his work at the school has been satisfactory.

Director.

To be accorded married, householder, widow or widower status, or to be allowed any tax credit in respect of dependents, an employee must complete and file Form N.D.T.1 in duplicate with his employer.

The other copy of Form N.D.T.1 is to be retained on file by the employer where it will be available at any time for inspection by officers of the Inspector of Income Tax.

In cases where Form N.D.T.1 is incomplete and filed, the employee is to be regarded for purposes of taxation as a single person without dependents. It will accordingly be apparent that it is unnecessary for single persons claiming widow or widower status or a tax credit in respect of dependents, engaged by more than one employer during the year, to file separate declarations for each employer.

Moreover, if during the year any change occurs in the status of an employee, the employee must complete and file with his employer an amended Form N.D.T.1 in duplicate.

Form N.D.T.1 may be obtained from local banks, post offices or from the office of any District Inspector of Income Tax.

Note.—Section 91, as reproduced below, was declared by Act of Parliament to come into force on the first day of July, 1941, and to be applicable to all payments on and after that date; provided, however, that the rate of National Defence Income Tax shall not exceed five per cent of any taxable income in the year 1941 or be 3½% wherever 5% is mentioned, and 3½% wherever 7½% is mentioned in subsection 1 of Section 91.

To Whom It May Concern:

Tax Rates

(a) In the case of a married person whose spouse is resident in Canada or in another country contiguous to the territory of the British Commonwealth of Nations or in a country contiguous to Canada, of five per cent if the income exceeds $1,200 per year; and in the case of a husband and wife living separately, of five per cent if each has an income of each is in excess of $660 per year;

(b) In the case of a single person, or a married person whose spouse is resident in Canada or in another country contiguous to the territory of the British Commonwealth of Nations or in a country contiguous to Canada, of five per cent if the income exceeds $1,200 per year; or of seven per cent if the income exceeds $1,200 per year;

(d) In the case of an individual who maintains a self-contained domestic establishment wherein he actually supports therein a person wholly dependent upon him and connected with him by blood relationship, marriage or adoption, of five per cent if the income exceeds $1,200 per year;

(f) In the case of income taxable as provided by subsections two and four of section eleven of this Act, of seven per cent;

Provided that there shall be allowed a tax credit of four dollars for the year 1940, fourteen dollars for the year 1941 and twenty dollars for the year 1942 and each year thereafter for each of the following purposes:

(i) The maintenance of a child in Canada or in another country contiguous to Canada and wholly dependent upon the taxpayer;

(ii) A child, grandchild, brother or sister of the taxpayer under twenty-one years of age, or if twenty-one years of age or over, wholly dependent on account of mental or physical infirmity;

(iii) A person dependent upon the taxpayer wholly dependent on account of mental or physical infirmity;

(iv) A child maintained by the taxpayer in Canada under a co-operative scheme approved by the Minister of Health of the United Kingdom or of Canada or any of the provinces of Canada for children brought from the United Kingdom under a scheme approved by the Minister of Health of Canada except one such dependent child whereupon the taxpayer is entitled to have the tax calculated as provided in paragraphs (c) or (d) of this subsection.

Tax Not to Reduce Basic Income

(2) If the tax is not payable under the provisions of this section, the amount of the tax shall be reduced by the following amounts, which shall be imposed and collected with this tax:

If the tax is $25.00 but not more than $100.00, by $1.00.

If the tax is more than $100.00, by three per cent of the tax payable.

Persons Not Liable

(4) Income of the following persons shall not be liable to tax under this section—

(a) Incorporated companies;

(b) Persons and institutions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (i), both inclusive, of paragraphs (b) and (c) of section four of this Act;

(c) Municipalities or municipal or public bodies which in the opinion of the Minister perform a function of Government;

(d) The service pay and allowances of—

(i) Non-commissioned officers and men of the Canadian Naval, Military and Air Forces while in the Canadian active service;

(ii) Commissioned officers of the said forces while on active service beyond Canada, or on active service in Canada whose duties are of a character as are rendered normally to members of the armed forces in aircraft.

Deduction by Employer

(5) Every employer at the time of payment of earnings to an employee shall deduct from such earnings the tax due on the earnings of employees under this section in respect of the earnings of the employee paid on or after the first day of July, one thousand nine hundred and forty-one, if the amount paid, including personal or living expenses, would cause the employee, if an unmarried employee as valued by the employer, daily, weekly, monthly or for such other period, is such that if continued for twelve months would cause the annual earnings of the employee to be in excess of the relevant amount mentioned in subsection one of this section.

Remittance by Employer

(6) Every employer shall, on or before the fifteenth day of the month next following that in which the earnings were due, pay to the Receiver General of Canada the full amount of the tax due; and the first remittance to be made on the sixteenth day of September, 1940.

Deduction from Interest and Dividends

(7) Any person paying interest on bonds, debentures or other like obligations or dividends in respect of shares of stock, irrespective of the amount, to persons registered as the holders of bonds, debentures or the obligations referred to herein, shall deduct from the amount of five per cent each and every such payment made to residents of Canada on or after the first day of July, one thousand nine hundred and forty-one.

Remittance by Corporation

(8) Each incorporated company referred to in subsection seven hereof shall make a remittance to the Receiver General of Canada, on or before the fifteenth day of the month immediately following the date of payment of the interest or dividends, the first remittance to be made on the sixteenth day of September, 1940.

Returns

(9) Every person required to make deductions under this section shall make a return at such time and in such form as the Minister may prescribe showing all deductions made.

Persons Deemed Trustees

(10) Every person deducting any amount under this Act shall be deemed to hold the same in trust for the Receiver General of Canada.

Legal Immunity

(11) No one shall have any right of action against an employer or incorporated company in respect of any moneys deducted as a tax and paid over to the Receiver General of Canada in compliance with or intended compliance with this section.

Forms and Returns Required

(12) Every employee who comes within one of the classes described in paragraphs (a), (c) and (d) of subsection one of this section shall be required to complete such form as the Minister may prescribe as to personal status and dependants and shall file the form with his employer:

Provided that a like form shall be so filed in each case where the facts as given in the form theretofore are changed by altered status or by a change in the number of dependants.

Tax Not Fully Paid by Deduction

(13) Every person liable to taxation under this section whose tax hereunder is not paid fully by deduction at the source, shall, on or before the thirty-first day of March in each year, without any notice or demand, deliver to the Minister a return, in such form as the Minister may prescribe, of the total amount of the tax due; and the person shall pay any tax due at such times and in such manner as in this Act provided.

Offences and Penalties

(14) Every person failing to deduct or remit or to deduct and remit the tax due pursuant to the provisions of this section at the time prescribed therefor shall be liable in default to the amount of tax which should have been deducted and remitted, but the penalty shall not exceed five hundred dollars.

Failure to File Form

(15) Every employee failing to file the prescribed form with his employer pursuant to the provisions of subsection twelve hereof shall be liable to the tax due at the rate applicable to the class of the employee and which would have been the rate to which he would otherwise have been entitled in respect of persons dependent upon him for support.

"Employee"

(16) "Employee" shall for the purposes of this section include any person who receives as income any salary, wages, remuneration, compensation, hire, emolument, stipend, perquisite, or any similar payment or any indemnity, pension or director's fee, howsoever paid for any services, functions or duties rendered or performed in Canada.

"Employer"

(17) "Employer" shall for the purposes of this section include any person who makes any payment of the descriptions referred to in subsection sixteen of this section.

Records to be Kept

(18) Every person required to deduct the tax hereby imposed from any payment made by him, shall keep an accurate record of all persons to whom any such payments are made, showing their names, residential addresses, the dates and the amounts of such payments and such other information as the Minister may require.

Refunds

(19) The Minister may make refunds to the taxpayer of any amount collected under this section which was not eligible or which the Minister is reasonably satisfied was not eligible under this section, provided the taxpayer applies in writing for such refund within twelve months from the close of the calendar year in which the amount was collected.

Deductions

(20) Income (except salary or other fixed payments referred to in subsection sixteen hereof) shall for the purposes of this section be subject to the deductions provided by paragraphs (a), (b), (f), (k), (l) and (o) of subsection one of section five and to the provisions of section six of this Act.

Exemptions

(21) Save as provided in subsection twenty of this section, income shall be taxed under this section without exemptions, deductions, allowances or credits except without prejudice to the provisions by civil servants referred to in section thirty-three of the Civil Service Subsidization Act, chapter twenty-four of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1927.

Time for Making Deductions, Etc., May Be Varied

(22) The time for making deductions and remittances as provided for in this section may be varied by regulations made hereunder."

GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS AS TO THE USE OF FORM N.D.T. 1

To be accorded married, householder, widow or widower status, or to be allowed any tax credit in respect of dependents, an employee must complete and file Form N.D.T.1 in duplicate with his employer.

Subsequent to receiving such forms from an employee, the employer is to forward one copy thereof to the Inspector of Income Tax for his district at the time of making his final return for the National Defence Tax. The other copy of Form N.D.T.1 is to be retained on file by the employer where it will be available for inspection by officers of this Division.

In cases where Form N.D.T.1 is not completed and filed, the employee is to be regarded for tax purposes as a single person without dependents. It will accordingly be necessary for such employees to file for tax purposes without dependents to complete and file Form N.D.T.1.

When an employee claiming married, householder, widow or widower status is engaged by more than one employer during the year it will be necessary for such employee to complete and file Form N.D.T.1 in duplicate with each employer.

Moreover, during the year any change occurs in the status of an employee, the employee must complete and file with his employer an amended Form N.D.T.1 in duplicate.

Form N.D.T.1 may be obtained from local banks, post offices or from the office of any District Inspector of Income Tax.

NOTE—Section 91, as reproduced below has been declared by Act of Parliament to have come into force on the first day of July, 1940, and shall be applicable to assessments on and after that date; provided, however, that the rate of National Defence Tax applicable to the total income of any taxpayer for the calendar year 1941 is to be 5½% wherever 5% is mentioned, and 5¾% wherever 7½% is mentioned.

To Whom Applicable

91. (1) In addition to any other tax imposed by this Act, there shall be levied and collected upon the income of each person described in paragraphs (a) to (e), both inclusive, of subsection one of section nine of this Act a tax to be known as the National Defence Tax at the rate:

Tax Rates

(a) In the case of a married person whose spouse is resident in Canada or any other part of the territory of the British Commonwealth of Nations or in a country contiguous to Canada, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year; and in the case of a husband and wife having each a separate income, of five per centum if the income of each exceeds $1,200 per year;

(b) In the case of a single person, or a married person whose spouse is not resident in Canada, or any other part of the territory of the British Commonwealth of Nations or in a country contiguous to Canada, of five per centum if the income exceeds $660 per year and does not exceed $1,200 per year; or of seven per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year;

(c) In the case of a widow or widower with a son or daughter resident in Canada or any other part of the territory of the British Commonwealth of Nations or in a country contiguous to Canada under twenty-one years of age who is wholly dependent upon such parent for support, or with a son or daughter under one year of age or over sixteen years of age who is wholly dependent upon account of mental or physical infirmity, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year;

(d) In the case of an individual who maintains a self-contained domestic establishment and who actually supports it, a person wholly dependent upon him and who will inherit him by blood through marriage or adoption, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year;

(e) In the case of a minister or clergyman in charge of a diocese, congregation or parish, whose duties require him to maintain, at his own and sole expense, a self-contained domestic establishment, and who is wholly dependent upon account of time or sickness, or servant, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year;

(f) In the case of income taxable as provided by subsections two and four of section eleven of this Act, of seven per centum.

Provision

Provided that there shall be allowed a tax deduction of five dollars for the year 1940, less the deduction for the year 1939 and twenty dollars for the year 1942 and each year thereafter for each of the following persons resident in Canada or in a country contiguous to Canada and wholly dependent upon the taxpayer:

(i) A child, grandchild, brother or sister of the taxpayer under twenty-one years of age who is wholly dependent upon account of mental or physical infirmity;

(ii) A parent or grandparent of a taxpayer wholly dependent on account of mental or physical infirmity;

(iii) A child maintained by the taxpayer in Canada under a cooperative scheme sponsored by the Governments of the United Kingdom and of Canada, or by the Government of India, or children brought from the United Kingdom under a Government plan, except one such dependent on whose account the taxpayer is entitled to have the tax calculated at the rate prescribed in (c), (d) or (e) of this subsection.

Tax Not to Reduce Basic Income

(2) If the tax exigible under the provisions of this section shall cause the income of a single person or a husband or wife to be reduced below the amount of basic income, or those amounts referred to in paragraphs (a), (c), (d) and (e) of subsection one of this section (except a husband or wife each of whom has an income in excess of $660) below $1,200, then to the extent that it would so reduce the income of the taxpayer such tax shall not be payable.

Extra Tax

(3) Taxes imposed by this section, which have not been deducted at the source, shall be increased by the following amounts, which shall be imposed and collected with the tax:

If the tax is $25.00 but not more than $100.00, by $1.00.

If the tax is more than $100.00, by three per centum of the tax payable.

Persons Not Liable

(4) Income of the following persons shall not be liable to tax under this section:

(a) Incorporated companies;

(b) Persons and institutions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (i), both inclusive, and in paragraphs (p) and (q) of section five of this Act;

(c) Ministers, officers or public bodies which in the opinion of the Minister form a part of Government;

(d) The service pay and allowances of—

(i) Officers, non-commissioned officers and men of the Canadian Naval, Military and Air Forces while in the Canadian active service forces, and

(ii) Non-commissioned officers of the said forces while on active service beyond Canada, or on active service in Canada whose duties are of such a character as are required normally to be performed afloat or in aircraft.

Deduction by Employer

(5) Every employer at the time of payment of earnings to an employee shall deduct and collect the tax imposed on the employee under this section by adding thereto the amount of the tax paid, and shall pay, on or before the first day of July, one thousand nine hundred and forty-one, if the amount paid (including personal and living expenses or the value of subsistence, if any, furnished to the employee) is less than the amount of the tax imposed, or if the period, other than the period, is such that if continued for twelve months would cause the annual earnings of the employee to be in excess of the relevant amount mentioned in subsection one of this section.

Remittance by Employer

(6) Every employer shall, on or before the fifteenth day of the month next following in which the earnings were due, pay to the Receiver General of Canada the tax deducted and collected, the first remittance to be made on the sixteenth day of September, 1940.

Deduction From Interest and Dividends

(7) Any person paying interest on bonds, debentures or other like obligations or dividends in respect of shares or stock, irrespective of the amount, to any person resident in Canada, or adding to the purchase price of any such obligation or shares shall deduct and collect an amount of five per centum from each and every such payment made to residents of Canada on or after the first day of July, one thousand nine hundred and forty-one.

Remittance by Corporation

(8) Each incorporated company referred to in subsection seven hereof shall remit the amounts collected to the Receiver General of Canada, on or before the fifteenth day of the month immediately following the date of receipt thereof, and thereafter, the first remittance to be made on the sixteenth day of September, 1940.

Returns

(9) Every person required to make deductions under this section shall make a return at such time and in such form as the Minister may prescribe showing all deductions made.

Persons Deemed Trustees

(10) Every person deducting any amount under this Act shall be deemed to hold the same in trust for the Receiver General of Canada.

Legal Immunity

(11) No one shall have any right of action against an employer or incorporated company in respect of any moneys deducted as a tax and paid over to the Receiver General of Canada in compliance with or intended compliance with this section.

Forms and Returns Required

(12) Every employer who consents to be subject to the classes described in paragraphs (a), (c), (d) and (e) of subsection one of this section shall be required to complete such class as the Minister may prescribe as to personal status and dependents and shall file the form with his employer.

(13) Every employer who consents to be subject to the case where the facts as given in the form last filed are changed by altered status or by a change in the number of dependents.

Tax Not Fully Paid by Deduction

(13) Every person failing to deduct or fail to deduct and remit the tax due pursuant to the provisions of this section at the time prescribed therefor shall be liable to a penalty equal to the amount of tax which should have been deducted and remitted, but the penalty shall not exceed five hundred dollars.

Failure to File Form

(15) Every employer failing to file the prescribed form with his employer pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be deemed to have failed to file the form with his employer and shall be liable to the Minister may prescribe of his full income during the last preceding year and shall pay any tax due at such times and in such manner as in this Act provided.

Offences and Penalties

(14) Every person failing to deduct or fail to deduct and remit the tax due pursuant to the provisions of this section at the time prescribed therefor shall be liable to a penalty equal to the amount of tax which should have been deducted and remitted, but the penalty shall not exceed five hundred dollars.

Records to be Kept

(18) Every person required to deduct the tax hereby imposed from any payment made by him, shall keep an accurate record of all persons to whom such payments are made, showing their names, residential addresses, the dates and the amounts of such payments and such other information as the Minister may require.

Refunds

(19) The Minister may make a refund to the taxpayer of any amount collected under this section which was not exigible or which the Minister is reasonably satisfied was not exigible under this section, provided that the taxpayer applies in writing to the Minister within six months from the close of the calendar year in which the amount was collected.

Deductions

(20) Income (except salary or other fixed payments referred to in subsection sixteen hereof) for the year ending March thirty-first shall be subject to the deductions provided by paragraphs (a), (b), (f), (h), (l) and (m) of subsection one of section five and to the provisions of section six of this Act.

Exemptions

(21) Save as provided in subsection twenty-two of this section, income shall be taxed under this section without exemptions, deductions, allowances or credits, and without deductions of contributions by civil servants referred to in section thirteen of the Civil Service Superannuation Act, chapter twenty-four of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1927.

Time for Making Deductions, Etc., May Be Varied

(22) The time for making deductions and remittances as provided for in this section may be varied by regulations made hereunder.

Dear Bishop Rix:

I have your letter of February 25th forwarding Mr. Thorman's letter to you of February 1st resigning as teacher of the Tahltan Indian summer school. Mr. Thorman appears very definite in his desire to resign and I have, therefore, recommended to the Department that his resignation be accepted.

Inspector Coleman reported that the lands of the Reserve in use by Mr. Thorman were needed by the Indians for the production of garden produce and the action of the Department in requesting Mr. Thorman to discontinue his use of these lands for this reason has, no doubt, been largely responsible for his resignation. I may say that the Department has for some time emphasized the importance of Indians being encouraged to the fullest possible extent in developing gardens and Mr. Coleman had this in mind in making the recommendation referred to.

It is my intention to visit Prince Rupert in connection with Departmental matters within the next few weeks and should be glad to arrange to call to see you regarding the schools in your diocese and other matters. Mr. Thorman's letter is being returned herewith.

My dear Bishop Rix:

I thank you for your letter of January 10th, in which you mentioned the matter of a School Teacher for Tahl-Tan Summer School for 1944.

With your consent and approval I should wish to be relieved of what has, since April 1943, become a distasteful duty. I have no assurance that the Indian Department will not visit upon me additional indignities. I have suffered an injustice amounting to a persecution at their hands. The Inspector of Indian Agencies Coleman has already written into a document charges of hypocrisy in that I had ulterior motives as a teacher, for gardening was a part of that teaching. I can allow him no further opportunity to exploit his imagination at the expense of what has always been a sincere undertaking. You are aware that the work at Tahl-Tan was first of all devotional and was recognised as such by the previous Agent H. Reed.

Isolated for between five and six months each year, from companionship, regular mail, conveniences of a home, and providing for a separate establishment under a salary never commensurate with the duties. These were never unbearable with a certain appreciation from the Indian Department and fortified by the spirit in which such duties are accepted. When I lack the confidence of the Indian Department I lack the essential that could make me a successful teacher in their employ.

For them to arbitrarily withdraw a privilege which privilege I produced from nothing, is a form of persecution I am unable to accept.

I dutifully request that you favourably consider my most earnest desire to decline any further duties under the Indian Department.

I am,
Your Lordship,
Yours faithfully,

W.P. Thorman.

Your 1941 inspection report on this agency requested that the ownership of the mission schools be cleared up and the following data is submitted in that respect:

**Caribou Hide Seasonal School:** As reported in June 15, 1942, report on this school the building was constructed by Mr. Jim Anglin, a school teacher, assisted by the Indians who cut and skidded logs as well as assisting in the erection of the building. The Department supplied some roofing to the value of about $100.00 including transportation from Telegraph Creek. The Roman Mission considers the Indians' help as donated and therefore claim complete ownership of the building; the Department's assistance being counted as a grant and not necessarily giving them part ownership. The value of the building is estimated at about $800.00.

**Dease Lake Seasonal School:** The Department supplied about $225.00 worth of material and the Roman Catholic Mission paid the Indians for their labour getting logs and erecting the building. A good deal of the work was done by the missionary himself. This building is fairly well finished and is now valued at $1500.00.

**Klappan Seasonal School:** The Department supplied $300.00 for material and equipment and the school was mostly built by the Indians under the supervision of a R.C. priest. The Indians donated their labour and the Mission considers the building is theirs, the Department's assistance being a grant. The value of the building is estimated at $1200.00.

**Lower Post Seasonal School:** A room in the Roman Catholic Mission building at Lower Post is used for school purposes and the Department has no interest in this school.

**McDame Creek Seasonal School:** Apart from about $30.00 worth of lumber for rough desks the Department did not assist in the construction of this school. It was built by the Roman Catholic Mission and the ground floor has been used as a school and church for ten years.

**Tahltan Seasonal School:** The building was constructed by the local Anglican Mission with Indian labour, mostly paid. The Department supplied about $150.00 for material but the Mission considers the building belongs to them. It is valued at about $1000.00.

**Teslin Lake Seasonal Schools:** The two schools here, one Roman Catholic and the other Anglican, are owned by the respective Missions.

None of the buildings for which the Department granted material or equipment would approach the requirements of a modern day school and as the expenditures made by the Department in each case are relatively small compared to the total value of the buildings I would recommend that their interest in each school be turned over to the respective missions to give the missions full ownership. Considering that the buildings have been used several years as

p.t.o.
schools without any rental being charged by the Missions, the Department would probably still not object to paying rent as authorized for the Dease Lake and Klappan schools.

The alternative to this suggestion would be to endeavour to purchase the Missions' share in the schools but I would definitely not recommend this course as I believe that it would be far less expensive, even over a period of years, to pay an annual rental of $75.00 in the case of the Dease Lake and Klappan schools and possibly Lower Post or Morice Creek if either operates, than to purchase these crude log buildings and try to improve them. From past experience it seems that the operation of these bush schools is quite problematic depending as it does upon whether or not the Indians camp at the location of the school during the usual term. At the present time it seems that any extensive outlay for establishing day school buildings would be unwise, especially in the more remote locations because it is evident that the Indians in this area as a whole are still not inclined to settle permanently in one location. Their houses in and near Telegraph Creek for the most part are used only as stopping over places between their trapping and fishing camps. This has been more evident during the past fall and winter when these people have had to earn their living from the country, as they did prior to the mining boom from 1941 to 1943 when supplies were going in by this route to Watson Lake Airport. It seems that the life-long habits of the Indians will not easily be changed, even to ensure the education of their children and the more or less temporary bush schools will probably have to serve, at least for the present.

R.H.S. Sampson,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

As instructed in your letter dated March 4th submitted, herewith, is a School Report of the Summer School that has been started on the Thaltan Reserve, under the care of Mr W.P. Thorman.

Considering that many of the families are still in the "woods" due to a late season on their beaver trapping the attendance is really very good.

The Teacher - Mr Thorman has submitted a sample of work done by a boy named James Dick, which is excellent, but it must be mentioned that his father is the best snow-shoe-maker in the whole Cassiar, which may account for such good showings.

The fishing season has not yet opened up, but when it does this school will reach its maximum benefit for the Indians of that district.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Harper Reed,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, January 27, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the third instant, enclosing a requisition for school supplies for the Anglican Summer Indian Day School on the Tahltan Reserve for the coming summer of 1936. In this connection it is noted that Mr. Thorman, who conducted the school last summer, will again act as its teacher during the coming summer.

The Department will approve of this school being carried on and will allow salary at the same rate as was paid during the summer of 1935, viz.: $90.00 per teaching month. It is understood that the school will be opened on or about May first, next, and will continue for a period of approximately 5 months. It is noted that this school, during the period it was in operation last summer, did a lot of good work.

The supply of school material considered necessary will be forwarded, addressed to you, Telegraph Creek, B. C., in time to reach Vancouver before April 15th, next. This school is to be conducted under the auspices of the Bishop of Caledonia, and I would request that, when the school opens, you will give the teacher every assistance you can in his work.

Yours truly,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

Harper Reed, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Telegraph Creek,
B. C.
Sir,

I beg to submit, herewith Schoolmaster W.P. Thorman's Day School Return, for the Tahltan Anglican Mission School, situated out on that Reserve.

Mr Thorman has continued the school into the month of October, so that his duties for a full month may be completed.

The School is now closed for the winter, most of the Indians having gone to their Trap Grounds, those that have not, and are able to live in the Townsite of Telegraph Creek, will send their children to the local Provincial Assisted Day School. They will be few.

The local Community, with also your Agent consider that the Tahltan Mission School has accomplished much good this summer, and it is known that better results can be expected for next summer's operations. Much credit is due to Mr Thorman.

I am.

The Secretary,
The Dept. Indian Affairs.
OTTAWA.

Sir,

Your obedient servant.

Harper Reed,
Indian Agent.

Requisition for School Supplies-1936

ANGLICAN TAHLTAN RESERVE - Summer School.

During the summer of 1935, under the above reference, a Summer Mission School was conducted on the Tahltan Reserve, to serve the Fish Camp children living out there - then, W. F. Thorman, Esq., J.P., was treated Teacher, and as the Reports show, the school did a lot of good.

It is understood that the school will be allowed to operate this summer (1936) and Mr Thorman will again act as its Teacher, with the same Salary as that of 1935. Bishop Rix, of Prince Rupert agrees with this, and wishes the school operated.

Therefore, hereunder is a list of school material now found necessary to start up the school, as soon as ever the Indians come in from their Spring Beaver hunt, i.e. early in May.

4 - Doz Pencils, H.B. rubber.
2 - Erasers.
1 - Rulers -12.in.
3 - Scribblers rul'd. pencil
2 - Plain
2 - Exercise Books- ink
1 - School Flag - 7 ft. Union Jack.

2 - Doz Metal Squares
2 - Compasses (cheap)
3 - Only Elementary Geography
3 - Doz Metal Gum Brushes
1 - Gall Fly Tox- or Flit.
1 - Hand Spayzer.

Un-usual in the request for Fly Tox, but in this upper country, The Department will understand, it is hardly possible to keep the flies out of a school building. A larger attendance is expected this year, than it was possible to obtain last year.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant.

Harper Reed,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
The Dept Indian Affairs.
OTTAWA.

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith a requisition for school supplies for the Tahltan Seasonal Indian Day School.

With regard to the request for blackboard, in the past the teacher has been using a piece of rubberized cloth about a yard square which is entirely inadequate. Inspector J. Coleman recommended in his inspection report on this Agency last fall that this school be supplied with proper blackboard.

The Fly Tox is badly needed at the school as flies and mosquitoes are troublesome during the months of June and July.

The teacher was requested to keep his requirements as low as possible when submitting the requisition.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise I am in receipt of an application from Mr. Acting Indian Agent Sampson in the Stikine Agency for authority to expend an amount not exceeding $25.00 for the construction of an additional toilet at the Tahltan Seasonal Indian Day School on Tahltan Indian Reserve No. 1. At present, there is only one of these toilets in existence for the use of pupils of both sexes, and I would recommend approval of the application.

It is hardly likely that authority for this could be secured and reach Telegraph Creek in time to secure the account before the close of the fiscal year. Consequently, it will be necessary to make it a charge against the fiscal year commencing April 1st next.

Yours faithfully,

Sir,

I beg to submit herewith the Tahltan Reserve Day School Report ending month of April 1939; of which Mr W. P. Thorman is the Teacher.

This school came in for an inspection by Dr Meyer with your Agent recently, and the school was found to be in excellent shape and the children well advanced in their work. Mr Thorman was even giving attention to very young children who reside on that Reserve, thereby keeping the Reserve in good order etc.

However it was found that the Indian Family of Freddy Loodecker had moved up to that location, and two of his children were attending the school, a fact that had come about without this Office having received notice. As these children are undoubtedly belonging to the R.C. Missions, the matter is hereunder outlined.

Freddy Loodecker age 38, who belongs to the Loodecker Telegraph Creek Family, and who are considered to be Anglicans - went out to Dease Lake to live some 8 years ago, and took to wife, one Fanny CHIEF, but up to date they have never married. However during that time the R.C. Mission's Record shows the following children born and christened by them:

Lorna - Born Oct-7-30 Baptised Father Allard June-10-31
Alma - Jan-15-32 - - - June-28-32
Walter - Nov-14-34 - - - June-11-35
Chera - May-2-37 - - - Poulet June-6-37.

The wife Fanny is a real nomadic, and so in a way is Freddy and so they wander from place to place, and are always leaving a "dirty" camp behind them. Last Fall they moved in from Dease Lake and during the Fall Lorna attended the local Provincial School, which seemed quite all right, and continued to do so up till until the end of last March. Then the family moved outto the Tahltan Reserve, no doubt because of illness in this Townsite and the overcrowded condition of the local school. Other reasons there may be but if so, same are not known.

Mr Thorman was seen, and stated that Inspector Pragnell when last here said that in some cases, such events could not be helped. This is thought correct in cases that come about in the Interior, but so near civilization as this is; at any rate the Indian Office should have been consulted. Mr Thorman did not even know that the pair were not married, but promised to look into the matter and find out what the intentions of Freddy Loodecker really were.

The R. C. Missions have not a school in this district directly around here; and therefore the children were left where they were; but they are aware of the incident.

May advice be allowed as to if these children should remain at this school, or attend some other.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant

Harper Reed
Indian Agent.

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
June 9, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment a report submitted by you immediately following your visit to the Tahltan Reserve day school.

I must state that I find it exceedingly difficult to grasp the exact meaning of the problems discussed by you in this report. The recommendation you make in the last paragraph is particularly difficult to understand. You state - "May advice be allowed as to if these children should remain at this school or attend some other". You will readily see how difficult it is for the Department to discover what your recommendation actually is.

I am anxious to know if you sought to emphasize the fact that Freddy Loedecker was living with Fanny Chief and that the pair were unmarried or if it was your intention to emphasize the fact that a number of children who are nominally Catholics were in attendance at a school conducted under non-Catholic auspices.

It is the policy of the Department, in so far as it is humanly possible, to provide distinct and separate schools for Catholic and non-Catholic children. It is not always possible, however, to provide these facilities, particularly in the outlying districts of the Dominion. If there is no Roman Catholic day school in the district it is better to have these children attend a school conducted under the auspices of the Anglican Church than no school at all, particularly in view of the fact that the father himself appears to be an Anglican.

Harper Reed, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Telegraph Creek, B. C.
An attempt should be made by you, in the interest of the children, to persuade this pair to get married. If they seek relief or assistance from you at any time you would be justified in refusing assistance until they promised you that they would get married. It is somewhat regrettable that certain Indians behave in this way and the Department is dependent almost wholly upon the recommendation of the Agent as to what steps should be taken in an attempt to remedy such conditions.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I beg to submit herewith a requisition for manual training tools and supplies for the Tahltan Seasonal Indian School.

The teacher, Mr. W.P. Thorman, has agreed to teach the boys manual training in an old Mission building which he uses for a work shop.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th ultimo, regarding the establishment of a summer school for the benefit of the Indian children at Fort Grahame and enclosing the applications which you received for the position as teacher.

In reply I have to say the Department will approve of this school being conducted for a three month period during the coming summer, from, approximately, June 15th to September 15th, next.

Approval is also granted for the appointment of Mr. Gerard Beauregard, B.A., of St. Joseph's Seminary, Edmonton, as teacher. He was nominated by the Roman Catholic Church authorities. The salary allowed him during the period the school is in operation will be at the rate of $90 per teaching month.

With reference to the request that the Department make an advance of $25 towards the cost of supplies while the teacher makes the journey in to the school and a like amount on his return, I have to say that the amount provided for salary is all we can allow. Present regulations do not permit making advances or payment of any part of the cost of transportation of teachers to and from a school.

Please advise the church authorities and Mr. Beauregard of his appointment and arrange that he arrive at Fort Grahame in time to commence duties on the date above mentioned. The teacher should prepare and forward a return, showing attendance, days taught, etc., at the end of each month, when cheque in payment of salary due will be sent. MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

Funds are provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year to complete a building for summer day school purposes at Fort Grahame, (Finley Forks Reserve, No. 1 - Federal District of Cariboo) Stuart Lake Agency, B. C.

It is proposed to conduct a school during the coming summer months - June 15th to September 15th. There are 47 children of school age at this point. A few have attended the Lejac Indian Residential School, but the majority have never attended school.

These Indians are all Catholic. The Roman Catholic Church authorities have nominated the services of Gerard Beauregard, B.A., of St. Joseph's Seminary, Edmonton, for the position as teacher. Mr. Beauregard possesses a B. A. certificate and two years' teaching experience.

I would request your approval for the establishment of this school and the appointment of Mr. Beauregard. The salary allowed will be at the rate of $90.00 per teaching month.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.
Sir:—

I would respectfully refer you to official letter dated February 20th last, File No.163-12-5, relative to the proposed summer school at Fort McLeod. Also your letter on the same subject in connection with Fort Grahame, File No. 163-13-5.

In the above connection I wish to attach hereto copies of three applications I have received for the position of teacher at these points. You will note that those two received from St. Joseph's Seminary were nominated by the Church authorities, and the other application is from Mrs. Usterstrom, wife of the Manager of the Hudson's Bay Company's post at Fort McLeod. I might say that the reason this application was received was on account of me discussing the question with her last Summer while at Fort McLeod, as I found out while there that she had been a School teacher before she was married. At that time I asked her if she would consider putting in an application for the position should one be available this year, and she said that she would consider the matter and let me know definitely this year, hence the application. That of course was prior to the time that it was thought that it might be advisable to allow the Church authorities to nominate the teachers.

You will please note that the salary expected by these applicants is not mentioned and I would therefore suggest that you allow them the same salary as the Department usually pays to a first year teacher under the same conditions. If it is decided to appoint the two male teachers, I feel that the Church authorities will make arrangements for their transportation up there, but would like to recommend that a grant of $25-00 be made to each one to cover the cost of supplies while making the journey in, and a like amount for the same purpose on their returning to the line of Railway at Prince George. I mean by that, that the supplies would not be bought for them until they are ready to leave Prince George en route North.

Both these schools should be ready to open by June 15th, and the teachers will be on the ground four or five days before that. That would allow them to run until August 15th, to make up the three months. I trust this will be satisfactory to the Department.

It seems hard for me to get a list of just what articles of school equipment is required for each of these schools, and I feel as if it would be better to leave the matter in the hands of the Department entirely, with the request that you please send me here a shipment of supplies necessary for the Fort Grahame School with approximately 50 pupils, and for the School at Fort McLeod with approximately 30 or 35 pupils. These two shipments should be entirely separate and clearly marked. In making them up please understand that practically all the pupils in each place will be beginners and consequently will not require any advanced books etc. I would suggest that slates and pencils be sent if possible, as well as scribblers etc. Pens and ink will not be required for this year at least. Sir:—

During my last visit to Fort Grahame and Fort McLeod during June 1932 I had several requests at meetings held at Fort Grahame and Fort McLeod that the Department establish a day school at Fort Grahame during the summer months instead of taking the children to the Residential School at Lejac as has been and still is the method used. At those meetings I did not make any definite promises although I saw the reasonableness of most of the recommendations brought up by the Indians, however I postponed the matter for the time being by telling them that owing to hard times generally it would not be possible for the Department to assume any further obligations in the matter of educational facilities. As I will be going into that Reserve again in a month I deem it advisable at this time to submit the whole proposition to the Department with a request that I receive a reply to this letter before I leave so that I can convey the contents of it to the Indians when I go North.

At present we are not getting any of the Fort Grahame children at the School at Lejac on account of the cost of transportation from there to the School, furthermore they are of a different tribe and different traits entirely than the other Indians in the Agency and those who have been in the School have either died or have returned to the Reserve in a sick condition. The same applies to Fort McLeod only of course in a lesser degree as the distance is not quite so great and the children do not pine for their homes to the same extent as their more Northerly friends do, however even at that we do not begin to get a fraction of the number of available children at Fort McLeod and if we ever propose to give them an education I think that something should be done if at all possible.

At the present time the manager of the Hudson's Bay at Fort McLeod is married to a woman who used to be a school teacher and I understand that she is prepared to take charge of the school for the Indians at Fort McLeod for three months in the summer when they are at the camp along with their parents, the rest of the year they are out on their hunting grounds and trap lines and do not spend any time on the Reserve. Would it be possible for the Department to consider establishing a day school at Fort McLeod for three months in the summer when these children could attend providing I can get this ex teacher to consider taking on the job and that we could get a suitable building on the reserve without any expense to the Department which could be used as a school? As I have not got any day schools in this Agency I am of course entirely at a loss to know just how they are operated but if some arrangements could be arrived at which would not entail the expenditure of too much money, I think that it would be a good thing.

In closing allow me to say that while I have not got a great deal of hope of getting anything this year or maybe next, still I would like to be advised on the question as fully as possible so that I might convey the definite information to the Indians as I know that they will be asking me if I ever did anything about submitting their former request to the Department. Kindly reply to this letter as soon as possible so that I may have it about the middle of June when I expect to leave for the North.

Your obedient servant,

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.

I kindly accept the following as the monthly report of Fort Grahame Day School, for the period of June the 11th to July the 11th, 1935. Desks and seats were constructed from material which you kindly sent.

The number of children attending school is twenty-nine. They are all from Fort Grahame.

Dear Sir:

Kindly accept this as the second monthly report of the Fort Grahame Day School, for the period of July 11th to August 11th, 1935.

I am again pleased to report favourable progress. Group 5 has the following to its credit:— the first seventy-five pages of the Corona Reader, Primer I, the first forty-five pages of Friends, spelling tests and contests on the above material and Two Little Indians. In arithmetic, this group and also Group 5, has become quite proficient in addition and subtraction; the writing is fairly good in most cases.

Group 4 has completed Two Little Indians, the first twenty pages of Friends and ten miscellaneous pages of the Corona Reader. The writing of this group varies from ability to write the letters of the alphabet to rapid writing of about half of the words covered in their reading.

Group 3 has completed two Little Indians and the first twelve pages of Friends. Addition had been mastered by all and two of them are able to subtract. In writing, the progress varies from ability to write the greater part of the letters of the alphabet to the writing of the word-list in Two Little Indians.

Of Groups 2 and 1, two children have completed the alphabet and can read the first nine pages of Two Little Indians. The remainder of these groups have learned an average of half of the alphabet.

During the month, the number of strappings was three, and the behaviour has greatly improved.

I am sorry to report a large decrease in attendance, which is due to the annual mid-summer game shortage in the vicinity of Fort Grahame. This occurs every year, and it forces the Indians, and their families, to leave the settlement for the bush, where game is more plentiful.

Therefore, I strongly recommend that, henceforth, the Fort Grahame Day School be opened on the first day of May. By adopting this policy, the greater part of the Indians children, of this district, would be able to get the full advantage of three months of school, per year, instead of one, or two months, as it is the case for many this year.

Yours truly,

Signed:— E.J. Lambert.

P.S.:— Kindly send cheque "Via. Prince George".

Dear Sir:

Kindly accept this as the third monthly report of the Fort Grahame Day School, for the period of August the 11th to September the 11th, 1935.

As the school register, which I am sending under separate cover, will inform you, there was an early closing of this school.

I again beg to lay stress on the fact that, at Fort Grahame, at least, the Indians are forced to leave the settlement at an early date. This is due to the fact that this immediate region does not contain sufficient game to last the bulk of the Indians much past the first of August. This does not harmonize with the present school term. But it would, if the school term were advanced so that actual teaching could commence by the third week in May.

During this last part of the term the school work has continued its fine progress.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith a special report covering my recent visit to Fort McLeod, Fort Grahame and Whitewater Bands of Indians in the northern end of this Agency.

Fort Grahame Reserve

The School is very well received at Fort Grahame, the teacher, Mr. Downey, is splendid and has, I think, the proper ideas of teaching Indian children in an out-of-the-way place like this. He stresses cleanliness all the time and even makes some of them leave the class room to wash, should they come to school in a dirty condition. His discipline is also excellent and he has the children interested in games, principally softball, which they play during recess and in the evenings almost continually. The result of the school is also very evident in the fact that the health of the children here is much better than I have ever found it before and I put this down to the result of more regular habits and hours, as well as them being much cleaner. As it rained all day the flying weather was Nil. we had to stay at Fort Grahame all night, but finally got away from there the next morning and went another 90 miles North to the settlement of nomade Indians at Whitewater where they are living.

Dear Sir:

The following is a report on the progress of the different groups:

GROUP 1. These pupils are still on the alphabet and numbers. They are learning these quite good and are just about through with them. They are also learning the phonetic tables given in the back of the Catholic Corona readers.

GROUP 2. These pupils are still reading the readers, "Two Little Indians". They are almost through with this but will have to go over it for the second time next month. In arithmetic they are being taught addition and are at present taking addition of single digit numbers. They have completed the phonetic tables and have a good knowledge of them.

GROUP 3. This class has completed the reader, "Two Little Indians" and have started the Catholic Corona reader and "Friends". They are working the workbook in connection with "Two Little Indians". They are working book A of the individual arithmetics.

GROUP 4. This group is advancing quite rapidly. They have completed, "Friends" for the first time and we are reviewing it at present. They have started the workbook in connection with "Friends" and are progressing but slowly as this book is quite difficult. They have completed books A & B of the Individual Arithmetics and are ready to begin with book C. These pupils are also quite good writers. We are using the spellers in connection with Group 3 and 4 and we have gone as far as the sixth week.

All of the pupils have shown signs of being cleaner and there has been quite a few washings in the last month. The school is swept every day, scrubbed once a week and the children are quite anxious to do this.

Hoping this meets with your approval, I remain,

Yours truly,

Signed: - P.J. Downey.

Dear Sir;

I am enclosing with the report form this letter in coalition with the report as the space provided for remarks isn't large enough.

I have segregated the pupils into four groups in accordance with their reading. I have gone by the reading in their grouping because I find that they are very poor in arithmetic and numbers as they never had either to any great extent last year. The arithmetic books sent up this year are very useful in teaching the fundamentals of that subject and they have taken a firm interest in them and are progressing rapidly.

**GROUP 1.**

These pupils are the younger and smaller ones and have been spending most of the time on the alphabet and figures up to ten. They are learning to count and read the alphabet but are progressing at a slow rate as it is extremely difficult to hold their undivided attention for any length of time.

**GROUP 2.**

This group has completely mastered all the letters in the alphabet and all the numbers to 15. They are being drilled upon sounds of letters and formation of simple words. They are also being taught the formation of letters as a course preceding writing and use of the readers. They might start writing at any time but we have not desks for them to place their exercise books on so they will be taught reading when they are ready for that stage. A few of them are writing.

**GROUP 3.**

This group is well advanced into the readers. They are reviewing "Two Little Indians" at present. Along with them a few of the more advanced in group 2 are taking the reader but for the first time only. This group is quite good in colouring and in the other work set out in the work book, to accompany "Two Little Indians". In arithmetic they are taking addition of numbers and are using the assigned arithmetic work books. They have also mastered the spellers up to grade 3 work.

**GROUP 4.**

This group is showing rapid progress in arithmetic and are through with the first stage of addition and are starting subtraction. They have completed the readers, "Two Little Indians" and are half way through "Friends". Their writing in most cases is very good. Much stress is being laid upon the formation of sentences and the sounds of various words which they have some difficulty in pronouncing correctly. They are familiar with the spellers up to Grade 4, but now their progress in this will be slower as the words become more difficult.

These Indians here are quite ignorant of any form of discipline in or out of school but are not really bad at any time but just mischievous. I have them now so they march out of school and are quite orderly around their desks.

They are very dirty but I have them wash themselves if they come to school dirty. They wash right in front of the school under my supervision. No strappings have been administered as yet. The school is swept.
swept out every day and is thoroughly scrubbed every week.

If there are any further instructions please advise.

I remain,

Yours truly,

Signed:- P.J. Downey.

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

The following is a detailed report of the progress of the Fort Graham O.C. School for the month ending August 15th.

Group 1:

These pupils are reviewing the alphabet and numbers up to thirty and are being given writing exercises which they do on the blackboard. As yet they have not been given books or pencils. They are also being taught the first part of the phonetic table and much stress has been put upon the correct pronunciation of words which they use in everyday life. This last being done to call the groups from one to four.

Group 2:

They have completed the number...
up to one hundred and all of them can count this far, and several much farther. They are still reading "Two Little Indians" for the second time and are being drilled on the spelling exercises given in the back of this reader. They are just beginning to work the word book in connection with "Two Little Indians" and are able to distinguish colours quite well. In arithmetic other than counting they are learning to add the numbers up to ten and to subtract them.

Group 3.

In arithmetic they are advancing very well; they have completed books A and B of the Individual Arithmetics and have a good knowledge of them. They are going over "Two Little Indians" for the third time and have almost completed the work book in connection with it. They are also taking the Arithmetic
up to one hundred and all of them can count this far and several much farther. They are still reading "Two Little Indians" for the second time and are being drilled on the spelling exercises given in the book of this reader. They are just beginning to work the word book in connection with "Two Little Indians" and are able to distinguish colours quite well. In arithmetic other than counting they are learning to add the numbers up to ten and to subtract them.

Group 3.

In arithmetic they are advancing very well; they have completed books A and B of the Individual Arithmetics and have a good knowledge of these. They are going over "Two Little Indians" for the third time and have almost completed the work book in connection with it. They are also taking the Catholic Grade Reader. They are spell advanced in spelling having completed
in the spellers to the end of the 10th week.

January 4.

These pupils' work in arithmetic has been advancing quite slowly as Book C of the Individual arithmetics is quite hard. They are about two thirds of the way through it and as far as they have gone have a thorough knowledge of it. They are reviewing the reader "Friends," again as there are no other readers to give them. Their work in the work book in connection with "Friends" is advancing slowly as they find this book extremely difficult. In the spellers they have completed to the end of the 80th week and can spell the words very well.

General

Throughout the term they have been given physical exercises whenever the weather permitted them to take them outside as the school is too small for any indoor exercises. They have taken
a great liking for the game of softball and we played almost every evening. Having them work at softball has certainly had its effect and for the last month they have all come to school clean and tidy. There have only been two pupils made to work Saturdays since July 30th.

The main thing that has been taught them is discipline. This is very difficult as their parents have no control over them but they are improving gradually.

All of the school supplies have been crated up and left in the school house nothing will touch them and the Quiter's supplies have been left in the warehouse of the Hudson's Bay Co.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit a report on the work done during the quarter ending August 22nd, 1938.

The grading has been somewhat changed, chiefly for psychological effect. Since there were no beginners this year, the fourth grade has remained the highest.

The use of text books has been reduced to a minimum. Much time has been spent on vocabulary building in preparation for the use of texts. Two fifteen-minute periods each day have been devoted to language lessons for the class as a whole. In this way sentence structure and pronunciation have been improved. Lip and tongue formation and coordination have been stressed for the purpose of securing an improved articulation. I am convinced that we could absolutely necessary as a preparation for reading.

Phonetics has been taught in all the grades.

An attempt has been made to make the arithmetic lessons as practical as possible by applying them to the calculation of the value of fur catches, counting change etc.

Attention and discipline have been given special attention and religious instruction has been given daily. The Lord's Prayer and the Angelic Salutation have been learned by all.

The school supplies have been listed and packed. The donation for 1939 will be forwarded under separate cover.

Yours very truly,

Walter Fitzgerald

In reply to your letter of the 21st ultimo, your File, 163-13-1 and with further reference to my letter of the 9th instant, No. N-3-S-719, I wish to advise that on account of illness Mr. Joseph Villeneuve who was substituted for Mr. Walter Fitzgerald, the teacher re-appointed for the Fort Grahame seasonal school failed to put in an appearance, Mr. Edward Joseph Lambert arrived to take his place and left Prince George for Fort Grahame on the 20th instant. His duties will commence June 1st. I may say Mr. Lambert taught at the Fort Grahame School in 1935 and that his appointment has been approved of by His Lordship, Bishop Bunoz.

I am enclosing herewith a staff questionnaire, duly completed. Kindly forward Mr. Lambert's salary cheque in care of this office.

Your obedient servant,

Robert Howe,
Acting Indian Agent.

RH/L.

The appointment of Mr. Edward Joseph Lambert as teacher of the Fort Grahame seasonal school for the coming summer is approved. He will be allowed salary at the rate of $90.00 a teaching month.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

**Remarks as to Progress, etc.:**

The school was closed for 3 days due to high water which flooded the school and the Indians had to move camp to higher ground. The low attendance of some of the pupils is due to their not coming in from their trap lines until some few days ago. Dear Sir;

The following is a detailed report on the progress of the pupils at the Fort Grahame Day School for the month ending July 15th.

Group 1.
The pupils in this group are learning the alphabet and the figures up to thirty. They are also learning the formation of figures.

Group 2.
The pupils in this group have read the reader "Two Little Indians" twice. They have just started "The Catholic Corona Reader." Their progress in the "Corona Reader" is very slow as they find it very difficult. In arithmetic they are half way through Book A of the "Individual Arithmetic." They practice writing nearly every day.

Group 3.
The pupils in this group have completed "The Catholic Corona Reader" and are well advanced in the reader "Friends." In arithmetic they have completed Books A and B of the "Individual Arithmetic." In spelling they have completed the spelling exercises to the end of the fifteenth week in the grade 3 work.

Group 4.
The pupils in this group have finished the reader "Friends." Their work in the work book in connection with "Friends" is advancing quite rapidly. They have just started to read "The Golden Mill." In arithmetic they have completed Books B and C of the "Individual Arithmetic" and are well advanced in the "Canadian Problem and Practice Arithmetic." In spelling they have completed the grade 3 spelling exercises.

Groups 2, 3, & 4 are being drilled on the phonetic tables. These groups are very good at drawing and colouring.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

The following is a detailed report on the progress of the pupils at the Fort Grahame Day School for the month ending August 15th.

GROUP 1. The pupils in this group are reviewing the alphabet and have finished the numbers up to fifty. During the latter part of the term they were taught the formation of figures. As yet, they have not begun to read or write.

GROUP 2. The pupils in this group have completed Book A of the Individual arithmetic. In reading they have completed "Two Little Indians" for the third time. Their progress in the Catholic Corona reader has been very slow as they find it very difficult. They are being given writing exercises nearly every day.

GROUP 3. The pupils in this group have completed Books A and B and have started Book C of the Individual arithmetic. In reading, they have completed the reader "Friends." In spelling they are advancing quite rapidly. To date, they have completed the spelling exercises to the end of the Grade 3 work.

GROUP 4. The pupils in this group are advancing quite rapidly in Arithmetic. To date, they have completed to page 46 in the "Canadian Problem and Practice Arithmetic." In reading they have finished the reader called the "Golden Mill." They are well advanced in spelling, having completed the spelling exercises to the end of the 16th week in the Grade 4 work.

Groups 2, 3, and 4 are still being drilled on the phonetic tables. During the latter part of the term the above groups were given drawing lessons nearly every day.

The school supplies have been crated and left in the school. The janitor's supplies, etc., have been stored in the Hudson's Bay warehouse.

Yours truly,

### Remarks as to Progress, etc.

- **Edward Hunter**: Weak average intelligence and willingness to learn, but seem to find it impossible to concentrate on studies, even when warned, for more than three quarters of an hour at a time. They are particularly restless during the last quarter of the day and it is almost impossible to sustain interest during this period.

Ottawa, May 4, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th ultimo, regarding the establishment of a summer school for the benefit of the Indian children at Fort Grahame and enclosing the applications which you received for the position as teacher.

In reply I have to say the Department will approve of this school being conducted for a three month period during the coming summer, from, approximately, June 16th to September 16th, next.

Approval is also granted for the appointment of Mr. Gerard Beauregard, B.A., of St. Joseph's Seminary, Edmonton, as teacher. He was nominated by the Roman Catholic Church authorities. The salary allowed him during the period the school is in operation will be at the rate of $90 per teaching month.

A requisition has been forwarded to the Government Stationery Office to forward, addressed to you, the supply of classroom material considered necessary. You should arrange to have this forwarded to Fort Grahame, in due time.

With reference to the request that the Department make an advance of $25 towards the cost of supplies while the teacher makes the journey in to the school and a like amount on his return, I have to say that the amount provided for salary is all we can allow. Present regulations do not permit making advances or payment of any part of the cost of transportation of teachers to and from a school.

Please advise the church authorities and Mr. Beauregard of his appointment and arrange that he arrive at Fort Grahame in time to commence duties on the date above mentioned. The teacher should prepare and forward a return, showing attendance, days taught, etc., at the end of each month, when cheque in payment of salary due will be sent. It is hoped that this school will meet with success during this summer.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

R. H. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof,

Dear Sir,

Salary at the rate of $60 a teaching month will be allowed for each of the above two teachers.

I enclose staff questionnaire forms, which you should have them complete and return as soon as possible.

The appointment of Mr. Patrick Downey as teacher of the Takla Landing Seasonal School was approved by official letter of the 6th instant.

It would be advisable, also, to have each teacher prepare a short report at the close of the summer season with reference to the work done during the time each school was in operation.

Yours truly,

EXTRACT from letter of April 6th, 1935,
from R. H. Moore, Esq., Indian Agent, Vanderhoof,
B. C., re Fort Grahame and Fort McLeod Schools.

Original on File 163.-12-1.

It seems hard for me to get a list of just what articles of school equipment is required for each of these schools, and I feel as if it would be better to leave the matter in the hands of the Department entirely, with the request that you please send me here a shipment of supplies necessary for the Fort Grahame School with approximately 50 pupils, and for the School at Fort McLeod with approximately 30 or 35 pupils. These two shipments should be entirely separate and clearly marked. In making them up, please understand that practically all the pupils in each place will be beginners and consequently will not require any advanced books, etc. I would suggest that slates and pencils be sent if possible, as well as scribblers, etc. Pens and ink will not be required for this year at least. If you could attend to this part of it for me at Ottawa, I would appreciate a list of what you do send.

Vanderhoof, B.C., June 13th, 1938.

Sir:
