EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM R. H. Moore, INDIAN AGENT, Vanderhoof, B. C., dated May 28th, 1935.

During my last visit to Fort Grahame and Fort McLeod during June, 1932, I had several requests at meetings held at Fort Grahame and Fort McLeod that the Department establish a day school at Fort Grahame during the summer months instead of taking the children to the residential school at Lejac, as has been and still is the method used. At those meetings, I did not make any definite promises, although I saw the reasonableness of most of the recommendations brought up by the Indians. However, I postponed the matter for the time being by telling them that, owing to hard times generally, it would not be possible for the Department to assume any further obligations in the matter of educational facilities. As I will be going into that reserve again in a month, I deem it advisable at this time to submit the whole proposition to the Department with a request that I receive a reply to this letter before I leave so that I can convey the contents of it to the Indians when I go north.
EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM R. H. Moore, Indian Agent, Vanderhoof, B. C., dated August 18, 1934.

Regarding Fort Grahame, I feel that we might be well advised to buy a few windows for the church building there, improve the roof a little and put some repairs on the floor, as it would be much cheaper than completing the building the Indians are going to put up, and will answer the purpose sufficiently well for three or four years at least until we can see with what degree of success our efforts in this connection are met by the Indians. Consequently, I would say that I could get along with $100.00 for Fort Grahame. If the desks have got to be made you can figure on an equal amount to Fort MacLeod.
Referring to departmental letter 163-12-1 of June 8th, last, regarding the possibility of establishing summer schools at Fort Grahame and Fort McLeod, I wish to report that at the former place there are 47 children of school age, none of whom have ever attended any school. No building is available, except the church, and it is not very suitable, owing to the fact that it is quite dark. However, when I discussed the matter with the Indians, they were quite prepared to put up a suitable log building providing the Department would assist them by supplying shingles for the roof, windows and door. There is no one available at this point who would be able to conduct the school, but the Principal of the Lejac Indian Residential School told me that if the Department would establish a school there, he would get qualified teachers and the salary would be very reasonable. He did not say the amount but I am sure that any figure the Department would set would be agreeable.
February 13, 1935.

Memorandum:

Fort Grahame: - To complete building for summer day school purposes - $100.00

Fort Grahame is located in the northern part of the Stuart Lake agency. Agent Moore reports there are 47 children of school age at this point, the majority of whom have never attended school. A request has been made by the Roman Catholic missionary and the Agent, that a summer school be conducted. There is a church building at this point, which, the Agent states, could be improved at much lower cost than erecting a new building. He estimates that, for the sum of $100, building material could be supplied to fit up the church building - which would provide suitable accommodation for school purposes for a number of years.

I would suggest that, when funds are available, the Agent be authorized to purchase building material, at a cost not exceeding the above amount, forwarding detailed accounts, in triplicate. It is understood that the labour will be performed by the Indians, without cost to the Department.
Ottawa, February 20, 1935.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant, regarding the proposed establishment of a summer school at Fort Graham, I have to inform you that the sum of $100 is provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the coming fiscal year, to complete a building for school purposes. In your letter dated August 18th, last, you stated that it would be advisable to buy a few windows for the church building, carry out certain improvements to the roof and also some repairs to the floor. You indicated that this arrangement would be much cheaper than erecting a log building and would answer the purpose sufficiently well for three or four years, until it is ascertained what degree of success will result in the operation of the school. It is noted, also, that it would cost approximately $75 to make the desks required.

The Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase of the building materials required to fit up the church building, to an amount not to exceed $100. Purchase should be made from firms on the approved list. Further, you are authorized to incur an expenditure not exceeding $75.00 in the purchase of the material required in building the desks. Please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, stating in detail the materials purchased. These accounts, you should attach proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. It should be understood, however, that, as our appropriation will not be available until the first of April, next, payment of accounts cannot be made before that date. I would request that you take any action in having the improvements carried out to the church building.

If the building is in readiness to start classroom work early next summer, you should take up with the church authorities the question of nominating a suitable teacher. The name, qualifications and experience of the teacher nominated should be forwarded for the approval of the Department.

I shall be pleased to hear from you, in due time, regarding the progress being made in completing the buildings for classroom purposes at both Fort Graham and Fort McLeod. If possible, you should supervise the work at both points and see that no waste is made of the materials supplied. When informing the Department of the teacher nominated, you should forward a requisition, setting forth the classroom supplies, such as blackboard, text books, scribblers, etc., required.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

R. H. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof, B. C.
Vanderhoof, B.C., October 11th, 1935.

Sir:

I beg to attach hereto the attendance report of the Fort McLeod Summer school, along with a report from the teacher, which I trust you will find satisfactory.

While on the subject of schools I wish to say that the total expenditure for school buildings both at Fort McLeod and Fort Grahame this year amounted to approximately $120.00 out of the amount of $450.00 authorized by the Department. The new school at Fort McLeod was not completed last spring in time to hold school in, so that the church was used. However, now it is ready except for the roof, windows and other material which will have to be shipped in and which will cost approximately $185.00 landed at the head of the waterways so that the Indians can get it. I would suggest that we allow the Indians sufficient gasoline to take the material down the river and lakes by boats and which should cost about $30.00 so that the $185.00 for material plus $30.00 for gasoline would be $215.00 and if agreeable to the Department I propose to make this purchase now of the money that is available and have it ready to go in first thing next May. This will make the total expenditure of $335.00 and the balance of $115.00 could be returned to the Treasury. Please advise me in this connection at your convenience.

Your obedient servant,

R. H. Moore,
Indian Agent.
Vanderhoof, B.C., July 20, 1937.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith a special report covering my recent visit to the Indians of Fort Grahame and Whitewater,

FORT GRAHAME RESERVE

This reserve was visited in the afternoon, some sickness of a mild nature was also found here and treatment and medicine given by the doctor. The school was inspected by me and found to be operating quite successfully. Mr. McKenzie the teacher, is doing good work and the children looked quite happy and making progress. The Indians have cut logs for a new school building but at the time of my visit these logs were still in the bush and the Indians said they would haul them out and put them up as soon as they could get a set of harness for their horses. (The only use they put horses to up there is packing consequently they have not got harness for any other work.)

R. H. Moore,
Indian Agent.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM R. H. MOORE, INDIAN AGENT, VANDERHOOF, B. C., dated July 30, 1934.

Original on 163-12-1.

Fort McLeod: Regarding the possibility of establishing a summer school at this point, I wish to report that there are 28 children of school age in this reserve, some of whom have attended the Lejac Indian Residential School. Here again there is not a building available for a school, but the Indians agreed to get logs out and put up the building if the Department would assist with the roof, windows and door. There is a woman at Fort McLeod who used to be a school teacher before she married the Factor of the H. B. Co.'s post at this point. I know that she would take over the job of teaching but plans to go outside this Fall herself with her own family so that they can attend school, it is therefore doubtful whether she would be available next year or not. However, the same arrangements can be made there as at Fort Grahame, leave the matter of teacher up to the Church, who has agreed to supply one. At all events, you can instruct me on this point later.

Orig. on 163-12-1

In acknowledging receipt of your letter
of the 13th instant, File No. 163-12-1, regarding the
establishing of proposed day schools at Fort Grahame
and Fort MacLeod, I beg to say that in my report of
the 30th ultimo I stated the number of pupils available
at each of the above points, viz. 47 at Fort Grahame
and 28 at Fort MacLeod.

Regarding the approximate expenditure neces-
sary for the completion of a suitable building at Fort
MacLeod for a school, I think that $200.00 would be the
maximum required and should cover the cost of the floor,
shingles and lumber for the roof, windows and doors,
and might allow something for stove, stovpipe, and roof

Dear Sir:

I understand that during the coming summer, a school, which will be in session during June, July and August, will be opened, for the Indian children at McLeod's Lake. I hereby make application for the position of teacher of this school.

I am the holder of a First Class B.C. Teacher's Certificate; Strathcona Trust Diploma; and certificates from the Provincial Summer School, in English, Literature, Expression, and Choral Singing. I have six years' experience as a teacher in rural schools in British Columbia. I am privileged to refer you to Mr. G.H. Gower, Dept. of Education, Victoria, who was the Inspector of Schools who visited the schools I taught, during the greater part of the time I was teaching. Mr. Gower is well known in educational circles for the high standard he sets his teachers, both as regards achievement and discipline. I have no hesitation in referring you to him for an estimate of my ability. He would know me only as "Miss Connellan".

I realize that this type of school would differ considerably from the ordinary public schools. No doubt the ordinary curriculum subjects would be taught, with particular stress upon oral language? The children at McLeod, as you doubtless know, speak English - but very badly. I would suggest particular stress upon cleanliness, and the common rules of health, as with all beginners, and children unaccustomed to school discipline, considerable time would have to be devoted to handwork.

To give effective instruction, in addition to ordinary school supplies, at least the following would be required: for hand work - crayons; paints; coloured folding papers; outline pictures to colour; sewing cards; kindergarten scissors; paste - preferably individual jars; and, of course, an adequate supply of drawing paper - which, one pre-supposes, would be included in "ordinary school supplies". For instance along the line of cleanliness and health - which instruction would, of necessity, take the form, to a considerable extent, of example, plus daily practice - I consider the following to be highly advisable - (and, for effective instruction, imperative): a minimum of four wash basins; paper towels; an abundance of soap; individual paper drinking cups; a goodly supply of kleenex (paper handkerchiefs) for daily "handkerchief drill"; a tooth brush for each pupil, together with several shakers of common salt. While not urgently required, a supply of some antiseptic mouth wash would be used to great advantage, in the inoculation of good habits. In addition to these requisites, I would suggest that gold and coloured "stars" and "dots" be supplied. These items are invaluable in any school room where the mentality of a small child prevails. With these children, particularly, every means of encouragement should be employed. Of particular value also, would be coloured chalks, counting blocks, and sticks, of varied lengths.

There is, in addition, a particularly valuable book published, entitled, I think, "Reading Lessons for Beginners", by Miss J.M. Fisher. This book is used now in many beginners' classes. It retails at 75¢ a copy, and a copy is required by each child.

I presume that there is a standard salary paid to the teachers of these outlying Indian schools? It is possible that transportation is allowed, from Prince George, or some given point which would vary with the geographical location of the school? This would not be necessary in my case, as my husband is in charge of the Hudson's Bay Company's store at McLeod's Lake, and I should be there, in any event, during the summer months.

I might add that I have spent two winters there, so that I already know the residents of the village - both parents and children. Should you see fit to appoint me to the position in question, the children would not have to overcome their natural shyness with an utter stranger, at the outset.

Although I know Capt. Barrie, Inspector of Indian Schools, I cannot refer you to him as regards school work. He has never had experience of me as a teacher. The fact, however, that Mr. Gower suggested to me that I take the position (frequently held by Capt. Barrie) of teacher of one of the rural classes in the Demonstration School, attached to the Provincial Normal School in Victoria, should convey to you some impression of the standard of my teaching.

Should you see fit to appoint me teacher on this school, I shall conscientiously endeavour to do all in my power for the mental, and physical advancement of the children. To such work I should bring, not only technical experience, but a not inconsiderable knowledge of the Indian mind and character, gained during six years' association with them in Kitwanga, and at McLeod's Lake.

I shall be at the above address until navigation opens on the Crooked River, in May. Thenceforth, letters should be addressed to me at McLeod, Via. Prince George.

Yours very truly,

Signed:- Sheila Utterstrom.

Indian Agent,

Ottawa, May 4, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th ultimo, regarding the establishment of a summer school for the benefit of the Indian children at Fort McLeod and enclosing the applications which you received for the position as teacher.

In reply I have to say the Department will approve of this school being conducted for a three month period during the coming summer, from, approximately, June 16th to September 15th, next.

Approval is also granted for the appointment of Mr. George N. Cormack, St. Joseph's Seminary, Edmonton, as teacher. He was nominated by the Roman Catholic Church authorities. The salary allowed him during the period the school is in operation will be at the rate of $90 per teaching month.

A requisition has been forwarded to the Government Stationery Office to forward, addressed to you, the supply of classroom material considered necessary. You should arrange to have this forwarded to Fort McLeod, in due time.

With reference to the request that the Department make an advance of $25 towards the cost of supplies while the teacher makes the journey in to the school and a like amount on his return, I have to say that the amount provided for salary is all we can allow. Present regulations do not permit making advances or payment of any part of the cost of transportation of teachers to and from a school.

Please advise the church authorities and Mr. Cormack of his appointment and arrange that he arrive at Fort McLeod in time to commence duties on the date above mentioned. The teacher should prepare and forward a return, showing attendance, days taught, etc., at the end of each month, when cheque in payment of salary due will be sent. It is hoped this school will meet with success.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

R. H. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof, B. C.
April 29, 1935.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Funds are provided in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year to fit up a building for summer day school purposes at Fort McLeod (McLeod Lake Reserve, No. 5 - Federal District of Cariboo), B.C.

Mr. R. H. Moore, Indian Agent, is arranging to have the building ready for classroom purposes, and the school will be conducted for a three months period this coming summer - June 15th to September 15th, next.

There are 28 Indian children on this reserve, who have never attended any school, and they are all Roman Catholic. The Roman Catholic Church authorities have nominated the services of Mr. George N. Cormack, St. Joseph's Seminary, Edmonton, Alberta. Mr. Cormack has first class general standing in both Junior and Senior Matriculation and is at present enrolled at the above named Seminary, taking Philosophy in conjunction with courses in Arts at the University of Alberta.

I should be pleased to have your approval for the conducting of classroom activities during the coming summer months and also for the appointment of Mr. Cormack as teacher. The salary provided is at the rate of $90.00 per teaching month.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.
Sir:

I would respectfully refer you to official letter dated February 20th last, File No.163-12-5, relative to the proposed summer school at Fort McLeod. Also your letter on the same subject in connection with Fort Graham, File No. 163-13-5.

In the above connection I wish to attach hereto copies of three applications I have received for the position of teacher at these points. You will note that those two received from St. Joseph's Seminary were nominated by the Church authorities, and the other application is from Mrs. Vetterstrom, wife of the Manager of the Hudson's Bay Company's post at Fort McLeod. I might say that the reason this application was received was on account of me discussing the question with her last Summer while at Fort McLeod, as I found out while there that she had been a School teacher before she was married. At that time I asked her if she would consider putting in an application for the position should one be available this year, and she said that she would consider the matter and let me know definitely this year, hence the application. That of course was prior to the time that it was thought that it might be advisable to allow the Church authorities to nominate the teachers.

You will please note that the salary expected by these applicants is not mentioned and I would therefore suggest that you allow them the same salary as the Department usually pays to a first year teacher under the same conditions. If it is decided to appoint the two male teachers, I feel that the Church authorities will make arrangements for their transportation up there, but would like to recommend that a grant of $25-00 be made to each one to cover the cost of supplies while making the journey in, and a like amount for the same purpose on their returning to the line of Railway at Prince George. I mean by that, that the supplies would not be bought for them until they are ready to leave Prince George en route North.

Both these schools should be ready to open by June 15th, and the teachers will be on the ground four or five days before that. That would allow them to run until August 15th to make up the three months. I trust this will be satisfactory to the Department.

It seems hard for me to get a list of just what articles of school equipment is required for each of these schools, and I feel as if it would be better to leave the matter in the hands of the Department entirely, with the request that you please send me here a shipment of supplies necessary for the Fort Graham School with approximately 50 pupils, and for the School at Fort McLeod with approximately 30 or 35 pupils. These two shipments should be entered separately and clearly marked. In making them up please understand that practically all the pupils in each place will be beginners, and consequently will not require any advanced books etc. I would suggest that slates and pencils be sent if possible, as well as scribblers etc. Pens and ink will not be required for this year at least. If you could attend to this part of it for me at Ottawa, I would appreciate a list of what you do send.

Your obedient servant,

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.

Enclosures.
The school was opened on June 21st after spending some time on making up forms from the lumber supplied. Due to the lack of a school-building at present, the classes were held in the Church Building except when the priest was staying at Ft. McLeod, during which time the building could be used for no other purposes than as a church. The days on which the school was open are indicated by the register, June 21st-Aug. 21st.

Five Saturdays were taught on to make the requisite number of days, i.e., to and including Sept. 9th.

At the opening of the school there were about 30 in attendance although there are 19 only registered as of school age. Older boys to about 20 years of age came to school and seemed quite anxious to learn. Later in the summer, the attendance of these older boys declined since, in the fall there is hunting and berrying to be done and they were unable to attend regularly. But the spirit of the whole village seemed to be ambitious in the matter of learning. Many of the boys and girls are self-educated, of course to a very limited extent, but they indicate the general attitude towards education. Thus the school is greatly appreciated by the village as a whole.

Discipline was quite good and there was very little trouble of this sort with either the children or the parents.

School hours were about four hours a day. For the first year, at least, on a new untried project with children unused to anything of this sort, I did not feel that a longer day was necessary, and indeed a longer day for the children would do more harm than good, at least until they are more used to school.

Progress Report.

There was no definite grading of the pupils although there was a classification into groups according to their advancement. Three boys Robert Harrisson Yalie?, Harry Chingee, Andrew Solanas had been to
Lejac, the first two for 1 year and the latter for 3 years. These of course were much advanced but could not very well be graded much beyond grade one. In some respects especially the latter were much beyond the first grade but in other respects were far behind. Although able to read very well for the length of time they were at school, yet they understood little of what they read. Their vocabularies both in speaking and reading are very limited and are confined to words with which they have daily contact. Then they do not understand anything written in a grammatical style for they understand only what is presented to them in the type of English which they use in speaking to white people. Thus, although advanced in the phonics of reading, they are retarded in its understanding, and in their speaking far below grade one. Likewise although they have been practiced, through necessity, in the art of composition and writing (of letters), their knowledge of grammatical structure is completely nil. In number work the first two advanced this year to subtraction and the latter has been working on multiplication tables. In pencilled art work they are very good for low grade pupils.

Writing.

The rest of the pupils advanced to a varying degree of knowledge in forming individual letters in chalk but not using pencils yet until they are quite familiar with the formation of all the letters. Only one boy, Achille Chingee writes all the letters and some words using pencil and paper. There are of course, older boys who are learning to write also with pencil and paper.

Phonics.

All advanced to varying stages in the recognition of individual letters and sounds and simple words (based on the phonics table at the back of the Corona Primer)
Number-work.

All know the formation of the numbers and are in varying stages of counting except Achille Chingee who had advanced quite far into addition.

Vocabulary.

All the children except the very young ones have a knowledge of the simple concrete and action words and further training in this line was very handicapped and almost impossible without further facilities.

Religion.

Due to their simplicity of language and difficulty in understanding the abstract or any type of logical English sequence of language it is almost impossible to give these children any kind of religious instruction by one who does not know their language without it going completely over their heads. This problem is one which would require very careful thought and a very definite plan of action before even attempting anything in this line.

Art.

The older pupils who can manage pencils easily are very good considering their former complete lack of art training. Further facilities such as art manuals and elementary art courses should be supplied for this part of the course.

Recommendations for further school supplies.

1. Phonic charts and flash cards are almost essential for any progress in phonics.
2. Number-work flash cards.
3. Blunt pointed scissors for cut outs in the work-books. These are necessary for fixing a vocabulary in the mind of the child.
4. Elementary Art manuals and courses for art training.

George A. Connaught
H. McLeod Indian School Teacher

Progress Report - McLeod's Lake

Group 1
Three of this group are progressing satisfactorily in reading writing and arithmetic. One of these, in particular, is advancing very rapidly in all branches. Leon Neville has at last shown signs of a glimmering of understanding. After an intensive campaign of a couple of months he is becoming a little more sure of himself in telling the difference between 1, 2, 3, although less sure of 4 & 5. His writing of individual letters is good, and although he seems to be able to distinguish letters better than numbers, still he becomes confused very easily. I am convinced he has a good deal of intelligence but, although he seems not to be bothered with such things as inhibitions (a more cheerful happy-go-lucky sort never existed), it would seem to require a psychologist to bring out that intelligence.

The fifth member of the group is about seven years old, has just started school and was away for the most of the term, so that his progress has been negligible.

Group 2
The three boys in this group are very satisfactory. One of them in particular, very slow in getting started, has in the last two years become really interested and has made good progress. These three are in the Corona Primer, are doing various degrees of addition and subtraction and are all good in writing although not in sentence composition.

The two girls in the group have had, in one case three, and in the other two, weeks of school this term. In addition to this handicap the girls just do not pick up English as well as the boys. This and their natural shyness retards their progress, particularly in reading. But their arithmetic is on a level with that of the rest of the group.

Group 3
One of this group (on the basis of his former work) has been away for the whole term, but since he has been to Lejac for three years he is still ahead of the others although Harry Chingee is advanced now almost as far. One of this group, Charlie Isidore, is not up to the level of the rest - but of the others two are reading the 1st Reader and two have finished it. Three of them are doing simple problems (one of these is the one who never attended - but he is graded on the basis of last summer) and the other two addition and subtraction. Four of them are advancing very well in the art of making sentences and the other one rather badly in this line.

In general - Their musical education has been directed along the line of Church music which is of course their chief contact with that art. I have even been able in the last summer to teach six or seven to read music in at least one key.

Their cleanliness is problematical. During the summer they can be kept in a reasonable state. But after a long winter a certain carelessness may be detected. However I notice that as they grow older their lessons in cleanliness seem to stick better, so that in general as they grow older they become much more careful in this matter.

Practical religious knowledge is satisfactory especially since they have the added advantage of a permanent mission.

Arithmetic.

Group I - This group has covered the following: counting up to ten, the writing of their numbers in figures up to 10, and in words up to five.

Sir:

I beg to attach hereto the monthly report from the McLeod Lake seasonal day school as submitted to me by the teacher, George N. Cormack. I wrote to Mr. Cormack regarding the date he closed the school and he explained as follows:

"I received your letter of August 7 and I am herewith enclosing the report for August. The school at Fort McLeod was closed this year at approximately the same date as it has been for the past four years. Owing to the fact that many of the Indians leave the village in August to hunt, and that all of them are occupied picking berries for their winter supplies, it is difficult to keep the pupils in attendance during that month. Therefore Mr. Moore instructed us we might teach on Saturdays and substitute these for the last 12 days of the term. This is what was done this year so that the full number of days was made up."

"The school was closed on Aug. 3. This was one day earlier and was because I had the opportunity, as noted in the report, of obtaining transportation to Prince George, the last opportunity at that time for, probably ten days. This was also in accord with Mr. Moore's past instructions which he gave us in view of the difficulty of getting boats or planes in that country at any specified time."

Trusting that Mr. Cormack's report will be found satisfactory,

Your obedient servant,

Jas. H.F. Lacey,
Acting Indian Agent.

SECTION 91 OF THE INCOME WAR TAX ACT

(Being Section 26, 4 Geo. VI., Ch. 34, 1940 (Second Session) as Amended by Section 30, 5 Geo. VI., Ch. 18, 1941)

NOTE—Section 91, as reproduced below has been declared by Act of Parliament to be in force from the thirteenth day of April, 1940, and to be applicable to all payments on and after that date; provided, however, that the rate of National Defense Tax applicable to any income or portion of any taxpayer's income shall not exceed five per centum, whereas 5% is mentioned, and 5% wherever 7% is mentioned in subsection one of Section 91.

To Whom Applicable

In addition to the other persons assessed by this Act, there shall be levied and paid upon the income of every person described in paragraphs (a) to (e), both inclusive, of subsection one of section nine of this Act a tax to be known as the National Defense Tax at the rate of—

Tax Rates

(a) in the case of a married person whose spouse is resident in Canada or in another part of the territory of the British Commonwealth of Nations or in a country contiguous to Canada, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year; and in the case of a husband and wife having resided together for more than twenty years, of seven per centum if the income exceeds $660 per year;

(b) in the case of a single person, or a married person whose spouse is not resident in Canada or in another part of the territory of the British Commonwealth of Nations or in a country contiguous to Canada, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year; or of seven per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year;

(c) in the case of a widow or widower with a son or daughter resident in Canada or in another part of the territory of the British Commonwealth of Nations or in a country contiguous to Canada, and under twenty-one years of age who is wholly dependent upon him for support, or of a son or daughter similarly resident and twenty-one years of age or over likewise so dependent so dependent or physically infirm, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year;

(d) in the case of an individual who maintains a self-contained domestic establishment which actually supports therein a person wholly dependent upon him and connected with him by blood relationship, marriage or adoption, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year;

(e) in the case of a minister or clergyman in charge of a diocese, congregation or parish, who is wholly dependent upon him for support at his own expense, or of a self-contained domestic establishment, and who employs therein on full time a housekeeper or servant, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year;

(f) in the case of the income taxable as provided by subsections two and four of section eleven of this Act, of seven per centum;

Provided that there shall be allowed a tax credit of four dollars for the year 1940, fourteen dollars for the year 1941 and twenty dollars for the year 1942 and each year thereafter for each of the following purposes resident in Canada or in another part of the territory of the British Commonwealth of Nations or in a country contiguous to Canada and wholly dependent upon the taxpayer:

(i) a child, grandchild, brother or sister of the taxpayer under twenty-one years of age, or if twenty-one years of age or over wholly dependent on account of mental or physical infirmity;

(ii) a parent or grandparent of a taxpayer, wholly dependent on account of mental or physical infirmity;

(iii) a child maintained by the taxpayer in Canada under a co-operative scheme approved by the Minister of Finance of the United Kingdom of Canada or any of the provinces of Canada for children brought from the United Kingdom of Canada, except one such dependent whose account the taxpayer is entitled to have the tax charged as provided in paragraphs (c) or (d) of this subsection.

Tax Not to Reduce Basic Income

If the tax payable under the provisions of this section shall cause the income of a single person or a husband or wife to be reduced below the amount of $660, or in the case of those persons referred to in paragraphs (a), (c), (d) and (e) of subsection one of this section (except a husband or wife who have resided together for more than twenty years), or in the case of the income taxable as provided by subsections two and four of section eleven of this Act, such tax shall not be payable.

Extra Tax

(3) Taxes imposed by this section, which have not been deducted at the source shall be collected by the following amounts, which shall be imposed and collected with the tax.

If the tax is $25.00 but not more than $100.00, by 10%.

If the tax is more than $100.00, by three per centum of the tax payable.

Persons Not Liable

(4) Income of the following persons shall not be liable to tax under this section—

(a) incorporated companies;

(b) persons and institutions mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (i), both inclusive, of subsection one of section four of this Act;

(c) municipalities or municipal or public bodies which in the opinion of the Minister perform a function of Government;

(d) the armed forces, all personnel of—

(i) warrant officers, non-commissioned officers and men of the Canadian Naval, Military and Air Forces while in the Canadian active service;

(ii) commissioned officers of the Canadian Navy while serving abroad in Canada, or in any part of Canada whose duties are such a nature as are required normally to be performed abroad or in aircraft;

Deduction by Employer

Every employer at the time of payment of earnings to an employee and at the time of payment of any other amount to an employee under this section shall deduct from the earnings of the employee paid on or after the first day of July, one thousand nine hundred and forty, the amount of five per centum of the value of the services rendered by the employee daily, weekly, monthly or for any other period of time such that if continued the total amount would be the amount of the relevant amount mentioned in subsection one of this section.

Remittance by Employer

(5) Every employer shall, on or before the fifteenth day of the month next following that in which the earnings were due, pay to the Receiver General of Canada the full amount of the tax so deducted, the first remittance to be made on the sixteenth day of September, 1940.

Deduction From Interest and Dividends

(7) Any interest bearing interest on bonds, debentures or other like obligations or dividends on shares or shares of stock, irrespective of the amount, to persons registered as the holders of bonds, debentures or like obligations or as shareholders deduct and pay to the Receiver General of Canada on and every such day made to residents of Canada on or after the first day of July, one thousand nine hundred and forty-one.

Remittance by Corporation

Returns

Persons Deemed Trustees

Legal Immunity

Forms and Returns Required

Offences and Penalties

(14) Every person failing to deduct or remit or to deduct and remit the tax pursuant to the provisions of this section at the time prescribed therefor shall be liable to a fine not exceeding the amount of tax which should have been deducted and remitted, but the penalty shall not exceed five hundred dollars.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

On November 18, 1946, The Most Reverend A. Jordan, C.M.I., D.D., Bishop of Prince Rupert, visited the office and brought the following matters to our attention:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from Indian Agent Howe, suggesting that the salary of $90.00 a month for the seasonal schools at Fort McLeod and Takla is too low. He points out that the teachers are usually secured in Edmonton and transportation from Edmonton to the points mentioned is approximately $75.00. He suggests that we pay the travelling expenses.

However, before replying to Indian Agent Howe, I would like to hear from you regarding what amount you consider would be reasonable for these teachers. With reference to the appointment of teachers for the Fort McLeod and Takla Seasonal Schools for the 1945 school season. It is extremely difficult to secure teachers at the salary rate of $90.00 per month.

In the past, some teachers have been obtained from Edmonton. Transportation costs from this point to Takla and Fort McLeod are in the neighborhood of $75.00 return. By the time the teachers pay board and lodging which is extremely higher in these remote areas there is very little of their salary left.

I would recommend that transportation costs to and from the schools be paid by the Department. May I be advised if this meets with approval so that I may be in a position to quote the exact salary to prospective candidates.

I wish to refer to your letter dated December 3rd, 1946, with respect to the suggestion of the Most Reverend A. Jordon, O.M.I., D.D., that the Seasonal School at Fort McLeod, B.C., might be operated on a full time basis in future.

Owing to the fact that this Band primarily derive their living from trapping and their more or less Nomadic habits, I was skeptical about a full time School at this Reserve. However, the parents have been consulted, and they are all in favour of the proposal. Therefore, I would recommend that the suggestion of the Right Reverend Bishop Jordon be carried out.

I would suggest that the 3 months Seasonal School term commencing about May 15th operate as usual, and if we are able to locate a full time teacher, the new full term could open Sept. 1st. In event that the Department approves, may I be advised at the earliest convenience so that we have ample time to locate a teacher, also, will the department advise as to salary and allowances for a full time teacher.

The present School building is inadequate and unsuitable for a permanent full time purpose. I would suggest that consideration be given to building a new School during the next fiscal year. An item of $2,200.00 was included in the 1947-48 estimates for this purpose. There are some good axemen amongst this Band capable of constructing a suitable log building. It will not be necessary to provide teacher's quarters, as I am confident lodging can be obtained from the Hudson's Bay Co. Post.

Dear Mr. Bruinsma:

We have received your letter of January 7. A teaching month consists of twenty-one days only because you are expected to teach twenty-one days (more or less) of the thirty or thirty-one days in a calendar month.

This means that you are free from teaching duties or responsibilities for the Saturday and Sunday of each week.

Your salary, however, covers the period from the first day of each month up to the thirty-first day of each month and was at the rate previously specified, namely, $155.00 a teaching month. In other words, your salary covers thirty-one days, but you are only required to teach for twenty-one days (more or less - depending on the number of Saturdays, Sundays and holidays in the month).

This misunderstanding has arisen with you because of the vocabulary in common use in all schools. If you had taken any Normal School training, the matter would be quite clear as we follow what is common practice in all provincial Departments of Education.

REMARKS (cont.)

Reading - is, I think, better this year than it has ever been. The boys in Group 3 and the girl (even though she still does not read as well as the boys) are showing much more intelligence in this line. This is reflected also in a better grasp of phonetic values (something which has generally been very very hazy heretofore) and in an ability to do simple arithmetic problems, and in a better attempt at sentence construction. Group 2 is also showing a greater enthusiasm and a better grasp of the subject, although not so far advanced as the other group.

As to texts, I mentioned last year my conviction as to the need for texts more adapted to their primitive life in order that they might gain the necessary facility in reading which they need to read more advanced material. I am still convinced of this, but nevertheless, the new Primer "Happy Days" is, in my opinion, a vast improvement over either of the former Corona Primers I or II, and I have experienced much less difficulty in getting them to understand this Primer.

Spelling and sentence construction are improving gradually with the older children (the spelling of these Indian is generally atrocious since they spell, naturally, by ear - and the sounds in their own language are very different from those of English, which latter language they speak as if it were Sekenais - and the sentence construction tends to be even worse, for the same reason).

Arithmetic, as usual, is quite satisfactory except in the case of one boy in Group 2 who is still floundering quite hopelessly. But the others, both Group 2 and 3 are very good. And this year 7 of them are doing simple problems very well. The Arithmetic involved in these problems is, of course, very simple, but I use them rather as an exercise in understanding and sentence construction - and I think it has been quite successful. Group 1 is just beginning, and next summer some of them will be doing simple Arithmetic - and the others will still be beginning.

All of the foregoing still excludes the perennial Group 1er Leon n'Yallie who is still as much a problem as ever. After 5 summers or so of schooling he is very little, if any, ahead of two of the children who started this summer - even his knowledge of English still is exceedingly sketchy. He needs, I suppose, a psychologist to teach him. His physical development, however, parallels his mental development - so I gather that there must be some constitutional defect.

Writing is never much of a problem since they love to write and scribble all over everything. They thus develop a remarkably good hand in comparison with white children who would be ahead of them in other lines.
McLeod's Lake July 19 - Aug.18, 1941

Cleanliness - in general has certainly greatly improved since the school was opened. Some of the younger children are still hard to convince - but on the other hand two of the new children (only 6 years old) have been remarkably clean right from the first day of school. It is noticeable that some of the families in the village look upon 'reasonable' cleanliness as a virtue. And then of course there are others. And with all the young children the case for cleanliness is not quite hopeless since they all love to swim - even the little girls.

This summer a school garden was attempted. And, consider the fact that everything was planted in almost pure dry sand, it has been remarkably successful. We planted flowers around the school building and a vegetable garden a few yards away. The planting was late since the school starts after the 15th of May but, for purposes of experience in gardening for the children, this made no difference at all. We also attempted a little beautifying with some rock-bordered paths down to the lake shore, and with ploughing the reclaimed wilderness that served as a playground for planting to grass. The results of this schooling in practical and not so practical gardening are still in the future - and time alone will tell if they have learned these lessons well enough to put them into practice. I think, though, that if this angle is followed up and emphasized sufficiently, the time and effort will not be wasted. At any rate this summer they have learned how to spade (and even plough), prepare the ground for planting, plant, weed, transplant, and keep the garden watered. With sufficient repetition and more practice - who knows - perhaps they might absorb some enthusiasm.

George Connach
improvement along this line. In general however their knowledge of English has improved greatly since the school was opened. I have noticed too that the younger children of a family know a certain amount of English when they start to school, indicating that the children who do go to school speak more English in the home than was formerly the case. This was especially so in the case of Pat n'Yallie who quite surprised me by the amount of English that she knew when she arrived at school for the first time - and when she had recovered from her first shyness.

Cleanliness is still the problem it has always been, the older boys being quite used to the idea, the younger children requiring the threat of sanctions. In this connection though, a great deal depends upon 'which side of the tracks' they come from - so that I have noticed in the case of several families, even the youngsters of pre-school age are kept remarkably neat and tidy, while with other families it is completely the opposite.
REMARKS (cont.)

Reading is improving generally, especially when a little more emphasis is placed on phonics. The pupils in Groups 2 and 3 are all improving, except Walter Solonas who is lacking somewhat in ambition in this field, and those in Group 1 who have just started school will, I have no doubt, advance very quickly next summer.

Their comprehension of what they read is improving also since I have been insisting on this before they go on to read further. This has, perhaps, the effect of slowing them down but I think that they are now grasping the idea that reading is more than just saying the words. In this connection however, they are up against great obstacles because of the matter to be read. The experience of these people in northern B.C. is very limited - and what they have learned about white customs and life has come mostly from trappers, prospectors and traders. Thus when they must learn to read from books which, in content, style and thought, are meant for white children, they are handicapped tremendously. A beginning at overcoming this has been made with the Pre-Primer "Two Little Indians", but apparently there are no other books so designed especially for Indian children. It seems to me that if these northern Indians are ever to take the intelligent interest in affairs which is to be desired, then the children should be taught that reading is one of the main keys to this active interest. The danger, at present, is that they might very easily learn to read and write without in the least realizing that these arts are of any value beyond the perennial writing of letters. In reading such books as deal with things familiar to every white child but almost incomprehensible to the Indian, it is very hard to make them realize that the story is telling them something, and that there is anything on the page beyond a mere jungle of words. I believe that these children should learn to read intelligently from books designed in every way solely for them.

Arithmetic is in every stage, from two of the new pupils who are still learning counting and simple addition to those who are doing multiplication and division and simple problems. Here again problem work is hampered by a lack of understanding.

Writing is generally very good under the circumstances but anything in the way of composition or sentence structure is very primitive. Several of the boys, however, are improving along this line. Here too, readers constructed with the Indian children in mind would aid in giving them models to imitate so that they would have a better chance of escaping from their very primitive idiom in which they express themselves.

Religious knowledge has been fairly well absorbed and prayers learned well.

Cleanliness - as usual - not very permanent in the younger children, but apparently appreciated and adhered to by the girls and the older boys.

**REMARKS AS TO PROGRESS, ETC.**

Holidays during quarter and reasons therefor:

- **May 22**: Ascension Thursday
- **June 9**: King's Birthday

Discharged - Harvey Isidore was not admitted to school this year since he seems to be a T.B.

Progress -

Group 1 - The two new pupils and two old ones. Of the former, Patricia n'Yallie promises to make excellent progress, while the other is too young and knows so little English that he cannot necessarily be slow. Of the latter, Edward Schmitt made last year signs of absorbing a little knowledge and may be presumed to advance more quickly than heretofore, while n'Yallie (Benoit) Lena has not yet seen a slight awakening of intelligence, but very slight.

Group 2 - The two girls who have been at school since it started and whose reading facility is improving but slowly, but whose ability in Arithmetic is unsatisfactory. One of them also started last year and whose chief difficulty is in learning what she learned before coming to school, but who is making satisfactory progress especially in Reading. Also two of the younger boys, Mack Taylie and Maurice n'Yallie who are doing much better than last year in every way.

Group 3 - Consisting of the older boys and one of the younger ones. This last one, although beginning School after the Others, reads and writes letters remarkably well but is not so remarkable, although not satisfactory, in Arithmetic. Allen n'Yallie reads with great ease but is very slow in Arithmetic. The other three are very good at numbers but just plod along in their reading.

Most of the children write very well, but any composition attempted is necessarily primitive in thought and phrasing. With some though, especially the boys I can effect some...

Ottawa, May 4, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th ultimo, regarding the establishment of a summer school for the benefit of the Indian children at Fort McLeod and enclosing the applications which you received for the position as teacher.

In reply I have to say the Department will approve of this school being conducted for a three month period during the coming summer, from, approximately, June 16th to September 15th, next.

Approval is also granted for the appointment of Mr. George N. Cormack, St. Joseph's Seminary, Edmonton, as teacher. He was nominated by the Roman Catholic Church authorities. The salary allowed him during the period the school is in operation will be at the rate of $90 per teaching month.

A requisition has been forwarded to the Government Stationery Office to forward, addressed to you, the supply of classroom material considered necessary. You should arrange to have this forwarded to Fort McLeod, in due time.

With reference to the request that the Department make an advance of $25 towards the cost of supplies while the teacher makes the journey into the school and a like amount on his return, I have to say that the amount provided for salary is all we can allow. Present regulations do not permit making advances or payment of any part of the cost of transportation of teachers to and from a school.

Please advise the church authorities and Mr. Cormack of his appointment and arrange that he arrive at Fort McLeod in time to commence duties on the date above mentioned. The teacher should prepare and forward a return, showing attendance, days taught, etc., at the end of each month, when cheque in payment of salary due will be sent.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

R. H. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof, B. C.

It seems hard for me to get a list of just what articles of school equipment is required for each of these schools, and I feel as if it would be better to leave the matter in the hands of the Department entirely, with the request that you please send me here a shipment of supplies necessary for the Fort Grahame School with approximately 50 pupils, and for the School at Fort McLeod with approximately 30 or 35 pupils. In making them up, please understand that practically all the pupils in each place will be beginners and consequently will not require any advanced books, etc. I would suggest that slates and pencils be sent if possible, as well as scribblers, etc. Pens and ink will not be required for this year at least. If you could attend to this part of it for me at Ottawa, I would appreciate a list of what you do send.

Ottawa, March 9th, 1948.

Dear Mr. Howe:

We are endeavouring to send in supplies for seasonal schools well ahead of time so that the Indian Agents concerned will have them on hand before the teachers report for duty. I understand that supplies have already gone forward to you for the Fort McLeod and North Takla Seasonal Schools.

On your requisition of November 21st, you refer to the "McLeod Lake Seasonal School" at the top of the requisition and then at the bottom to the "North Takla Seasonal School". It is presumed that this is the school to which we refer as the "Fort McLeod Seasonal School" and is an entirely separate school from the Takla Landing Seasonal School.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mr. R. Howe,
Indian Agent,
Vanderhoof, B.C.
Department of Mines & Resources, Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: your file F.163-12-4(E)
Seasonal Schools.

I wish to refer to your letter dated March 9th, 1948, having reference to my requisition of November 21st for School material which was headed at the top - "McLeod Lake Seasonal School" and at the bottom "North Takla Seasonal School."

The requisition was actually for the Fort McLeod Seasonal School. However, we have recently received supplies for both Seasonal Schools above referred to, therefore, please cancel my requisition of November 21st last.

Dear Sir:

I have the honour to forward my report on an Educational Survey of the situation at Quatsino, Kwawkewlth Agency.

You will see from my report that I did not consider it necessary to go to Quatsino, as I had suggested to you I might do, it being very difficult to arrange for such a trip owing to the break down of the engine of the Department's launch, "Oikumi". It was easy to obtain all the necessary details from the Agency records, and I had the help of the Indian Agent, Mr. M.S.Todd. Mr Todd would have found it difficult to arrange to be with me had I decided to go to Quatsino, as he was engaged on other Departmental business.

A copy of my survey report is being sent to Mr. Indian Agent Todd, MARKED CONFIDENTIAL, as he was so closely identified with me in making this investigation.

Your obedient servant,

Gerald H. Perry,
District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Investigation:

The facts brought out in this Survey Report were obtained while at Alert Bay on other Departmental business. No expense of any sort was incurred in carrying out this brief survey of conditions and needs at Quatsino. My investigation took the form of a conference with the Indian Agent, Mr. M.S. Todd, who was able to supply the required information from his records.

I did not consider that it was necessary to proceed to Quatsino as this trip would have cost more in time and money than it could possibly be worth. Other factors also had to be taken into consideration, such as the break down in the engine of the Department's launch "Gikumii", and the fact that the Indian Agent was very busy. I came to the conclusion that it would be better to visit the school when this had been established.

This survey was undertaken with reference to the facts reported by Mr. Indian Agent Todd in his letter of October 30th 1924, the last paragraph in particular, and the second paragraph of your letter 3/78462 addressed to Mr. Todd on February 6th 1925.

General:

The Anglican Church has lately erected a Church at the village of KOKKEMO, and it is proposed to establish an Indian Day School in this building.

I understand from Mr. Indian Agent Todd that the Department of Indian Affairs has sanctioned the establishment of such a school, and that an item has been inserted in the 1925-26 Estimates of the Department to cover the salary of a teacher here as well as the provision of the necessary school desks, blackboards, text books and other necessary requirements.

I am assured by Mr. Indian Agent Todd that this Quatsino area is an Anglican Mission and not as I had believed a United Church territory.

Children:

The list of Indian children for whom a school is desired is given on the next page of this survey. It will be seen from this list of thirteen boys and five girls, who would in the ordinary course of things attend school if one were established at Kokkemo, three boys and two girls are now attending the St. Michael's Indian Residential School, Alert Bay. It will be seen from my recommendation that only two of the five children now attending the Residential School be permitted to remain there after the Day School is established, these two being the sons of the two Chiefs. We would have to recommendations are carried out at least sixteen children to start this new Day School and as I understand that the Indians are anxious for education, it may be that we could get an average attendance of nearly fifteen. This would seem to me to be sufficient in this case as the Anglican Church is available for school purposes.

The question of a teacher is taken up in a later paragraph of this report.

There are shown above thirteen boys and six girls, but of these there are at present three boys and two girls attending the St. Michael's Indian Residential School. I would recommend that Moses Johnny and John Charlie be permitted to continue their education at St. Michael's as they may be Chiefs' Later but that the three other children present at St. Michael's (two girls and a boy) attend the Day School when this is established.

This is also the wish of the Indian Agent.
It is very necessary that a well qualified and experienced teacher be chosen to open this school should it be decided to establish one at Koskemo.

It would be possible for a teacher to live in Quatsino, just half a mile away from the location of the school. There would be no difficulty, I understand, in finding a suitable boarding place.

Mr. Indian Agent Todd and I agree that it would be much better to obtain the services of a married teacher if this were possible. I hope that it may be possible for the Department to authorize the purchase of the necessary lumber locally so that a small teacher's residence, quite a small one is all that is necessary, could be erected near the proposed school and on the Indian Reserve. The Indian Agent and I agree after a discussion on the matter that it would be far better to have such a married couple amongst the Indians rather than living away from the Reserve, so that one could help in the case of the ordinary illness of any of the Indians and could dispense the simple drugs as a rule supplied to out of the way schools by the Department.

Such a small teacher's residence might be constructed by the Indians under supervision.

I should like to suggest that if this school is authorized, and the other recommendations of the Indian Agent and myself meet with the approval of the Department, the present teachers at the Lakelsap Indian Day School, Skeena River Agency, Mr. and Mrs. John Heyhurst be given the opportunity to transfer to the proposed Koskemo Indian Day School.

Mrs. Heyhurst has I understand proved a great success as a teacher at the Lakelsap Day School, I am to inspect this school in May, and Mr. J. Heyhurst has also been a success with the boys and young men of the village. They also have been able to dispense the ordinary simple drugs supplied to them.

While Mr. and Mrs. Heyhurst do not wish to resign their positions at the Lakelsap School or to sever their connection with the educational work of the Department of Indian Affairs, they have asked me to consider them as applicants for a transfer to another Indian Day School working under Anglican auspices should such a school become vacant.

Mr. John Heyhurst being by profession a Contractor and Builder, would be well suited to supervise the construction of a small teacher's cottage, should this be decided on at Koskemo. Their only reason for wishing for a transfer is that the Nass River climate does not suit their little five year old daughter.

I should be very glad to see the above transfer made though the salary paid at the proposed Koskemo Indian Day School would of course be less than that now paid to the Heyhursts.

The whole of the above is submitted with respect for the information of the Department.

Gerald H. Barry,
District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, in further reference to the establishment of a day school at Quatsino.

In reply I have to say that, in view of your report, the Department has given favourable consideration to providing the funds required to fit up a classroom and to pay the salary of a teacher. It is noted, from your letter, that a teacher's salary and classroom equipment would not cost more than $1,100. It is noted, further, from the report on the survey made by Mr. Inspector Barry of the situation at Quatsino, that the Anglican Church, who lately erected a church building in the village of Kasikemo, would allow this building to be used for classroom purposes. The Department is informed that there would be at least 16 children who could attend when the school is opened.

I have to request, therefore, that you will state what equipment is necessary to fit up the classroom in the church building, giving particulars regarding any desks required, the size of same and the number of each size, also dimensions - length and width - of any blackboard required.

The Department will provide salary for a teacher as from September first, next, the beginning of the new school year. I may add that, while no appropriation was specially provided to meet the expense in establishing the school and for teacher's salary, it has been found possible to arrange for the funds from our general appropriation for Indian Education.

At a later date, you might take up with the authorities of the Anglican Church, under whose auspices the school will be conducted, the matter of nominating a qualified teacher; and, in due time, you should forward the name, qualifications and experience of the teacher nominated. If a fully qualified teacher is obtained, we would be prepared to allow salary at the rate of $90 per teaching month.

Your reply, giving full information as to the desks and other equipment required, will be appreciated, in order that the classroom will be ready by the date above mentioned. It is noted that the teacher could obtain living accommodation in the white village at Quatsino.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Your letter dated May 4th, No.156-36-1 in reference to the proposed Indian Day School being established at Quatsino has been received, and I am sorry to learn the Department feel nothing can be done this year. It might be as well for me to review the circumstances leading up to this request for a school.

On my first visit to Quatsino after taking over the Agency I discovered very little had been done for the Indians of this place. Their living conditions were deplorable and practically none of the children had ever been to school, with the result they were growing up uneducated and living in an unfortunate state. I undertook to help these particular Indians but felt before the Department could do much to assist them the first step would be the amalgamation of the bands in order that we could establish them in one village. This matter was discussed with them and explained thoroughly, after which the Indians responded to my wishes and the amalgamation took place, and was approved by the Department.

At that time I promised to undertake to get a Day School established at their village providing they would amalgamate as there were not sufficient children to warrant it otherwise. The amalgamation took place and with a building now provided which could be used for that purpose, I feel an effort should be made if at all possible to open a school there this year. A teacher's salary and classroom equipment should not cost more than $100.00. If necessary we could get a local teacher who could live at the white village at Quatsino for this year. It is my plan to eventually have a teacherage erected there where we could employ a married man who would live right on the reserve; his presence I am sure would be the means of improving conditions in this village.

When the 1935 Estimates were being prepared the Department stated it was not necessary to include educational requirements for the year, but Supplementary List showing school requirements was forwarded to Mr. G.O. Perry, Assistant Commissioner at Victoria, and I was under the impression he had forwarded the same to Ottawa, but evidently this was not done. I do not want the Indians to feel we are letting them down, and if the Department could reconsider their decision it would be appreciated very much.

Your obedient servant,

Synopsis of Memorandum to Council of May 25th, 1935.

A number of small Bands of Indians were recently amalgamated at Quatsino, Kwawkewlth Agency, B.C. There are 20 Indian children of school age, the majority of whom have never attended school and for whom no educational facilities are provided. It is intended to fit up a classroom in the Anglican Church building and engage a teacher's services. The local Indian Agent, the Inspector of Indian Schools and the authorities of the Church of England in Canada, under whose auspices the school will be conducted, have strongly urged the establishment of day school facilities. Funds to provide for the fitting up of the classroom and for the payment of teacher's salary are available in our Estimates for the current fiscal year.
Sir,

His Lordship Bishop Schofield has recommended Mr. Edward A. Hill-Tout of 1115 Collinson Street, Victoria, B.C., for the position of Indian Day School teacher in our new school at Quatsino which is to be opened on September 1st. While in Victoria recently Bishop Schofield discussed with Mr. Hill-Tout's application, and requested me to forward it to the Department for their approval. I am therefore enclosing herewith copy of this application for the Department's consideration, and would request you to advise me if it is approved.

I think I should inform the Department in my opinion it is necessary to appoint a man teacher to this position for the present, as it will be necessary for him to board at the white village of Quatsino, some half mile distant which will necessitate rowing back and forth from his boarding house to the school.

Personally I would prefer to have a married man and his wife living on the reserve, but as we have no teacherage there at present this will be impossible for the time being.

The Indians have presented me with the enclosed picture of their new Church at Quatsino which we are going to use for a school and which was built entirely by Indian labour. As this is the only picture I have, could you be good enough to return it to me at your convenience.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I beg to make application for the position of teacher of the Quatsino Indian School. I am a graduate of the Victoria Normal School, holding a first-class interim certificate, with the additional credit of the second year at the Victoria College. I have also registered for the summer School course, and I intend taking the Primary Grade Course and the Rural School Problems Course.

I have been Signalling Instructor in the Boy Scouts and I am now a member of the 11th. C.M.G.C., here at Victoria. During the last year and a half I have been doing tutoring of public and high school subjects, and have been teaching Sunday School to Grade 5 boys.

My interests in sports lie along the line of tennis, baseball, basketball and football. I am interested in music, both vocal and instrumental, and in amateur dramatics.

I have seen Captain Barry at his office here and he mentioned that it would be advantageous to have a teacher's residence on the reserve, and that the pupils might help in its construction. I feel capable to supervise the building of such a residence; and I have had training with my father, who is an interior decorator and painter, besides a technical course at the Victoria High School.

I will be twenty years old in September of this year, and stand about five feet six inches tall, and weigh 132 lbs.

I have had an interview with the Bishop of Columbia on this matter, and lacking his recommendation which I had hoped to get, he said that he would be quite willing for me to have the position.

If I am appointed to the position, I shall give you my very best services.

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir,

Acknowledging your letter dated October 20th, in reference to the establishment of an Indian Day School at Quatsino Sound, I beg to advise this matter has been contemplated by this office, but no action has been taken as yet.

I might state certain steps are being taken for the eventual amalgamation of all the bands on Quatsino Sound, with a central village at the location where the Church is now being erected by the Diocese of Columbia, and when this is done the Department will be approached with a view to establishing a Day School at this point, having already received the consent of the Church to use the Church as a school building.

I am enclosing a copy of my reply to Mr. Neill's letter, and would kindly ask the Department to deal with the matter if approached by Mr. Neill at Ottawa, as I do not consider correspondence of this nature should be directed to this office.

Sir,

The enclosed copy of letter received from Mr. A.W. Neill, M.P., dated Ottawa May 4th, 1936, has been received and I am enclosing the same with copies of all correspondence in connection with the establishment of the Indian Day School at Quatsino and the appointment of a teacher to that position which were received from Mr. Neill and my replies thereto.

I am also enclosing, for the Department's information and attention, copy of letter received from Mr. George Nordstrom, applicant for the position of teacher at the Quatsino Indian Day School and my reply to him.

Shortly after Mr. Nordstrom's application had been received I was in Victoria and His Lordship Bishop Schofield communicated with me requesting to see me on some matters pertaining to our Schools. His Lordship advised me the Rev. Mr. Govier of Port Alice had been in communication with him in reference to Mr. Nordstrom's application and stated he was in favour of a local man being employed, however when he had learned of Mr. Nordstrom's qualifications he hardly felt Mr. Nordstrom was the man for the position.

Later His Lordship recommended our present teacher for the position, which recommendation was forwarded the Department for their approval and under date of August 16th the Department advised me they had approved of Mr. Hill-Tout's nomination by the Bishop, at which time this office notified Mr. Hill-Tout to report for duty on September 3rd.

In my reply to Mr. Neill's letter dated August 10th written on August 14th, I mentioned Mr. Nordstrom's application was not found to have sufficient qualifications to warrant our School Inspector and the Church to recommend his appointment to the position. For the Department's confidential information, I quote from a letter received from Inspector Barry regarding the appointment of a teacher for the Quatsino Indian Day School as follows:

"With regard to a teacher, I may say that I have made the usual confidential investigation with regard to the candidate you mention, Mr. George Nordstrom. In confidence for your information and if necessary for the information of the Department of Indian Affairs in Ottawa, I may say that I could not possibly recommend that he be engaged even for one year as teacher at Quatsino. The only record that we could discover was that he had been granted a THIRD CLASS CERTIFICATE or PERMIT in 1901. This was before there was a Normal School in B.C. There is no record, as far as I could find that he has ever had any professional training either at a Normal School or at a Provincial Summer School. As his Permit does not appear to have ever been made permanent, I do not understand how he can have any certificate at the present time."
In addition I would draw your attention to the fact that this man was given his Temporary (?) Permit or Third Class Certificate in the year 1901 as shown on the records in the Department of Education. Even if he were only just out of High School then and there is nothing to show his age, he would be well over fifty now. I expect that you will find that he is older than this. Now, as you of course know quite well, a man of this age who has not been teaching for many years and whose original training is to say the least of it quite doubtful, would be quite useless to us in establishing a modern Indian Day School.

"There are a large number of teachers with First Class B.C. Certificates out of work and many of them are Anglicans with good Church recommendations. I would be most careful in making a recommendation to the Department that a teacher be appointed to your new school.

"I hope that you will consider this letter CONFIDENTIAL. I do not believe that it is any use whatever starting an Indian Day School at Utsalino if we are to appoint untrained and obviously quite unsuitable people to teach it."

I am presuming in view of the above, that His Lordship Bishop Schofield could not conscientiously entertain Mr. Nordstrom's application, and it was through this that Mr. Nordstrom's application was not successful.

This is all the information which I have, and I would appreciate, if Mr. Neill calls upon the Department, that they endeavour to explain the matter satisfactorily to him. As far as this office was concerned it was a matter entirely in the Bishop's hands as far as the appointment was concerned, and I might add I did not know the present teacher until after the nomination was made.

Your obedient servant,

M. S. (signature)

Sir,

Two years ago the Department opened a new Day School at Quatsino for the Quatsino Band of Indians, and at that time I recommended and included in my Estimates sufficient funds to build a teacherage on this reserve, having in mind that a married man would be most suitable for this particular school and location. However this matter was left in abeyance as a single teacher was appointed and he was able to board in the white village of Quatsino.

Since that time we have come to the conclusion it is very essential in the interests of this school and the Indians on this reserve that a married man be employed as teacher, and live on the reserve. I have recently been advised by our present teacher that he intends to resign at the end of the present school term, and I am herewith recommending to the Department that sufficient funds be provided in the 1937-38 Estimates for the purpose of building a teacherage on this reserve. There are no buildings available within reach of the school that could be used, and as the weather is very bad there it is impossible for the teacher to live any distance from the school.

We also feel the teacher's presence on the reserve is very desirable for many reasons, and I would appreciate if you would give this matter your consideration and approve of the recommendation.

I would suggest that you discuss the matter with Mr. School Inspector Barry, as he is familiar with our difficulty there and can give you first-hand information as to our problems in that connection.

I would request that fifteen hundred dollars be included in the Estimates for the erection of a teacherage, and would ask that it be included in the 1937-38 Estimates so that it may be built and ready for occupancy when the new school term opens on September 1st, 1937, and a new teacher is appointed to this school.
