Sir,

Recently we have experienced some difficulty with our Day School at Quatsino, and it was necessary for me to make a hurried trip there to have the matter straightened out, which I am pleased to advise the Department was cleared up satisfactorily.

While there, the teacher informed me he intends to resign at the end of the present school year, and in view of his pending resignation and the difficulties we have experienced during the past two years through a teacher not living on the reserve, we are now making a report to the Department together with recommendations.

The Quatsino Band has never had very much done for them towards improving conditions at their village and when the Department established a school on this reserve it was my opinion if a married man could be employed to live on the reserve and make his home there, it would be a solution to our difficulty, and would do a great deal towards helping the Indians, not only from the school point of view but for other reasons as well. This tribe is very keen to respond to assistance, but although I have done everything I can during the past three years to assist them and encourage them, nevertheless it is very evident until they have someone to live on the reserve and set the example, we shall never get conditions on this reserve improved as they should be. I feel the only solution is to have a married man employed as teacher of the Day School to live on the reserve.

I had hoped this could be done when the school was first established, and that the Department would build a teacherage on the reserve at that time, but as a single man was appointed who was able to obtain board at the white village about a mile distant, the matter of the teacherage was left in abeyance. However, now that the present teacher is resigning, and a new one will have to be appointed, I am bringing this matter to the Department's attention.

I am therefore requesting the Department to include in my 1937-38 Estimates sufficient funds to build a small teacherage on this reserve, which could be built and ready for occupancy by September 1st next when the new school term opens. I feel fifteen hundred dollars would be sufficient although as this is an isolated location it will cost more to erect the building than it would elsewhere. It would be my intention to erect a small building of four rooms sufficiently large to accommodate a married man and his wife, and would be pleased to submit suitable plans if the Department so desired.
I can see no other way out than to build a teacherage if we are to carry on at Quatsino satisfactorily and at the same time clear up our other problems which we are faced with, and I would appreciate if the Department would kindly include this in our Estimates.

I have today taken the matter up with Mr. D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C. at Victoria, and enclose herewith copy of my letter to him.

Your obedient servant,

(M.S. Todd)
Indian Agent

On December 3rd I received a wire from Mr. E. Hill-tout, teacher of the Quatsino Indian Day School, submitting his resignation, requesting that it take effect immediately. Upon receipt of this wire I communicated with him by long-distance telephone and advised him I would proceed there immediately to look into his difficulties. Sir,

I am just in receipt of Inspector Barry's reports on his recent inspection of several Indian Schools in this Agency, and it is regrettable that I find it necessary to correct misstatements he has made in his reports in respect to one or two schools.

It is noted in his report on the Quatsino Indian Day School on Page 2, second to the last paragraph, he states as follows:

"I am very sorry to learn from the teacher that two boys whose ages are a little over 15 years were expelled from the school on January 27th 1938 by the Indian Agent without any reference to me and without any report on the matter. These boys apparently refused to do their school work. These boys were Moses Johnny and Phil Johnson. The fact that boys can get out of going to school by refusing to either behave themselves or do their work is a very bad precedent here. I could have suggested a very different solution had I been consulted before definite action was taken."

First let me say I did not expel these boys from school nor did I instruct the teacher to do so. On April 29th last I visited this school and asked the teacher if he made this statement to Captain Barry, and he told me he had not. I asked him what he did tell the Inspector, and he informed me he advised Inspector Barry he was having trouble with these two boys not attending school regularly and that when I had visited the school on or about January 27th last he had mentioned it to me that they were absent from school at that time but no action had been taken owing to the boys continually giving trouble in the school and that they were nearing the age of graduation.

The teacher also informed me he had mentioned to Captain Barry having similar trouble with the boys when the Inspector had made his previous inspection, but at that time the Inspector had offered no solution to the difficulty.

Inspector Barry's remarks are also noted in reference to accommodation for the new teacher. He states in the second paragraph of Page 3 that the teacher does not live in the village but has rooms in Quatsino and comes to the school daily in a small boat and also there would be no difficulty in finding a suitable place for a married man and his wife to live in Quatsino.
For the Department's information, the present teacher found it very difficult in going from the Quatsino white village to the reserve each day to hold school on account of the rough waters in that particular place, and later in order to be closer to the school has lived in a tent for over two years about half a mile from the school.

It is my contention and honest belief that the Department should erect a small teacherage on the reserve as the present teacher has found it impossible through storms to get to the school and some time has been lost through this.

I agree with Captain Barry that a married man and his wife is what is needed at Quatsino. This village is one of the dirtiest and unkept in my whole Agency, and as these Indians have considerable money in their Capital and Interest Account which they intend to use for the improvement of the village, they need someone living there continuously to assist them and bring about better living and moral conditions. This is a great opportunity for the Department to help these Indians by putting a married man and his wife there in a small teacherage.

I have asked in my Estimates for funds for three years to build a small teacherage, and while I am aware the Department do not own the school building nevertheless if a suitable married man was living in the village it would go a long way towards cleaning up the problem we have on our hands. Even if the school were closed in years to come, which I do not anticipate, it would pay the Department to build a teacherage there now and then give the building to the Indians if it was of no further use to us.

I hope the Department will see their way clear to build this teacherage this year if a married man is appointed to this position. I can understand Captain Barry's views are only from an educational point of view and that he does not understand the many other angles which enter into recommendations I make in the matter of spending public funds.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent

There is, as the Department is no doubt aware, a very great shortage of qualified teachers in B.C. and it is almost impossible to find candidates for the vacancies still existing in the Indian Day Schools. Mrs. McCorriston is the daughter of Dr. Dunn of Massett and is a well-educated girl, having passed her Senior Matriculation in Prince Rupert in 1931. Her influence in the Quatsino Reserve would no doubt be extremely good. She wishes to teach as a war time activity during her husband's absence overseas.

Mrs. McCorriston is well known to Inspector Barry who considers that although she has not had much actual teaching experience in Provincial schools, she is the type of girl who ought to be quite successful at Quatsino. He suggests that the Departmental regulations with regard to the employment of married women be waived in this case under present war time conditions and lack of teachers but that the appointment, if made, be of a temporary nature.

Sir,

I have received a special request from Mrs. E.L. McCorriston, teacher of the Quatsino Indian Day School, to have her school close on December 13th next for Christmas vacation instead of December 20th, the regulation date.

Mrs. McCorriston's husband, who is on active service in Eastern Canada, has been granted two weeks' furlough starting December 13th, and she wishes to be able to spend the holiday with her husband before he proceeds overseas. Mrs. McCorriston is now teaching each Saturday and will continue to hold school on Saturday until the full number of days have been made up with the hope that the Department will approve of her request.

I realize this is unusual procedure, but in view of the circumstances, which may be the last opportunity she will have to see her husband before he proceeds overseas, I would strongly recommend that the Department grant this request so that her holiday could start on December 13th next.

I might add Mrs. McCorriston has so far been very successful in her work at Quatsino, and I would appreciate very much if the Department would do this for her as I am anxious to cooperate with her in every way possible.

Would the Department kindly wire me advising if her request may be granted, as mail service to Quatsino is rather intermittent and she would like to make her plans in advance.

Re: Quatsino Indian Day School

The above mentioned school has no provision for teacher accommodation and the only available building which might be used for such a purpose is in the white community across the bay from the reservation. The teacher, Mrs. Mary Hawkes, who has recently been appointed, is buying a small boat to enable her to travel back and forth daily. It is felt therefore that an allowance should be made to Mrs. Hawkes towards the rental of a teacherage, plus fuel allowance. It is recommended that a grant of £25.00 a month be approved for this. The building will be furnished by the teacher.

An item will be included in the 1930-31 estimates for a teacherage on the reservation and should the attendance warrant the school's continued operation we will recommend the construction of this building.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Ottawa, August 3, 1935.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department is approving of the appointment of Miss Helen Earl as teacher of the new school which is to be established for the benefit of the Indian children of the Campbell River Indian reserve. Miss Earl has had long experience as a teacher, under the direction of the Department and the Church. The school will be conducted under the auspices of the United Church of Canada, who nominated the services of Miss Earl.

At the present time, the Department is not aware when the school will be completed and ready for occupation, but Miss Earl will take charge when the classroom is ready. I would request that you give her every assistance you can in her work at this school. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $85.00 per teaching month.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Attached please find tender received from Mr. Robert E. Yeatman of Campbell River, B. C., in connection with Campbell River Indian Day School Teachorage amounting to $237.60. It was the Department's intention to have the teachorage site cleared of stumps and second growth last year but due to our inability to obtain any one to do the work it was not done. The location was not cleared at the time the teachorage was built other than the needed spot where the building was located. I am recommending that this work be approved and Mr. Yeatman's tender of $84.00 be accepted.

On my last visit to Campbell River Mr. Yeatman informed me the teachorage was so cold last winter it was almost impossible to live in the building. Last year we insulated the ceiling of the teachorage, the front room and kitchen, but the walls of the bedroom, bathroom, front and hall were not undertaken. It is these rooms that is making the teachorage so cold. In addition to this it is necessary to build some cupboards which should have been provided when the teachorage was built. The painting of these rooms is also necessary.

Mr. Yeatman has offered to provide all the materials, paint and labour and complete this work for $153.60 and I am recommending that the work be approved and Mr. Yeatman's tender accepted.

When this work is completed it will not be necessary to spend any more money on the interior of this teachorage for sometime as it should then be comfortable to live in. If funds are not available the amount of this tender $237.60 could be transferred from the Gilford Island Indian Day School appropriations.

(M. S. Todd)

To Dr. Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt General of Indian Affairs, OTTAWA

Sir,- We, the undersigned chief and head men of the Wewiakim Band of Indians located at Campbell River B.C. beg respectfully to ask that your Dept establish an Indian day school at Campbell River for the education of our children.

There are 18 children of school age now either on the reserve or at a boarding school and there will be several more eligible next fall.

Our reason for this request is that at present we have to send them to a boarding school at Chilliwack which is two days journey from here and a rather expensive trip. If our children get sick or die at school we have no chance to see them until it is too late. We do not know what goes on at a school so far away and have no chance to see our children except once or twice a year and after ten years our children are almost strangers to us.

The education of our children was guaranteed to us by the white Man's Govt. and we were not told that we had to lose our children during almost all their youth as they marry soon after leaving school. We were promised day schools adjacent to our reserves.

It is said that there is a day school at Cape Mudge which is only a few miles away but it is across water which is often dangerous for adults to cross let alone children.

It is said that day schools are not useful because the Indians move about so much. This is often the case but our women live here all the time and would keep up the home.

There are 80 of us all told in the band and a population of eighty white people always have a school and we have the same rights, have we not?

Please help us, Dr Scott.-

Replying to your letter No. 156-7-5 dated September 3rd in regard to the erection of the new Indian Day School at Campbell River, I beg to advise upon receipt of your letter I immediately proceeded to Campbell River.

Sir,

I am just in receipt of a letter from our Assistant Commissioner, Mr. C.C. Perry at Victoria, enclosing copy of a letter dated Ottawa, July 3rd, No. 156-7-8 in connection with the proposed Indian Day School at Campbell River, B.C.

It is noted the Department are requesting the Indians to donate a site of approximately one acre, and also request me to locate this site.

It appears to me we are not getting on very fast with the final arrangements for the erection of this school. A lot of correspondence and delay is taking place through matters being referred from this office to Mr. Perry, and from him back here again; I think either one of us should be appointed to look after the building of this school, it does not matter who, but the main thing is to get started on the building. Half of July is gone already and we only have six weeks left to complete the school if it is to be ready for the opening of the fall term, and unless we put it into one person's hands I cannot see how it is going to be ready for occupancy by September.

A few days ago I visited the reserve and located a site but owing to the Indians all being away fishing it was impossible to get enough together to hold a meeting to get a resolution passed for them to donate this land for school purposes. I have, however, seen most of the Indians and they have agreed to do this and as soon as I can get them together a meeting will be called and a resolution taken to this effect. It will not be necessary to compensate anyone for the location which we decided upon.

If the Department will advise me when they have decided to let the contract to start the building, I will proceed to Campbell River and show the contractor the exact location and position where the school is to be erected. I will look after and arrange to have the land set aside for school purposes but this cannot be done until the Indians return from their fishing grounds. I would suggest the Department immediately decide on the school they intend to build, let it by contract, to be completed by the end of August at the latest. If there is anything I can do to assist the Department in hurrying it along, I will be pleased to do so.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to Departmental letter No. 156-7-5, dated May 20th, ultimo, in regard to the proposed Indian Day School building and site at Campbell River, B.C.

I now beg to report that owing to the remoteness of this village from a convenient centre for obtaining supplies, I would recommend that the School be erected by contract.

In regard to the site, this has been tentatively chosen by arrangement between Agent Todd and the Indians. A copy of a letter dated June 21st received from the Agent is sent herewith and I would be glad to have the Department kindly refer to the concluding paragraph of my letter of 5th September, 1933, in which the matter of a site was referred to. I am anxious to avoid, if possible, the purchase of a site if we can get the Indians to allot a site for school purposes. A play-ground is not considered necessary as the area around the site is considerable. At the same time it is considered that some definite understanding should be had with the Indians and the Department's policy as to a School site of this kind determined so that no question may later arise either from Church or Indians as to the ownership of the site. Since the Department has not mentioned in its letter what are its wishes in regard to the method of acquiring the site, I consider it advisable to ascertain the views of the Department so that I may make suitable reply to the Agent's inquiries.

The blue-print mentioned by Agent Todd was not enclosed with his letter. Dear Sir,

As requested in your letter No. 15/6/39867 dated May 29th, I have been to Campbell River and accompanied by the Indians, decided on the location for the new Indian Day School.

There were two sites available, in my opinion the one out on the Spit a short distance from their cemetery was the more suitable, but the Indians felt they wanted it centrally located so that the children would not have so far to go to school, and we finally compromised and chose a site about seven or eight hundred feet along the Spit Road from the main entrance. There is a well close by which could be used, and I feel this site will be quite satisfactory.

You state in your letter, "With reference to the site, it is considered that the Indians should donate a site free of cost." We are not quite clear in regard to this and would appreciate if you would kindly advise the procedure to be followed in erecting a school on a reserve, whether it is necessary to have the site surveyed and a Surrender taken from the Indians so that the ownership of the property will remain with the Department and not with the Band concerned.

You requested to know my views as to whether the building should be erected by day labour or by contract; in view of the Indians now being away to the fishing grounds, and the necessity of having the school completed in time to start the new term on September 1st, I feel there is only one way to build the school and that is by contract. I am therefore enclosing the blueprint which Captain Barry very kindly gave me the last time I was in Victoria, and which I believe was used for the Indian Day School recently built near Victoria. I gather from the Department's letter you will be looking after this entirely, so I am enclosing these papers for your files.

Your obedient servant,

DR. MCGILL,

The Estimates for the current fiscal year provide the sum of $1,600 to erect a new school building on the Campbell River Indian Reserve, (No. II, Kwawkewlth Agency - Electoral District of Nanaimo) B.C.

I understand that the Architect prepared plans for a day school which was built on the Tsartlip reserve a few years ago, and these would be satisfactory for the school at Campbell River.

If a school is to be ready for classroom purposes at the beginning of the next school year, it will be necessary to have the contract for its erection let as soon as possible. Dear Sir:

Re-Indian Day School - Campbell River Band.

Further to my letter to you of the 21st instant referring to a petition received from A.W. Neill, Esq., M.P., from the Campbell River Indians asking that a Day School be built on their reserve, I beg to say I am now in receipt of a communication from Mr. Indian Agent Halliday pointing out that as a result of the census recently taken by him of the Indians of the Campbell River Band, it is shown that while there are 35 children on this reserve, 16 of this number are of ages ranging from 6 to 14 years of age. There are also a few children of 15 years and over who at present are attending the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School at Chilliwack. Agent Halliday and School Inspector Barry are both in favor of a Day School being established and in view of the fact that there is a sufficient number of children of school age to warrant a fair degree of attendance and also a considerable number coming up, I feel disposed to recommend that a school be established about the same size as that intended for the South Saanich Indians of the Cowichan Agency, the dimensions being 16' x 24'. The Architect of the Provincial Public Works Department has kindly furnished me with a stock plan used by the Educational Department in the construction of rural schools which cost in the vicinity of $1,000.00, and this would suit our purpose admirably for the future in cases of this kind. The dimensions can be increased according to the number of pupils to be taken care of.

A copy of the Petition referred to by Mr. Neill is attached hereto for your information. Upon perusal of the signatories to this petition it was found that besides those from Campbell River there were names of a number of Indians from Cape Mudge, Comox and Salmon River but this point is not important, the main point being that there are sufficient children on Campbell River Indian Reserve to warrant the construction of a Day School for them as set out in the petition. The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Canada.

For two (2) years I have made provision in my estimates for the re-decorating of the Campbell River Indian Day School, but owing to the shortage of labour and our inability to get someone to do this work, it was not possible to have it done. The labour situation is still acute.

Last winter while visiting the Campbell River school, Miss Hill, teacher, informed me she thought that she could get an Indian lady to wash the ceiling and walls; in fact, everything in the building, and if this were done it would make it possible for us to carry on for another year without having the building painted.

The building was built in 1935 and there has never been any decorating done since, with the result that it was filthy and not healthy for the children. When Miss Hill informed me of the availability of an Indian lady, I examined the walls and found the paint was in good shape, and that if we could wash the interior thoroughly, the school would be nice and clean.

I, therefore, took it upon myself and instructed Miss Hill to obtain the services of an Indian lady to have this work done and asked her to supervise the job. This was a large undertaking and meant scaffolding in order to reach the high ceiling. I told Miss Hill that the department would pay Twenty-Five Dollars ($25.00) to any Indian lady who would make a good job of it.

Gower was forwarded Ottawa, and a portion of the requisition was authorized by Ottawa for local purchase and was supplied so far as it was possible to obtain. There were some items which could not be purchased as they were not available. Just what Ottawa shipped direct, if any, this office is not aware of, as we are never advised. Notice of Shipment is sent direct to the teacher for her signature, and she in turn mails it direct to Ottawa, and we never get to know just what has been supplied on the requisition until I visit the school and check up with the teacher. In my opinion, a copy of the Notice of Shipment should be forwarded to this office so that we could have a record of what has been supplied direct from Ottawa.

Upon checking up our file I find, due to the change of teachers at the end of November, 1944, Mrs. Waywell did not purchase locally some articles authorized by the Department, and due to this office being so busy, it escaped our notice that this was not done. However, I am writing to Mrs. Yeatman today and requesting her to forward a further requisition covering the supplies she needs, and at the same time requesting a list of the goods which have already been received.

Indian Commissioner for B.C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B.C.

After a great deal of effort I have finally found someone who will redecorate the Campbell River Indian Day School, both interior and exterior, as well as out-buildings, and I enclose you, herewith, tender submitted to this office by Mr. Robert E. Yeatman of Quathiaski Cove, B.C., which will be self-explanatory.

As the interior and exterior of this building require decorating and as we have at last found someone who will do the work, I would recommend that the Department approve of this at an early date, as Mr. Yeatman informs me he must take advantage of dry weather and wishes to have it finished shortly after July 15th, as he has other work to do after that date. It will, therefore, be necessary to have the Department wire me at once if they approve, so that I can instruct him to proceed with the work, otherwise he will not be able to do it.

I consider the price asked is exceptionally good when the building is to receive two coats inside and out.

If we miss this opportunity to have it done now, I can give no assurance when I will be able to find anyone else to undertake the work. I, therefore, again request the Department to communicate with me by wire, as I would like to take advantage of this opportunity to get this work done.

Encs.

(M.S. Todd)

AIR MAIL

Mr. M. S. Todd, Indian Agent, Alert Bay, B.C.

On the recommendation of Indian Commissioner MacKay, it has been decided to accept the tender of $214.00 from R. E. Yeatman for material and labour required to paint the interior and exterior of the Campbell River Indian Day School building and the outbuildings.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

COPY SENT TO INDIAN COMMISSIONER MACKEY
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Todd's letter of June 29th and tender from Mr. R.E. Yeatman covering the supply of materials and labour required to paint the interior and exterior of the Campbell River Indian Day School building and the outbuildings at a cost of $214.00. It will be noted that Mr. Yeatman, if given the contract, is anxious to proceed with the work at once as he has other employment in view after July 15th, in view of which it is recommended that the Department advise Mr. Todd by airmail if funds are available for painting this school. An amount of $100.00 is provided in the estimates for this particular project, and as the question of painting this building has been the subject of comment by the School Inspector it is recommended that Mr. Todd be authorized to have the work done.

I may say that I am writing to the Agent pointing out to him that he has given us very little time to deal with this matter as his letter was not received at this office until July 3rd.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Enc.
Indian Commissioner for B. C., Department of Mines and Resources, Vancouver, B. C.

After a great deal of effort I have finally found someone who will redecorate the Campbell River Indian Day School, both interior and exterior, as well as out-buildings, and I enclose you, herewith, tender submitted to this office by Mr. Robert E. Yeatman of Quathiaski Cove, B. C., which will be self-explanatory.

As the interior and exterior of this building require decorating and as we have at last found someone who will do the work, I would recommend that the Department approve of this at an early date, as Mr. Yeatman informs me he must take advantage of dry weather and wishes to have it finished shortly after July 15th, as he has other work to do after that date. It will, therefore, be necessary to have the Department wire me at once if they approve, so that I can instruct him to proceed with the work, otherwise he will not be able to do it.

I consider the price asked is exceptionally good when the building is to receive two coats inside and out.

If we miss this opportunity to have it done now, I can give no assurance when I will be able to find anyone else to undertake the work. I, therefore, again request the Department to communicate with me by wire, as I would like to take advantage of this opportunity to get this work done.

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent.

Early this year/office advised the Department it was necessary to install a circulating oil heater in the Campbell River Indian Day School due to the fact that we were unable to get wood, and that the wood-burning heater was no longer safe.

In the Department's letter dated July 4th last, file #156-7-5 (WT1), they requested information regarding type required and its approximate cost. Following this, Commissioner MacKey in his letter dated July 25th last, file #6-11-4, requested to know if we could buy a suitable heater locally, and if so, to forward quotations so that the necessary Purchasing Order could be issued. The Commissioner further stated that if we were unable to buy one locally to advise him and they would endeavour to secure one in Vancouver.

Recently while in Vancouver I was informed that they were unable to buy one in Vancouver. At that time the B.C. Packers Ltd., Quathiaski Cove, wired me they could supply a stove but required immediate reply. As we had made arrangements with the oil company to obtain necessary stove oil, and as it was necessary to give them an immediate reply without forwarding it to Ottawa or the Commissioner's Office, I instructed them to supply this stove and have it installed in the Campbell River Indian Day School; as they were without heat due to the old stove having collapsed.

I attach hereto voucher #553 covering this purchase and recommend that it be paid. I might add this stove is of the larger type required for a school and is giving perfect satisfaction.

Encs.

Indian Agent.

Acknowledging your letter dated July 4th last, file #156-7-5 (W.T.l), authorizing supplies for Campbell River Indian Day School, and requesting information regarding a new heater, I wish to recommend as follows:

For several years we have had difficulty in obtaining wood for both Cape Mudge and Campbell River Schools. Last year we purchased an HH-50 Norge Oil Heater for the Cape Mudge School at an approximate price of $125.00. This heater is proving very satisfactory and has overcome our difficulty with fuel.

It is very difficult for teachers to have a fuel problem when they live so far from the Agency, and I would like to install an oil burner here. Re: Campbell River and Cape Mudge Schools

I am enclosing a memorandum dated June 14th, from District School Inspector Davey, with regard to the admission of Indian children to the Provincial schools, Cape Mudge and Campbell River.

You will note that new Provincial schools are being erected at these points and that in the case of the Campbell River School, seventeen Indian children can be enrolled. On the basis of enrolment, the contribution required from the Department towards the capital cost of buildings and equipment will be $18,700.00.

In the case of the Provincial school being erected on Quadra Island, twenty-three Indian children can be enrolled and on the basis of enrolment, the contribution required from the Department towards the capital cost of buildings and equipment will be approximately $30,000.00.

Mr. Davey has covered the matter fully in his memorandum and there would appear to be no need to enlarge on the subject at this time.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Campbell River Indian Day School.
Cape Mudge Indian Day School.

In accordance with the recommendation of the Joint Parliamentary Committee that Indian children, wherever possible, be educated in association with other children, our field officials have been carrying on negotiations with various provincial departments of education.

These talks have been particularly successful in British Columbia where we have our own School Inspector. Mr. Davey, a former provincial department of education official, has been able to make considerable progress in having Indian children admitted to provincial schools. The total of such children now enrolled in these schools has risen to 456.

For some time Inspector Davey has been in discussion with the Campbell River School District concerning the two new provincial schools being erected at Campbell River and on Quadra Island (near the Cape Mudge Reserve). Please find attached a complete memorandum from him, clearly outlining the situation at each of these schools insofar as it concerns the Indian children who might be educated in them. As these are children of the United Church faith, there will be no objection from local missionaries to the proposals outlined by Inspector Davey. A summary of his suggestions is as follows:

(a) Campbell River - size of school 21 rooms including library, home economics and industrial arts.

Cost of school - $485,599 plus 6% architect's fees and $61,961 equipment.
White enrolment - 489
Indian enrolment - 17

Estimated contribution from Indian Affairs
Based on basis of enrolment - $16,700.

(b) Cape Mudge (Quadra Island Provincial School) -

Size of school & rooms (Superior)

Cost of school, anticipated $26,310
and equipment at $11,834.

Transportation - one mile walk to bus and
5 mile trip by bus.

White enrolment - 72
Indian enrolment - 23

Estimated contribution from Indian Affairs
Based on basis of enrolment - $30,000.

You will note Inspector Davy recommends that we
continue both our small one-room schools as primary and kindergarten
rooms. I concur in his recommendation as too often the first two
years of school are taken up with teaching these Indian children
to speak English. Mr. Indian Commissioner Arnell has recommended
that the Department make a contribution towards the capital costs
of provincial schools at both Campbell River and Quadra Island.
I concur in his recommendation and would request that we be
authorized to prepare an agreement to be entered into with the
Campbell River School District, along similar lines to the draft
agreement attached hereto.

HIS MAJESTY KING GEORGE THE SIXTH in right of Canada, represented herein by The Minister of Mines and Resources, hereinafter called the "Minister"

- and -

THE ASHcroft SCHOOL DISTRICT NO. 30 in the Province of British Columbia hereinafter called the "School District"

WHEREAS the St. George's Indian Residential School is situated near the town of Lytton in the Province of British Columbia;

AND WHEREAS this school is graduating into high school an increasing number of Indian pupils;

AND WHEREAS Lytton High School operated by the School District is now overcrowded and will require an extra classroom to accommodate these pupils;

AND WHEREAS nine of the additional twenty pupils for whom high school educational facilities are required are Indian children;

AND WHEREAS the School District estimates that the cost of this addition will be approximately fourteen hundred dollars plus two hundred and fifty dollars for additional equipment or a total of sixteen hundred and fifty dollars;

AND WHEREAS THE Minister is of the opinion that these Indian children can best receive high school education in the Lytton High School and that the financial assistance agreed upon in the terms hereinafter mentioned is fair and reasonable;

NOW this Agreement Witnesseth that the parties hereto mutually covenant and agree as follows:

1. That this Agreement shall commence on the first day of January, 1949, and shall be subject to the terms, conditions and stipulations hereinafter expressed, that is to say:

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6418, file 855-5, part 2)
2. The Minister shall pay to the School District an amount of seven hundred and forty-two dollars and fifty cents ($742.50) which sum represents nine twentieths of the estimated expenditure for the establishment of an additional high school classroom.

3. The Minister shall pay to the School District, tuition fees for these Indian High School pupils in accordance with the provisions of Section 133 "Public Schools Act" of the Province of British Columbia.

4. The School District shall render each quarter to the Minister a statement of the tuition fees to be paid; this statement shall be in the form as prescribed by Section 133, "Public Schools Act" of the Province of British Columbia.

5. It is understood and agreed upon between the parties hereto that neither the execution of this Agreement nor anything contained herein nor the expenditure of any funds hereunder by His Majesty in right of Canada shall be deemed to confer upon the Minister or any officer or department of the Government of Canada any right of supervision or control over any school or educational institution operated by the School District, with respect to which any funds are expended under this Agreement, nor any supervision or control over the administrative or teaching personnel or the curriculum or the methods of instruction or the materials of instruction of any such school or educational institution.

6. The Minister shall endeavour to maintain a standard of health, cleanliness and clothing among these Indian pupils such as would be comparable to that of white
children attending the school.

7. Either party may effect determination or cessation of this agreement on the thirtieth day of June in any year by giving to the other party notice in writing by registered letter of intention to effect such determination or cessation, such notice to be good and to take effect as aforesaid only if received on or before the first day of September next preceding the thirtieth day of June aforesaid.
